column2: CINCINNATI, Jan. 23.--Superintendent Woon, of the Water-works Department, to-day submitted to the Board of Public Works an exhaustive report upon the present water supply of the city and the necessity of its immediate enlargement.

The seats of the Brooklyn Tabernacle were publicly rented for the first time last evening. The total number of seats in the church is 647, of which 556 were offered at auction, the remainder having been previously disposed of or reserved for the use of strangers. The auction was directed by E.E. Hoyt. The attendance was large and the bidding spirited.

The second ball this season of the Family Circle Dancing Class was given last evening at Delmonico's. To make it as different as possible from the balls given by the Patriarchs the rooms were lighted with pink instead of yellow light, and the crash was removed from the ball-room floor. There were no decorations. The invitations were from 10 to 2 o'clock.
ALBANY, Jan. 23.--Superintendent Fairman, of the Insurance Department, has issued his annual chart showing the condition of the New-York joint stock fire insurance companies Dec. 31, 1881.

The Rep. Edward Cowley, better known as Shepherd Cowley, whose establishment for the care of little children was broken up by the authorities and himself sent to the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island for cruelty to defenseless little ones, delivered a lecture last evening in Republican Hall. The Shepherd was some years ago the Chaplain of the penitentiary, and while acting in ...
When Gen. Grant was asked yesterday about his rumored purchase of the Morelos Railroad in Mexico, he said there was nothing to warrant the statement that he had bought the road.

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--In the Court of Appeals, to-day, business was transacted as follows: No. --Maria Phinney, Administratrix, , respondent, vs. William Orth et al., appellants; argued by Henry Daily, Jr., for appellants, submitted by respondent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Dr. B. Joy Jeffries, of Boston, appeared by invitation before the Naval Committee of the House to-day in reference to the bill now before the committee concerning an international commission to decide as to the standard methods of testing visual power and color perception in navies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--After the call of States in the House, to-day Mr. Orth, of Indiana, reported from the Committee on Foreign Affairs the resolution that the President be requested to obtain from the British Government a list of all American citizens, naturalized or native born, under arrest or imprisonment by authority of said Government, with a statement of the causes of such arrest or imprisonment, ...

We have lately been made aware that certain references made by New-York journals to the representatives of Pennsylvania as typical protectionists of the extreme kind are resented by those gentlemen as unfair.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 23.--Great indignation prevails in this city owing to the criminal carelessness of the railroad officers which led to the terrible collision on the Charleston and ...
Wall-street overran with rumors yesterday announcing a prospective panic. The bears were in control on the floors of the Stock Exchange, and prices were sent whirling downward.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Nearly 50,000 bids for star service in the Territories were filed in the Post Office Department on Jan. 7, and the contracts will be awarded in March on about 3,000 routes.

The Correctional Tribunal of the Seine today passed a judgment on a group of financiers which will serve as a warning to many Directors of companies who are about to be confronted with the problem of evolving a dividend.
PARIS, Jan. 23.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Committee of Thirty-three presented their report on the bill for the revision of the Constitution.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The tug H. P. Farrington, belonging to Cornell's tow line, was blown up at 7 o'clock to-night while lying at Peck's Dock, Haverstraw, and destroyed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 23.--The ocean tide yesterday afternoon was lower than for several years past. The bar opposite the Hotel Brighton was bare to a point beyond half the length of the iron pier, and the bar was covered with sea crabs in the spawning state, and with large sea clams.

Capt. Weightman, of the steam-ship Longhirst, which arrived from Barrow yesterday, states that he was 19 days in crossing the ocean. Strong westerly gales and high head-seas were encountered during the whole passage and delayed the steam-ship considerably. On Sunday last, when about 100 miles east of Sandy Hook, a disabled brig-rigged steam-ship was sighted.

Steinway Hall was filled last evening by an audience in which the Scotch element largely predominated, and which was brought together to listen to the songs of Scotland as rendered by Mr. Kennedy, the well-known vocalist, and his family. The occasion was the second concert given by Mr. Kennedy since his return from a tour around the world, during which he has been absent from this ...
The weekly conference of the Baptist Pastors yesterday was entirely devoted to the Rev. Dr. Williams's paper on "The Theories of Future Punishments."

The investigation into the alleged mismanagement of the Dock Department by the Grand Jury, acting on the suggestions contained in the charge of Recorder Smyth at the opening of the term, resulted in the drafting of a presentment, which was handed in to the Recorder in General Sessions yesterday.

An ingenious system of piano robbery, carried on by an organized band of swindlers, has just been brought to light, chiefly through the efforts of T. Leeds Waters, a Fourteenth-street piano-dealer. One day in September last a woman who gave her name as Wiess entered Mr. Waters's store and said she wanted to buy a second-hand piano.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Permanent Exhibition Company to-day a resolution approving of the action of the Board of Directors in selling the exhibition building was adopted.
BOSTON, Jan. 23.--The fierce north-west gale, which set in Sunday afternoon, continued last night, and this morning there were no indications of an abatement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23, 1882. The national bank notes received for re demption to-day amounted to $343,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $722,023 86, and from Customs $706,484 69.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The Board of Supervising Inspectors of Steam Vessels reconvened to-day, Gen. Dumont in the chair. Mr. Tower read a letter from George H. Kelley, of Providence, relative to fog signals and other measures for the prevention of collisions at sea, which was ...

--Mr. Charles Burr Todd, who is known for the laborious investigations he has made in the origin and history of the Burr family in America, including its most celebrated member, contributes to the February number of Lippincott a valuable historical paper on Gen. William Eaton, the neglected if not forgotten hero of Derne, a city beyond the Lybian desert.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--The expected general advance in west-bound freight to 45, 32, 26, and 19 cents, respectively, on first, second, third, and fourth class goods was not made here this morning as was expected.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 23.--The corner-stone of the new Cotton Exchange Building, at the northwest corner of Carondelet and Gravier streets, ...

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 23.--The ice in the Erie Canal is eight inches thick and an abundant crop is expected. Cutting commenced at West Troy this morning. Judge Ingalls has decided that owners of land on the banks of a navigable stream have a legal right to stake out as much ice fronting their land as they can stow on their premises, provided they have erected a barricade in accordance with the law.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--In the case of the United States against the Executors of the late Samuel A. Way--an action of contract to recover $55,000 in settlement of duties and penalties upon importations of tobacco--a decision in favor of the defendants was rendered in the United States Circuit Court here this afternoon. Way died soon after agreeing to pay this sum to the Government.

Another forgery by ex-Auditor Palmer, of Newark, N.J., was discovered yesterday. His total deficiency up to this time is $188,000. Suit has been begun against the ex-Auditor's bondsmen to recover the amount of his peculations and to compel the bondsmen to transfer to the city the ...
CINCINNATI, Jan. 23.--A dispatch to the Times-Star, from Nashville, says: "The river has fallen 15 inches in the last 12 hours.
BERNE, Jan. 23.--The National Council have decided to transform the Swiss Consulate at Washington into a Legation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--William B. Stevenson, book-keeper in Disston's saw works, in Tacony, who left the city a week ago taking with him $3,000 of his employers' funds and Millie Stanton, a girl of 19 years, who worked in the establishment, was arrested upon his return to the city this morning. He will have a hearing to-morrow.

The Executive Committee of the National Association of Trotting-horse Breeders met last evening at the Everett House. It was decided to hold the next meeting of the association at the grounds of the Gentlemen's Driving Association in this City on or about Oct. 1 next. The time of the meeting will be definitely fixed later on by the Committee of Arrangements, which consists of ...

The thirteenth annual bonspiel, or champion match of all the curling clubs of America, under the auspices of the Grand National Curling Association, was played in part on Cortland Lake, at Yonkers, yesterday, and will be finished this afternoon. Comparatively little is known among Americans about this interesting sport, but for over four centuries it has been the Scot's delight.

Another forgery by ex-City Auditor Palmer was discovered yesterday in Newark. It purports to be an award for damages to William Riker amounting to over $4,000, and makes his deficiency nearly $188,000.

TRENTON, Jan. 23.--The returns made by the Assessors of the several counties in the State to State Controller Anderson show a total valuation of the taxable realty and personalty in the State of $527,451,222 50. This is an increase of $9,545,947 over the returns of 1880 in 19 of the 21 counties. Only two of the counties show a declining valuation.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--The first production of the Greek play of "OEdipus" before a popular audience, to-night, preparatory to its reproduction in other cities and on the road, was in several respects a flattering success. The performance of the actors was, as a whole, remarkably smooth and sincere, and have evidence of exceptional care in preparation.
BERLIN, Jan. 23.--The Government has presented in the Landtag a bill providing for buying up six private railways at a cost of 477,000,000 marks, mostly payable in Treasury bonds.

There is going the rounds of the newspapers much ingenious gossip to the effect that Mr. BLAINE proposes to reorganize what he can find of the old Whig Party. To this end, it is said, "he will preside at all the Webster and Clay meetings that shall be held" wherever he can reach them.

The Comley-Barton Opera Company, by arrangement with Mr. D'Oyly Carte, gave a performance in English of Offenbach's opera comique, "Madame Favart." An attempt was made last Saturday evening to force an entrance to the residence of Mr. Walter T. Marvin, at One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street and Willis-avenue, which proved unsuccessful. The burglar was fired upon by Nelson J. Marvin, a son of Mr. Marvin, and is believed to have been wounded.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 23.--William, Isaac, and Sarah Jane Baker, the surviving children and heirs of James Baker, deceased, have commenced a suit in Common Pleas Court for the possession of that portion of the city known as Whisky Island.

The only man who ever beat a nitro-glycerine explosion after it was once started is John McCleary, of Pennsylvania. He saw what was coming and ran. His coat-tail was cut off and his back was somewhat scratched.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The concession made by the Choctaw Nation to the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway Company will not be ratified by Congress without opposition. The bill providing for a ratification was favorably reported to the Senate from the Railroad Committee of that body, and was recently recommitted on motion of Mr. Hawley.
BOSTON, Jan. 23.--Charles Dana Co., provision dealers, have failed, with liabilities of from $100,000 to $150,000.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23.--The first Message of Mayor Whyte was submitted to the City Council this afternoon. The financial condition of the corporation on Dec. 31, 1881, is shown to be as follows: Amount of funded debt, $34,894,191 73; guaranteed liabilities, $1,492,000; total, $36,386,191 73. Of this amount interest is provided and paid on about $15,000,000 by various railroads and ...

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 23.--This afternoon Jailer George A. Stevens stopped at the door of "Chip" Smith's cell and informed the unfortunate young man that the Supreme Court had denied the motion for a new trial.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 23.--P.A. Gilzinger, a prominent inventor and mechanic of this city, became violently deranged here on Saturday last, and was taken to the Hudson River Insane Asylum, at Poughkeepsie, yesterday afternoon.

The new Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company is an assured fact. The preliminary papers of incorporation were signed on Saturday and will be filed to-day. Subscriptions to the stock have been made promptly and without felicitation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 23.--There have been conflicting reports regarding the treatment of the Chinese students who were ordered back to China several months ago since their arrival home.

There is living at Middletown a family in which nine distinct languages are spoken, namely: English, German, French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Greek, Arabic, and Turkish, besides number of dialects connected mostly with Italian and Spanish.

--Seldom does a magazine print a more readable and entirely fresh chapter of anecdotes and sketches concerning an eminent public man than the Atlantic has this month in Prof. Herbert Tuttle's "Some Traits of Bismarck." It is the best thing in the number, and nothing in any magazine this month offers better entertainment.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--Daniel Berrigan went to the house of Daniel Kelly, in Melvalestreet, last night, and, without provocation, stabbed Mary Snell, who was visiting there. The knife penetrated her forehead, inflicting a dangerous wound. She is a stranger to her assailant and resides at Pleasantville, N.J. Berrigan was arrested early this morning and held for trial.

Further testimony was taken yesterday by Messrs. Smith, Elwell, and Schwab, representing the Chamber of Commerce, as a special committee to inquire into the pilotage system of this port. The Pilot Commissioners were examined yesterday. Capt. Snow declared that in the opinion of the Pilot Commissioners the number of pilots now licensed was none too large, though it was possible that the number of boats employed might be lessened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--1 A.M.--For NewEngland, very cold and generally fair weather, north-west winds, shifting to easterly, and rising, followed by falling, barometer.

TORONTO, Jan. 23.--In the appeal case of McLaren, of Carlton Place, Ont., against the Canada Central Railway for damages to lumber by fire caused by sparks from a passing locomotive, a special jury to-night gave a verdict for the plaintiff, awarding him $100,000.
Mr. J. Nelson, a resident of this City, and for many years a prominent member of the Masonic fraternity, dropped dead at 7 o'clock last evening in the reading room of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 23.--Dr. S. Chance, a prominent physician at St. Paris, Champaign County, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself in a wood-shed. Mental depression is assigned as the cause for the deed.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Jan. 23.--The Mormon question was very generally presented by the clergymen here yesterday, and a strong petition to Congress for effective action against polygamy is receiving hundreds of signatures.

PITTSTON, Penn., Jan. 23.--A Mrs. Delaney was found dead in her bed this morning. The body was burned to a crisp. The cause of the accident is unknown.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--The Police were informed on Saturday that Theodore Hecker, 30 years old, had been missing from home since Jan. 15, on which evening he parted with a number of friends. This morning his body was found floating in the Delaware at Race-street wharf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The crowd which assembled at the Court-house this morning was unprecedented in the history of the famous trial of Guiteau. The Police regulations were inadequate, and Judge, counsel, members of the Bar, and others entitled to be present had to elbow their way through a swaying mass of humanity which surrounded every entrance to the court-room.

Without exception yesterday was the coldest day that the Winter of 1881-2 has thus far produced. On the morning of the 4th inst. the thermometer marked a temperature of 6 above zero, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning the mercury in the thermometer at Central Park Observatory sank to 9 above zero, and at 10 o'clock last night Signal Service officers in the Equitable Building recorded a temperature of 4 above zero.

LONDON, Jan. 11.--This is the time of year when we look for what we call in England "severe weather." It may, indeed, almost be called midwinter. "The solar year commences," says William Howitt in his "Book of the Seasons," "in the very depth of Winter, and I open my record of its various aspects under that of its unmitigated austerity.

There seems to be throughout the country a revival of the anti-Mormon agitation that has at intervals recalled the attention of Congress to a much-discussed subject. Usually the debate, begun in the newpapers, languidly taken up in the pulpits, and finally dying away in the halls of Congress, has not seriously disturbed the Mormon magnates.

TRENTON, Jan. 24.--Ever since the Democrats of the Assembly brought their party into disgrace by the scene of wild confusion and disorder that made the opening of the One Hundred and Sixth Legislature memorable, they have been trying to mitigate their offense by saying, in the orthodox school-boy fashion, "You made us mad."

The resignation of a Ministry is a sign of the healthy working of a constitutional Government if the act is not too frequently repeated. In Great Britain, which has one of the most perfect systems of representative Government in the world, the Ministry orders a fresh election whenever its claim to represent the convictions of a majority of the electors is seriously questioned, and promptly resigns if defeated at the polls.

LONDON, Jan. 24.--A Paris dispatch annouuces that urgency has been votod for the debate in the Chamber of Deputies on the report of the committee on the bill for the revision of the Constitution. Funeral services over the remains of the late Major-Gen. Silas Casey were held yesterday afternoon at the Lafayette-Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, the Rev. Dr. T.L. Cuyler and the Rev. George F. Pentecost officiating. The remains of the deceased soldier were inclosed in a casket covered with black broadcloth, the plate, candles, and trimmings being of silver.

The flow of lava from the noted Hawaiian volcano, Mauna Loa, lately in eruption, is the greatest observed there within the last 50 years. It began on Nov. 5, 1880, and continued without interruption till the middle of August last year. Probably no lava flow has been so largely photographed, and an artist, M. Furneaux, has represented various phases of it in 38 oilpaintings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Some of the members of the committee of the Tariff Convention, who have recently visited this city and called upon the President, reported that he was not in favor of the creation of a Tariff Commission. It seems that they did not fully understand the President's position.

ALBANY, Jan. 34.--The Assembly entered to-day upon the fourth week of its unorganized existence. The proceedings were characterized by a little more life than usual, the younger members particularly contributing to the activity of the short session. Sundry indignant Democrats of the regular faction protested against the delay in organizing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24.--Twenty-three Princeton youths are in trouble. They indulged in an old-fashioned orthodox spree one night not long ago, marched through the streets of the village in a body, sang bacchanalian songs, tore up fences, smashed gates and street lamps, and dashed things to pieces generally. Their route was through the centre of the old town, and such destruction marked their path as would have made a fully developed hurricane fairly...

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 24.--The cold wave has come upon this city with great severity, and advices show that the entire river region has been visited by extreme cold. The mercury marked 18 below zero in the upper portion of the city early this morning. It afterward receded to 4 below at noon, and to-night, at 3 o'clock, it is standing at 10 below. There is no wind and the sky is clear.

BERLIN, Jan. 24.--In the Reichstag, during debate on the budget to-day, discussion arose concerning the late imperial rescript. Prince Bismarck said it did not aim to create a new Constitution. The maxim, "The King reigns, but does not govern," did not apply in Germany.

Warner, the Secretary, and that the line had been abandoned since the 9th inst., when the last trip was made and the last boat left this City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24, 1882. The President has in contemplation a series of State dinners, but so far has not been able to fix the dates. The first will probably be given in about two weeks. The President has not yet decided the question of holding public receptions, but it is understood that none will be held until after the Lonten season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Gen. Sherman today received the following telegram from Gen. Sheridan: "I forward this morning" history of Lieut. McDonald's arrest in Mexico. He was on an Indian trail and went to a Mexican town for forage. He and party of scouts were arrested and afterward released by higher authority and have returned home."

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 25.--The Wheat market was purely and simply a speculative one. Prices were unsettled, and the feeling was nervous and uncertain throughout. The board was full of rumors of corners, and the presence of one or two large operators from abroad created unusual remark.

The news that a verdict had been rendered in the Gaiteau case brought people out of their homes to-night not withstanding the inclement weather, and the hotel lobbies were thronged. Naturally the trial was almost the only topic of conversation, and so far as expressions at places of public resort could be heard, the verdict was universally approved and the jury highly commended.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, Jan. 25.--The Directors of the Bank of Prince Edward Island will make up $85,000 and the shareholders $125,000 of the bank's deficiency. If the depositors and outside banks will accept the offer made them, namely, repayment in equal installments at one, two, and three years, without interest, the bank will resume on a good basis.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 25.--Mr. Z. Chaffee Trustee and Assignee of the A. W. Sprague Manufacturing Company, has received from William H. Hopkins and 150 associates an offer of $2,600,000 for the entire property in his hands. He has accepted the offer, subject to the approval of the court.

Before he could begin his address the prisoner broke in with the statement that his sister had been doing some silly talking in Chicago; she meant well, but she was no lawyer.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 25.--The steamer Gen-- eral Whitney, Capt. Hallett, for New-York, returned to this port to-day somewhat disabled, hav-- ing, while at anchor off Chatham in a north-east gale, broken her windlass and lost her anchor and chain. She will repair and proceed. She reports the Pollock Rip Light-ship gone from her moorings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The bill to permit Associate Justice Ward Hunt, of the Supreme Court, to retire was passed in the House to-day, and will soon become a law. Justice Hunt was commissioned on Dec. 10, 1872, and the period of 10 years of service which would entitle him to retire will end next Winter.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 21.--The Hon. Jonathan Norcross, of Georgia, who is spending the Winter in Florida, in this city, was the last Republican candidate for Governor of Georgia. CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25.--The news of Guiteau's conviction and of the manner in which the jury returned so early an answer was received in Cleveland with universal expressions of satisfaction, and when the result was read from the stages of the Opera-house and the Academy of Music, the people became so excited that they arose in their places and cheered.

DUBLIN, Jan. 25.--The steward on the estate of Mrs. Morony, at Milltown, was shot dead last night. He was 80 years old. Mrs. Morony has been for some time under Police protection. No arrests have been made.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 25.--Floyd Whitney was arrested in this city last night charged with having murdered Warren Stafford at Chatham, Tioga County, Penn., on July 25, 1880. He admits having killed Stafford, but says he acted under great provocation and did not intend to take his life. Since the murder Whitney has been a fugitive in Colorado and various parts of this State. He will be taken back to Pennsylvania.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 25.--Over 300 names, including those of some of the best man in the two cities, have signed a call for a meeting, to be held to-morrow, to protest against polygamous Mormonism. TROY, N.Y., Jan. 27.--A girl in a collar factory here saw a man fall through the ice in the Hudson River this morning. A hat was found on the ice, near the spot where he fell through. The body has not been recovered.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--The following Stock Exchange firms have failed: Charles Ray, Jr., with heavy differences in Eries; Da Costa Fuld; Nathan Hertz, dealers principally in foreign securities; also the old-established firm of Manners-Sutton Graham.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--The Secretary of the Interior has transmitted to Congress the report of the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad Company for 1881. The Directors claim that enormous benefits have resulted in the West from the completion of this railroad in developing latent resources.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Several votes were taken in the Senate to-day on various propositions which arose during the discussion of the Sherman Three Per Cent. Funding bill, but a final vote was not reached. Mr. Sherman is determined that his bill shall not be allowed to die without a strong effort on his part to save it.

Col. Elwell S. Otis. Twentieth Infantry, is to command the school.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 28.--The Richmond and Danville Company have completed the Western North Carolina Railroad to Paint Rock and Pigeon River. Trains are now running to both points. Worth, and put an end to all talk of a forfeiture of the contract because the road was not completed by Nov. 1, 1881.

READING, Penn., Jan. 28.--The accounts of Col. George W. Grant, Postmaster of this city, have been investigated by B.N. Sharretts, of New-York, Special Agent of the Post Office Department, and found to be short about $3,000. This discovery was made to-day and caused much excitement, as Grant has heretofore borne a high reputation.

BUFFALO, Jan. 28.--In the Court of Oyer and Terminer this morning the application of District Attorney Hatch for a nolle prosequi to be entered in the indictment for murder against Orrin C. Thomas and Edward G. Parker was refused by Judge Barker.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 28.--The Official Gazette to-day says the North-west Mounted Police force is to be increased from 200 men to 500 men by March 1.

BUFFALO, Jan. 28.--The horse disease known as "pink-eye" has at last reached this city, and is causing the street railroad company especially a great deal of inconvenience. This morning 81 horses were down with the disease in its most virulent form.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 28.--Special Agent John A. Galbraith, who was sent here to investigate charges made against Gen. McMillan, has completed his investigation, and to-day telegraphed to Col. Daniel B. Parker, Chief Post Office Inspector, Washington, saying: "I have fully investigated the charges against Postmaster McMillan. They are wholly malicious and entirely unsustained."

BATAVIA, Jan. 28.--A call has been issued by the National Christian Association, which has its head-quarters in Chicago, for a convention to be held in this place on the 7th, 8th, and 9th of February. The organization is opposed to all secret societies in general, and to Masonry in particular.

PETERSBURG, Jan. 28.--The latest news from Irkutsk states that Engineer Melville has proceeded to the mouth of the River Lena to resume the search for Lieut.-Commander De Long, with the greatest energy, aided by natives. A countryman came to this city on Tuesday last with a load of hay, and after having it weighed he drank too much beer and lost the weight account. He then delivered the hay, and received $6 on account until he could find out the actual weight, but on his way home he drank more beer, and lost the money.

PHILADHLPHIA, JaN. 28.--About 9 o'clock this evening, while Dr. A.F. Miller, a resident of Cermantown, was passintg Old York road and Fisher's-lane, an unknown masked man grasped his horse, and, producing a pistol, demanded that the Doctor pass over his money. PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28.--The well-known actor John E. McDonough is lying dangerously ill at his residence in this city. He is suffering from a cancer, involving the lower jaw, tongue, and neck. His death is hourly expected.

One of the duodecimo law manuals which are becoming popular. A large audience filled the hall of the Cooper Union last evening to hear Mr. E.B. Drew's lecture on the Chinese. LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 29.--At a late hour last night Michael Gumpf stabbed Charles Carr, inflicting a probably fatal wound. Gumpf made his escape. The affair was the result of a quarrel about a woman.

THE TROAD, Nov. 20.--At the head of that gulf which washes the base of Phrygian Ida lies an extensive plain, bounded by a semicircle of lofty mountains. It was known to the ancients as the plain of Thebe, for even after the town of Thebe had been long destroyed the power of the Homeric poetry kept its name alive in the minds of the Greeks, and it clung to the plain through all antiquity.

George Johnston, a colored man, whose friends claim that he was 104 years of age, died Saturday morning in a squatter's shanty at No. 309 East One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, where he has lived since 1859. Johnston was certainly a very old man, but whether he had lived more than a century is a matter of conjecture.

LONDON, Jan. 17.--The first indications of the coming season are manifesting themselves. The sea of fashion is at ebb-tide. It will soon flow back to the London beach, and gradually refill all the nooks and corners which it has left almost high and dry since last September. Cabinet Ministers come to town for good at the first breath of the returning tide.

The semi-annual dividends payable in Boston in February will aggregate $3,597,455. Ex-President Paul A. Chadbourne will accept the Presidency of the Massachusetts Agricultural College, to which he has just been chosen. and will serve the first year without pay. An effort is being made to raise an endowment fund of $100,000 in one-thousand-dollar subscriptions for the college.

John Horan and his wife occupy a suite of apartments on the second floor of the house No. 547 Greenwith-street. The house is an old-fashioned private residence, which has been remodeled to accommodate five families. The apartments in which Horan lives consist of a front sitting-room.

The steamship William Burbitt, Capt. Granville, arrived from Newcastle yesterday after a stormy passage of nearly 19 days. She left the Tyne on the afternoon of the 9th during a strong north-easterly gale. The weather was very thick in Pentland Firth, and the winds were unfavorable and the seas rough while passing through the North Sea and the English Channel.

Mollie Holbrook, alias Mollie Hoy, one of the boldest and most expert of the many female thieves in this country, was arrested late on Saturday night by Detectives Cosgrove, McNaught, Rogers, and Wood, of Inspector Byrnes's command, on a bench warrant issues by Recorder Smyth. She is under indictment for larceny from the person, and the prospect is that her conviction will speedily follow.

After much preliminary announcement and speculation. "CEdipus Tyrannus" was presented last night at Booth's Theatre before a large audience. PARIS, Jan. 30.--The billiard-match between Vignaux and Slosson began this evening, in the presence of a large number of spectators. The principal French and American professionals, including Schaefer and Daly, were present. Vignaux played first and missed. Slosson followed, and also missed. At the end of the evening's play Slosson had made 600 points, his average being 50. Vignaux scored 340, his average being 28.

PARIS, Jan. 30.--The Francais states that in view of the claims lodged against it the Union Generale, acting in conformity with legal advice, suspended payment to-day until the general meeting of its shareholders, which will be held on Friday next. The Messager de Paris announces that at the instance of the Union Generale a judicial Administrator of its affairs has been appointed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The National Board of Health to-day received reports showing that during the week ending Jan. 28 there were 11 deaths from small-pox in New-York City, 1 death in Wilmington, Del.; 6 cases in Dayton, Ohio; 3 cases of varioloid in Indianapolis, Ind. ; 2 cases of small-pox in Winchester, Va.; 3 cases of varioloid in Louisville, Ey., and 16 cases of small-pox and 6 deaths in Gourd, Kan.

The Senate has concurred in the House amendments to the new Election bill, and unless the Governor refuse his approval it will become a law. The provisions and regulations for the registration of voters are full and precise. Every voter must produce his certificate of registration at the time he offers to vote, and there is every opportunity to register so as to become qualified as a voter. The registration is permanent.

Wall-street was somewhat excited yesterday when, about noon, the telegraphic announcement was made that the Union Generals of Paris had suspended payment. The first report of it was doubted, and when, later on, confirmation of it came, the effect of the failure on the stock market was so slight that it occasioned more surprise and curiosity than the failure itself did.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Whitney Bellows, D. D., Pastor of All Souls' Church, Fourth-avenue and Twentieth-street, died at his residence, No. 232 East Fifteenth-street, at 11 o'olock yesterday morning. His death was painless, and he was conscious until 15 minutes before the event. At midnight of Sunday a change for the worse in his condition was observed, and he continued to sink until the end came.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 30.--A lawyer was called at midnight last night to draft a will for Lawrence Ager. The attorney found Ager and his wife at the point of death, the woman suffering from hemorrhage of the lungs. Ager informed the lawyer that he had over $2,000 to dispose of.

PARIS, Feb. 3.--Slosson won the billiardmatch to-night, making a total of 3,000 points. Vignaux's total count was 2,553. The attendance was very large. At the commencement of the play this evening Vignaux declared that if he lost he would demand revenge in an eight days' game of 4,000 points. Slosson's average to-night was 32 and Vignaux's 26.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23.--Several changes have been made in the Criminal Court room since the jury brought in their verdict of "guilty as indieted" against the murderer of President Garfield. The tiers of chairs in the rear part of the room have been removed, and in place of the well-dressed ...

COAL FIELD, Va.., Feb. 3.--An explosion occurred at the Grove shaft of the Midlothian coal mines, about a mile and a half from here, at about 1 o'clock this afternoon. Thirty-two men were caught in the shaft, and there is little or no hope that any of them will be got out alive.

The difficulties which have beset the proposed international military match at Wimbledon between teams representing the British Volunteers and our State Militia or National Guardsmen were, perhaps, inevitable.

MONTEVIDEO, Feb. 2.--The Spanish manof-war Consuelo has sunk in dock. DUBLIN, Feb. 3.--Mr. Harris, who was one of the traversers in the State trials, has been unconditionally released from Galway Jail.

Oscar Wilde talked to an audience of about 1,800 persons in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening on "The English Renaissance," but he made the extremities of his swallow-tail coat the object of more attention than his words. The assemblage was thoroughly matter-of-fact, with the exception of two persons.

At the meeting of the Tammany General Committee last evening the Chairman, Senator John G. Boyd, announced that he had been so busy since the organization of the committee that he had not yet had time to appoint the standing committees.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 3.--This afternoon fire broke out in the Commercial Elevator, a structure of brick, slate, and corrugated iron, and the rapid spread of the flames rendered its destruction complete. The Marine Block, adjoining, and the Sternberg Elevator, close by, were saved with great difficulty.

BRIDGEPORT, Feb. 3.--There was great joy here to-day over the fact that last evening this pleasant city became the birthplace of the second elephant ever born in captivity. The proud owner of the animal was sought by the masses, who desired to congratulate him upon the event, but the hero of many circus campaigns was not easily accessible.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3, 1882. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amounted to $206,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $461,604.12, and from Customs $722,- 422.83.

The annual presentation of badges to the marksmen of the Seventh Regiment took place at the new regimental armory last evening. There was a very large number of spectators present, including many ladies. The State marksman's badges are presented to every member of the State Militia who qualifies by scoring 25 out of a possible 50 ...

Seligman Co., H.S. Henry, of No. 44 Exchangeplace; D. Appleton, Mr. Kaufman, the manager of the Bank of Nevada Agency, and D. Jackson Steward, of No. 21 William-street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--The House has a select committee on the alcoholic liquor traffic, and a motion is pending in the Senate for the appointment of a committee on the same subject in that body.

PANAMA, Jan. 25.--The complete success of Admiral Lynch's expedition to the Peruvian mountain towns is now confirmed. Leaving Lima Dec. 21 he took a somewhat circuitous route, which compelled him to march a much greater distance than by the Oroya Ravine.

About 200 members of the American Agricultural Association left Chambers-street ferry yesterday morning in a special train of cars supplied by the Erie Railroad and in charge of Conductor William J. Van Duzen to inspect Mr. Theodore A. Havemeyer's Mountain Side Farm at Mahwah, N.J. Sleighs awaited the party at the Mahwah depot, and to the jingle of the bells they were driven rapidly to the farm-house.

ALBANY, Feb. 3.--No movement toward an organization of the Senate was made by the Democrats to-day, and there is not likely to be any until the organization of the Assembly is completed.

Mr. Erastus W. Glover, of No. 231 West Fifteenth-street, who has been employed as a brakeman on the Washington express, fell from the train as it was passing through NewHaven, Conn., on Thursday night and was killed.

The fire in the ruins of the old World Building was completely extinguished during the night of Thursday, and yesterday very little smoke rose above the piles of brick and iron and charred beams of which the burned structure had been composed.

It is now sixty-eight years since the American brig General Armstrong began her memorable and eventful career. Up to that time the vessel, for all we know, had simply been an adventurous craft, pursuing British vessels when found without convoy, and carrying consternation into merchant fleets of Great Britain.

CAIRO, Feb. 3--The Khedive has accepted Mahmoud Baroudi as Prime Minister, and the latter has accepted the office and will submit a list of Ministers to the Khedive. The Notables hesitated to prepare a Ministerial list on the ground that it would infringe on the Khedive's prerogative.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--The 3 per cent. funding bill was passed in the Senate today by a vote of 38 to 18, after one long speech from Mr. Windom and short speeches by other Senators, who seemed reluctant to part with a subject that had been so fertile in suggestions for debate for nearly a month.

The fourth annual exhibition of the NewYork Microscopical Society at Chickering Hall last evening was generally pronounced by experts with the microscope the finest that has yet been given, alike as concerns the beauty and value of the instruments and the variety and rarity of the objects exhibited.

The effect of the long-continued public demand for legislation looking to the regulation and supervision of railroads in this State appears in the fact that, although neither branch of the Legislature is yet fully organized, four different bills have been introduced providing for the establishment of a Railroad Commission.

BUFFALO, Feb. 3.--Sherwood Dunn, on April 15, 1879, entered into the employ of the furniture manufacturing firm of Weller, Brown Mesmer as a salesman and assistant book-keeper. A year ago Charles E. Brown, of the firm named, and his wife parted and the wife went to her parents in Cleveland.

Baker to inform the Governor, that the Assembly had organized and was ready to proceed to business. Gov. Cornell immediately transmitted his Message to the House, and it was ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee of the Whole.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4.--At 3:45 o'clock this morning fire was discovered on the first floor of the large Jefferson public school building on Virginiaavenue, between Four-and-a-half and Sixth streets.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 4.--The murder of Mrs. Caroline Loux at Grafton by her brother-in-law, William Jacobs, and the suicide of the latter equal in horror and tragedy anything of its class which ever occurred in this vicinity. Jacobs' wife died a year ago. Before and since her death Jacobs had been criminally intimate with Mrs. Loux.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4.--The case of the State against the Standard Oil Company, an action to recover $3,000,000 tax on capital stock assessed by accounting officers of the State, comes up for trial Feb. 20. The ground on which the action is taken is that any foreign corporation doing business in Pennsylvania is bound to pay a tax upon all dividends earned in and out of the State.

ATLANTA Feb. 4.--The Rev. F.L. Dupont, hailing from Farmington or Hopkinsville, Ky., was carried to the station-house here last night supposed to be intoxicated. He says the cause of his strange conduct is to let his wife get the insurance on his life.

A strange case of suicide was yesterday brought to the attention of Coroner Keller in Brooklyn. Miss Louisa Cruiksbank, residing with her parents at No. 1,009 Pacific-street, took Paris green with suicidal intent on Sunday, and died from the effects of the poison on Monday evening.

Mrs. W.H. Blackmore, once widely and popularly known to theatre-goers as Eliza Newton, died in Bellevue Hospital at 3 o'clock yesterday morning in great suffering and almost friendless.

The sixteenth annual ball of the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique attracted several thousands of ladies and gentlemen to the Academy of Music and Irving Hall last evening. The exhibition of the French cooks' works of art in the latter place was said to have been the finest ever seen in this City.

The bill introduced by Mr. ROBESON on Monday last to provide Mr. CORBIN'S proposed line of steamers from Montauk to Milford Haven with a subsidy places the scheme in its true light before the public. When the schema was first mentioned, THE TIMES...
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 7.--The Government is about to publish a statement which it hopes will put an end to the foreign agitation regarding the Jews.
Toronto papers say that ice-harvesting is now at its height there, and the crop secured will be larger than ever before.

Gowen as President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad there has been a great deal of talk about a powerful combination between the two. Mr. Gowen has made no secret of the fact that an arrangement existed between Mr. Vanderbilt ...

LONDON, Feb. 7.--Parliament reassembled to-day. The House of Commons was well attended, but there was a sparse attendance in the House of Lords. Mr. Bradlaugh was under the gallery of the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--By direction of the President, the Secretary of War yesterday assigned Col. George L. Febiger, Assistant Paymaster-General, to duty in charge of the Paymaster-General's Department, and ordered him to take charge of the Paymaster-General's office in this city.
Von Suppe's comic opera of "Fatinitza" will be presented in the Thalia Theatre to-night for the first time this season.

The Hon. Elijah Ward died at Roslyn, Long Island, yesterday morning. Mr. Ward was for many years a prominent figure in local and national politics. He was born at Sing Sing Sept. 16, 1816, and was at the time of his death in his sixtysixth year.

VIENNA, Feb.7.--The recent skirmishes appear to indicate the intention on the part of the insurgents to force their way across the Drina, so as to escape being cut off from the Montenegrin frontier by the extensive Austrian reinforcements.
PARIS, Feb. 8.--Mr. B.B. Hotchkiss, formerly of New-York, has been made a Knight of the Legion of Honor.
Tuesday afternoon the pupils who have been attending the Catholic parochial school in Rahway filed out of the school crying.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The Senate promises to be almost unanimous in declaring the Arrears of Pensions act a wise measure, which ought not to be repealed.
Frank R. Sherwin was arrested at the Victoria Hotel, in this City, upon a bench warrant from Albany County, last Saturday.
Mr. Orlando B. Potter, with his son and counsel, were in their places facing the jury when Coroner Herrman, yesterday morning, resumed his investigation into the Potter Building disaster.

Col. Elisha Dyer, Jr., was elected Adjutant-General of Rhode Island on Tuesday by the unanimous vote of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--President Arthur has pardoned James Webb, a sailor, who was tried for murder, convicted, and sentenced to be hanged by the United States Consular Court at Nagasaki, Japan.

Quite a large number of letters have been written to THE TIMES inquiring the meaning of the verb "to galote," and its derivations. Strange as it may seem, the writers are apparently acting in good faith, and are really as deplorably ignorant as they represent themselves to be.
The Board of Health decided yesterday to refuse in future to register births which are reported after the lapse of a year after their occurrence.

TRENTON, Feb. 8.--The time for the holding of the joint meeting will probably be Feb. 28. The House and Senate Joint Conference Committee to select a date, has agreed on that day, but the result of its conference will not be made known until next Monday evening.

ALBANY, Feb. 8.--The Senate did a little routine business and then resolved itself into a debating society to discuss the old question as to who is responsible for the delay in organizing the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The House Committee on the Judiciary this morning adopted the report of the Sub-Committee on the Genava Award, and agreed to report favorably the bill prepared by the sub-committee. Subsequently the bill was reported by Mr. Reed, of Maine.

The sale of boxes and seats for the Patti season of opera at the Germania Theater, was begun at auction in the theatre yesterday afternoon. The season is for seven nights, beginning on Thursday, Feb. 23. The sale began at 4 o'clock.
The first rehearsal for the fourth concert of the twenty-fourth season was given yesterday afternoon, under the direction of Mr. Theodore Thomas, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
It must be admitted that the anti-polygamy bill, passed by the House of Representatives a few days since, is a desperate remedy for the Mormon evil.
A meeting of the passenger and ticket agents of the Eastern and Western lines was held at the office of Commissioner Fink yesterday.
William R. Martin was formerly a Park Commissioner in this City, and has the reputation of being a shrewd lawyer.
The eighteenth annual dinner of the Dartmouth College Association of New-York took place at Pinard's last evening. Covers were laid for 86, and the affair proved highly enjoyable.

The differences between John A. Walsh, one of the star route mail contractors, and ex-Second Assistant Postmaster-General Brady have culminated in several suits, one of which is brought in this City, and an attachment has been issued on certain property which Brady claims to have.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The President has, in a special Message to Congress, transmitted a communication from Secretary Kirkwood, inclosing letters from Acting Governor Gosper, of Arizona, in relation to the lawlessness existing in that Territory.

Edward A. Freeman, D.C.L., the English historian, delivered in Chickering Hall last evening the second of the course of lectures on "The English People and Their Three Homes," which he is giving for the benefit of the New-York Free Circulating Library.

PARIS, Feb. 8.--The Bourse was very bad to-day owing to sales on the part of overladen buyers, who had become completely discouraged. The bears are now directing their operations against the credit establishments whose shares are much offered.
The biennial session of the National Trotting Association began at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon, and at the roll-call 94 associations responded to their names.

Counsel for the Anti Bobtail-Car Association of Brooklyn entered notice of an application yesterday for an injunction to restrain Police Commissioner Jourdan from interfering with passengers on the bobtail cars who are willing to pay their fares, but who are not willing to put their fares in the box provided for that purpose.

The Hon. David A. Wells delivered a lecture on "Free Trade Necessary to Future National Development" in the Art Association Hall in Brooklyn last evening. The lecture was given before the Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club and the Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn.

Soon after the steamer Albemarle, of the Old Dominion Line, reached her wharf at the foot of Beach-street, North River, Capt. A.V. Mallett, her commender, went to the Fifth Precinct Station-house and reported the mysterious disappearance of one of his passengers, a lady known to him as Mrs. Roat, who was lost overboard during the voyage.

The second annual meeting of the Union of the Mutual Benefit Associations was held last evening at No. 409 Broadway, with J. Henry Smith, of the Mercantile Benefit Association of this City in the chair, and James R. Pitcher, of the United States Mutual Accident Association, as Secretary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8, 1882. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amounted to $249,000.

Among the papers laid before Chairman Wales by Secretary Barker at a meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday was a communication from William L. Fischer, Superintending Gardener of the department, in which the latter complained that Superintendent Jones had been making himself too officious.
Gen. James Watson Webb was yesterday 80 years of age. He received at his residence, No. 14 West Thirty-eighth-street, a few of his old friends who called to congratulate him upon the event.
Considering how bravely the high tariff men started out at the opening of the present Congress, it must be confessed that they have not made much progress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8.--The case of Cadet Whittaker is still in the hands of the Secretary of War, where it has been ever since the JudgeAdvocate-General, in making his review of the proceedings of the court-martial, decided that the court was illegally constituted.

LONDON, Feb. 8.--In the House of Commons to-day, in the debate on the address in reply to the Queen's Speech, Sir Stafford Northcote, following the lines of the speech of the Marquis of Salisbury in the House of Lords yesterday, accused the Government of allowing matters to drift in regard to Egypt and Ireland and the commercial treaty negotiations with France.

ALBANY, Feb. 8.--Speaker Patterson did not present to the Assembly his list of committees to-day, though it is generally believed that he has it completed, or so nearly so that a few dashes of the pen only will be required to prepare it for presentation.
On Boston authority it is stated that the latest high school translation of "Arma virumquil cano" is "I sing of arms and the virus."

Any one who will take the trouble to glance over the Congressional Record for the session of two years since, or a file of THE TIMES for a corresponding period, will find in it many things which read like ancient history.

PARIS, Jan. 16.--When the collaboration of MM. Millaud and Hennequin produced "Niniche" and "La Femme a Papa," everybody thought that those clever authors had done their best, and that, no improvement being possible, their next attempt would be a comparative failure.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9.--The commission house of Harlow, Spencer Co. suspended to-day. They were carrying a large amount of wheat for customers and had put up some $50,000 margins for them which had not been reimbursed, and the break of yesterday and to-day compelled them to suspend temporarily.

The masquerade ball of the German Liederkranz Society drew a large crowd of merry-makers to the Academy of Music last night, and they danced in fancy costumes until almost daylight.

LONDON, Feb. 9.--In the House of Commons to-day, Mr. Marriott (Liberal) announced that he would move an amendment to the proposed Parliamentary rules providing that no rules shall be satisfactory which will enable a bare majority to close a debate.

At a meeting of the Butter, Cheese, and Egg Exchange held yesterday morning it was unanimously resolved that the Exchange should be removed from its present location, Greenwich-street near Reade, to the Erie Railroad building at West and Reade streets.

There was considerable excitement occasioned on the Produce and Cotton Exchanges yesterday afternoon by the announcement of the failure of William R. Preston Co., general commission merchants, at No. 66 Pearl-street.

A meeting of bondholders of the Columbus, Chicago and Indiana Central Railway Company was held yesterday in the offices of the Union Trust Company to hear and consider a plan proposed for the settlement of the litigations in which the company has been involved for several years and for its reorganization.

Deputy United States Marshal H.M. Burnett yesterday arrested Joseph P. Hague, a wellknown Newark broker, on a charge of complicity in the Mechanics' Bank defalcations. The United States Grand Jury at Trenton had found two bills against him, one charging him with conspiracy ...

Jewish refugees from persecution in Russia have arrived in the German Empire in a very destitute condition. About 200 recently reached Berlin so entirely without means that they had to be fed and clothed at once.

Miss Fannie Duer Robinson, a daughter of Mrs. Beverley Robinson, of New-Brighton, Staten Island, was married yesterday afternoon to Mr. William H. Davidge. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church, New-Brighton, by the Rev. Mr. Johnson, the Rector of the church.

A bobtail car of the Twenty-third-Street Railroad Company was stopped at the Sixth-avenue crossing to permit a Sixth-avenue horse car to proceed on the morning of Jan. 22, 1881. Before the latter car had passed the horse attached to the "jigger" started forward.

There is no excuse for prolonging the unseemly wrangle over Clerks and Door-keepers at Albany. Both branches of the Legislature have presiding officers, and there is no good reason why they should not get to work, dispatch the necessary business of the session, and disperse.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9.--Within the next fortnight the terms of more than 50 of the most expert, daring, and desperate professional thieves in the Eastern Penitentiary of this State will expire, and the convicts turned loose to augment the horde of other malefactors now operating in this city.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--Now that Grenville Murray is no more, smart and scurrilous articles in the weekly press and occasional Continental sketches in the dailies can no longer be attributed to his once prolific and always lively pen.

The Hon. Sir Henry Parkes, K.C.M.G., Colonial Secretary and Premier of the colony of New South Wales, Australia, arrived here from Albany yesterday morning, and has takes rooms, during his tarry in this City, at the Windsor Hotel.

A well-dressed middle-aged man, evidently a gentleman, approached the hack-stand at the entrance to the Central Park at Fifty-ninth-street and Fifth-avenue a few minutes before 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and engaged Alfred Carlin, a hack driver, of No. 139 West Fiftieth-street, to drive him through the Park.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 9.--A special from Doctortown, Ga., says the boilers in the Kirkam Mill there exploded to-day, killing David Mitchell and scalding six others.

Berthold Auerbach, the German novelist and poet, died at Cannes, France, on Wednesday, after an illness of one week. It is said that his death was hastened by grief at the persecution of the Jews, he being an Israelite by birth.

LONDON, Feb. 8.--Lord Granville, in his dispatch of Jan. 7 to Minister West in reference to the Clayton-Bulwer treaty controversy, denies that any analogy exists between the cases of the Panama and Suez Canals.

WINNEMUCCA, Nev., Feb. 9.--Charlie Hing, a Chinaman, was hanged to-day for the murder of Ah Lick, a fellow-countryman, last May. On the scaffold he said that he committed the act in selfdefense, and claimed that $600 had been used to bribe witnesses to swear falsely.

ATHENS, Jan. 17.--The recent election in Greece has resulted in the defeat of the Government in spite of the pressure which it is able to exert at the polls.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 10.--The city of Adrian is in a state of great excitement over the discovery of the seemingly unauthorized negotiation of $150,000 worth of bonds of the issue of which no one had any knowledge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10, 1882. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amounted to $315,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $405,943 35, and from Customs $1,159,212 96.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--The notorious forgers arrested on Wednesday were held yesterday each in $5,000 bail on the forgery charge and in $3,000 each on the charge of conspiracy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--The light freight business to the East has caused much recrimination as to alleged unfairness among the trunk lines, and the Vanderbilt roads are accused of breaking faith by taking freight at the old rates.

ALBANY, Feb. 10.--The stories which have frequently been heard or late of cruelties alleged to be practiced in the Elmira Reformatory led to the presentation of a resolution to the Assembly to-day calling for as investigation of that State institution.
VIENNA, Feb. 10.--Two Panslavists have been arrested in Panszowa. RAGUSA, Feb. 10.--The armistice is ended, owing to the extreme demands of the insurgents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The bloody struggle in the editorial rooms of the Republican has been the engrossing subject of conversation to-day. A. M. Soteldo, Jr., was told by the surgeons, as he lay in the Providence Hospital this morning, that he must soon die.

Gov. CORNELL is credited with a purpose of appointing an active politician to the office of Superintendent of State Prisons, which is soon to become vacant by the expiration of the term of Mr. PILSBURY, because he is ambitious to be renominated and re-elected to his present position.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--Mr. Fyre yesterday gave notice that he would to-day call up the Morrill Tariff Commission bill and present some remarks upon it, and at the close of the morning hour to-day he made good his promise.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10.--A woman of extraordinary size was carried into the clinic room of the University Hospital this afternoon, where Dr. William Goodell was arranging a case of glittering surgical instruments, subsequently employed in an operation of an unusual character.

John Ritchie, of Boston, who was once part owner of the burned building on Park-row, was the first witness called by Coroner Herrman yesterday. He said the structure was built with care, and he believed there was no better building erected at that time.

In the United States Circuit Court, yesterday, Judge Blatchford rendered his decision in the case of the people of the State of New-York, represented by the Commissioners of Emigration, against the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique.

LONDON, Feb. 10.--Lucifer matches were discovered in the Devonport dock-yard in some baled oakum, which originally came from Dublin. Orders have been issued to examine all the bales on their receipt, as was formerly the custom during the Fenian scare.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Feb. 10.--A special to the Tribune from Helena, Montana, says: "Col. Clendenin was accidentally killed yesterday by the caving in of the Barker Silver Mine."

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 13.--The ice-men of the Hudson are again in suspense and tribulation all along the line. Very little has been done since the heavy rain of last week. The ice became flooded with water, and the great body of snow on the surface was converted into slush that was very difficult to remove. Cold weather alone could remedy the evil, and that did not ensue.

BOSTON, Feb. 14.--The Chinese instructor in Harvard College, Prof. Ko Hun Hua, died somewhat suddenly this afternoon, at his home in Cambridge, of pneumonia. He had been ill with a cold for about a fortnight, but that his trouble was of a serious nature was not generally understood.

No further action will be taken in the case.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 19.--Five masked burglars broke into the farm-house of Michael Ulrich, five miles from here, last night. They overpowered Mr. Ulrich and his wife and, with drawn pistols, compelled the old couple to divulge where their money was concealed. The robbers secured more than $1,000 in cash. Nothing else was taken.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 19.--A Swede named Abraham Neilson, living in a hovel on Websteravenue, beat his wife so badly at 8 o'clock to-night that she died in half an hour. Neilson has been arrested and lodged in jail.

And yet it is only a few years since that instrument received respectful attention in civilized countries.

The condition of affairs in Egypt remains exceedingly dangerous and threatening, and from causes which are not apparent at once either to Europeans or Americans. Advices from various countries of the East show that a very serious revival of Mohammedan fanaticism has already begun.

The man who killed himself in the doorway of No. 250 Mereer-street on Saturday night by shooting himself in the breast was Jules Le Hembre, a glass silverer, who last lived at Mrs. Bertha Weber's, No. 64 West Third-street. He was born at Tournay, in Belgium, in September; 1835, and went to Marseilles in 1865.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 16.--The British bark George H. Kemp, Capt. Katenkemp, 47 days from Huelva, Spain, for Philadelphia, arrived in this port in distress on the 9th inst., leaking badly. She has experienced very heavy weather on the passage. She had twice been within 20 miles of Delaware Breakwater, but had been driven off.

The sexton of the Ross-Street Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, Eastern District, rang the bell yesterday afternoon in honor of an event over which all the congregation rejoiced. The church debt had been wiped out.

A service in behalf of the House of the Good Shepherd, Rockland County, took place at the Church of the Transfiguration, East Twenty-ninthstreet, last evening. Bishop Potter presided and expressed his approval of the work done by the institution. Many persons knew of the work, he said, but there were too few who understood it.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 19.--A special from Salida reports that a passenger train ran into the caboose of a freight train in Marshall Pass yesterday. WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--According to Consul Schoenle, of Barmen, the predictions made in his former report on the discovery of petroleum wells in Hanover, near Peine, that "the supply and quality of oil from these wells would prove of importance," have been partly realized.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--An anti-polygamy meeting of the Protestant churches of Washington, under the auspices of the Pastors' Union, was held in the Memorial Church in this city this afternoon. The Hon. Hiram Price presided, and the Rev. Sheldon Jackson, who was for many years in charge of the Presbyterian missions in Utah, delivered an address. A series of anti-polygamy resolutions were adopted by a rising vote.

It is announced that a herd of 11,000 sheep has just arrived at Lincoln, Neb., from Washington Territory. The journey has occupied two years. The trail from Washington Territory to the Missouri River is said to be the longest and hardest known to stock men. Three years is often consumed in a drive over this distance.
The mysterious person who possesses a key to the fire telegraph boxes, and who has been sending out false alarms of fire recently, renewed his nefarious operations yesterday.

Emigration to Cape Colony from Great Britain is fast increasing, For 1879 the returns show only 1,332 emigrants; for 1880 the number was 2,607; for 1881 it was 4,163. These 4,163 consisted of 324 men for the Government railways, 2,613 artisans and domestic servants, 758 agriculturists, and 468 recruits for the Cape Mounted Riflemen.

CHESTER, Penn., Feb. 20.--Two more of the victims of the explosion at Jackson's pyrotechnic works died last night. One William H. Franklin, was a member of the Franklin Fire Company, and the other, Robert Taylor, was a young colored man. Mr. Franklin leaves a young wife, but Taylor was unmarried. The deaths from this explosion now aggregate 17.

A point that has long given the United States Customs authorities more or less trouble was decided in the United States District Court yesterday. A collection of ancient vases, statuary, weapons, and other antiquities arrived at this port from France in the Spring of l879.

The appropriation given by the State of Maryland for fish-culture being equally divided between two Commissioners, one for the Eastern, the other for the Western, Shore, Major T.B. Ferguson presents in his report an account of the work accomplished by him on the Western Shore.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20.--The leading produce markets were more active to-day and very irregular. Wheat was unexpectedly strong, under a vigorous buying for April, to the comparative neglect of other deliveries.

The papers in connection with the Coroner's investigation into the fire in the Potter Building have been received in the District Attorney's office. The matter will be investigated by the Grand Jury on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has contemplated the construction of a shorter line between Cincinnati and Chicago for several months, but no definite conclusion on the subject has yet been reached. At present the only route controlled by the company between the two points makes it necessary to run to Xenia by the Pan-Handle route, and thence westward.

The seventh annual charity ball for the benefit of the S.R. Smith Infirmary was given last evening in the German Club rooms, at Stapleton, Staten Island. Despite the exceedingly unpleasant weather, over 300 persons were in attendance and the affair worthily terminated a season of more than usual gayety on the island.

Senator CALL, of Florida, represents one extreme of opinion concerning legislation for the suppression of polygamy, and Mr. HASKELL, of Kansas, very fairly represents the other. Mr. CALL does not think that polygamy can be touched as long as it is a part of the religious faith and practice of a certain sect.

ALBANY, Feb. 20.--Speaker Patterson, for some reason, failed to announce the names of any of the clerks of committees, although it was given out authoritatively that he would take this action to-night. The Speaker has seven such clerkships which, by courtesy, are left to him to fill.

The strike among the cartmen employed in the Street-cleaning Department, and by Messrs. Mairs and Walton, the contractors, which was to have begun yesterday, proved a failure. The cartman employed by Commissioner Coleman did not strike. All those who asked Mr.Walton to increase their pay from $3 to $3 50 a day were given the increase and went to work, and the customary force will be at work to-day as usual.

LONDON, Feb. 20.--In the House of Commons this evening, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, President of the Board of Trade, replying to Sir James Hogg, said he hoped to introduce a bill to regulate the power of companies undertaking electric lighting.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20.--A pastoral letter has been prepared by Bishop O'Farrel, of the newly created Roman Catholic diocese of Trenton, and will be promulgated at Easter, which enjoins upon clergy and laity a strict observance of the Church's rules respecting marriage.
The eighth annual Martha Washington Reception of St. John's Guild last evening, in the Academy of Music, was attended by the leading families of the City. The scene was grand and picturesque.

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 20.--The will of the late Joseph F. Sheffield, admitted to probate this morning, contains important bequests of a public character. It is dated April 20, 1875. WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--Mr. Cox's bill to promote the efficiency of the Life-saving Service was passed to-day in the House under a suspension of the rules. This bill provides for the establishment of 30 additional life-saving stations and six houses of refuge.

TRENTON, Feb. 20.--In the Senate, on motion of Mr. Youngblood, a resolution was adopted to recall from the House the bill which increased the Chancellor's salary from $10,000 to $15,000, but the House had adjourned. This kills reconsideration, and the bill awaits the action of the Governor.

Anything more stupid than the act of the man who, the other day, defaced the Field monument at Tappan has seldom been recorded by a wondering and indignant press. So stupid was it that it was an entirely superfluous performance for the defacer to further advertise his own idiocy by celebrating his deed in original verses.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 24.--The trial of Charles W. Stickney for the murder of Montgomery T. Campau in May last was brought to a close to-day by the jury rendering a verdict of "not guilty, on account of insanity."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24.--The Mason courtmartial met at 10 o'clock to-day, the full board being present.

ALBANY, Feb. 24.--There was an uproar among the regular Democrats to-day when Speaker Patterson divided up the spoils which courtesy has given to his office. The appointees comprised a Postmaster and assistant, a Post Office messenger, five assistant doorkeepers, and janitor and an assistant, and three general messengers.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 24.--The nominations made by the Readjuster caucus last night for members of the State Supreme Court of Appeals, to succeed the Democratic incumbents, do not cause any surprise.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., Feb. 22.--In anticipation of the throng of visitors in search of health who will flock to this place during the coming season, Harrison Phoebus, the proprietor, has enlarged and improved the Hygeia Hotel, so that it is now the largest caravansary of its kind south of New-York.
CAIRO, Feb. 24.--A report was circulated here to-day that the levee had broken, but it proved to be false, only a small portion sliding, which was repaired immediately.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24.--The game of railroad chess which is being played between the Pennsylvania and Jersey Central Railroad Directors and the Philadelphia and Reading and Baltimore and Ohio Directors in this State is becoming interesting. BOSTON, Feb, 24.--A location was to-day granted the proposed New-York and Boston Inland Railroad by the town of Sherburne, and now the location has been secured from the limits of the town of Brookline to Douglass, the boundary line between Massachusetts and Connecticut.

Prince Prisdang is the title of a half-brother of the King of Siam. He is about to visit this country as an emissary from his royal relative. Two years ago the King of Siam sent a special embassy to England for the purpose of effecting an alteration in the treaty existing between the two countries.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24.--For the first half hour on the Board of Trade to-day a panic prevailed in the leading grain markets, and the feeling all day was one of uncertainty and distrust. The return of fine weather in the North-west, a downward tendency in the markets of Europe, and the uncertain feeling in stocks in the United States, all helped a depression.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25.--The recent failure of H. O. Kenyon Co., of the Board of Trade, proves to be a much more disastrous affair than was at first anticipated. PHILADELPHIA, March 1.--James B. Mantrop, of Peruvian claims and Denver bond notoriety, was brought before Magistrate Smith to-day to answer the charges against him, but at his request the hearing was postponed until next Monday. There were, however, some now developments of this complicated case.

The meeting of the Medico-Legal Society last evening was one that called out a larger audience and more spirited discussion than usual. The paper of the evening, read by Prof. William A. Hammond, presented a medical exposition of a form of insanity that has become of great interest since the trial of Charles J. Guiteau for the assassination of the President, namely, the form familiar to medical exports as "reasoning mania."

The Titans in Delmonico'a last evening enjoyed what was called a grand classical banquet in honor of Mother Earth, Protectress of the Order. The crest of the order is a Titan supporting the heavens; the motto, "Usque ad Superos," and the flower, the violet. No man is eligible to membership who is under 6 feet 2 inches in height.

Costello, of New-York, and Mr. Sheridan, of Kings, brought in their demands for an investigation of the man agement of the Street-cleaning Department and of the elevated railroads, which were referred to in this morning's TIMES.

A meeting of hay merchants was held yesterday at the Butter, Cheese, and Egg Exchange to devise means to bring the members of the trade into closer communion. The sale of the paintings in the collections of United States Minister Levi Morton and Mr R. Hoe was concluded last evening in the presence of a large assemblage of bidders in Leavitt's salesrooms. Seventy-seven lots were disposed of, at rather better figures than on the preceding evening, the total bids for the evening aggregating about $31,000, as against S19,000 on Tuesday.
