Michael E. McGloin, Robert Morrissey, and Thomas Moran, jointly indicted with two others for murder in the first degree, were called to the bar of the General Sessions yesterday. Counsel for the defense demanded a separate trial for MoGloin, which was granted.

Prof. W.G. Sumner, of Yale College, lectured last evening before the Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club, in the hall of the Art Association, in Montague-street. He was introduced by Thomas G. Shearman as one of the brightest and ablest writers and speakers on the tariff question in the country.

CHICAGO, March 1.--The officers of the different Chicago lines terminating at Council Bluffs held a meeting yesterday to discuss their future relations with the Missouri Pacific Railroad, whose extension to Omaha will, it is expected, be completed by June 1, when it will apply for admission to the Iowa pool.

The benches in the Jefferson Market Police Court room were filled to their utmost capacity yesterday by young women, employes of Macy Co. and John Daniell Son, who had come to testify in behalf of their employers, who were charged with not providing suitable seats for them in their stores. Justice Kilbreth was on the bench, and Emma Gates Conkling, Carrie Williams, and Lillie Devereux Blake appeared on behalf of the prosecution.
Booth's Theatre was crowded last night with one of the best audiences that has attended any performance this season to hear Mme. Gerster in the music of Violetta.

TRENTON, March 1.--When, after it had been smuggled through the two houses in a single day without attracting any one's attention, it became known among the members that Senate Bill No. 111 perpetuated the control of the present managers over the New-Jersey Central Railroad, there were visible signs of disappointment and chagrin on the faces of some of the members.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--There have been referred to committees in the House several propositions for the reclamation of the arid lands of the far West. Mr. Belford's bill, which provides that such lands shall be leased for a term of years, has already been described.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1.--The trial of Thomas A. McDevitt, Benjamin B. Wiley Christian Price, and H. Legrand Ensign, charged with conspiracy to defraud the Government in the star routs mail contracts, was set down for to-morrow in the United States court, but to-day David W. Sellers, counsel for McDevitt, applied for a postponement until the next term of the court.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--While Senator Miller, of California, was speaking yesterday in favor of the passage of his bill to prohibit Chinese immigration into the United States Mr. Hoar was busy writing. Today the Senate listened for two hours to the speech which Mr. Hoar was then finishing.

The Treasury statement for the late of March shows a marked falling off in the rate at which the public debt has of late been reduced. Up to the 1st of February the total reduction was, in round numbers, $88,000,000, or an average per month of $12,587,000.

ALBANY, March 1.--Below are given the detailed official semi-annual reports of the savings banks of Kings County for Jan. 1. There are 14 banks in operation in the county, though two of them have only a nominal existence.

ALBANY, March 1.--The result of the election in the Eighteenth Senatorial District is both a surprise and an enigma to the politicians here. All sorts of explanations are put forth to account for it, and they differ as widely as the partisan, personal, and factional perdilections and prejudices of those who make them.

The late Mr. WAGNER an anti-Conkling Republican and a railroad "monopolist," was elected to the State Senate last Fall by a majority of 6,782 over Mr. ARNOLD, who ran as an independent candidate and is presumed to have received the bulk of the Democratic vote, with possibly some help from the Anti-Monopolists and ultra "Stalwarts."

BOSTON, March 1.--A bill was reported in the Legislature to-day for the sale of the stock held by the State in th New-York and New-England Railroad. It allows the State Treasurer, subject to the approval of the Governor and Council, to sell from time to time the whole or any portion of its stock in the road, or assign and transfer it to the railroad corporation in exchange for second mortgage bonds.

Cocks, President of the association, called the meeting to order at about 2 O'clock.

CAIRO, Ill., March 1.--The situation here has decidedly changed for the better. The Ohio River shows a fall of about three inches, and the Mississippi a fall of about four, but it is thought the rise reported above will check the fall. The levees still hold out firm, and everything looks brighter. Business is picking up, and the general feeling is that Cairo is safe. The weather is clear and pleasant this morning.

The St. David's Benevolent Society, of the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, celebrated St. David's Day by giving a dinner last evening in the Westminster Hotel. Nearly 100 guests sat down in the large dining-room, which was tastefully draped with the Welsh national red dragon flags.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--John M. Carson, clerk of the Committee of Ways and Means, has prepared the following analysis of the financial transactions of the Government for the month of February: The reduction in the public debt for February is $9,783,511, and for the eight months ending yesterday, $97,869,443, which is equal to a monthly reduction during the current fiscal year of nearly $12,250,000.

CHICAGO, March 1.--The latest report of corn shortage appears not to have been overdrawn. In the West the quantity available is growing small by degrees and lamentably less. Parties who had collectively about 10,000,000 bushels cribbed at this time last year now have scarcely one-fortieth part of that quantity, and the farmers have little behind.

PARIS, March 11.--The production of M. Lalo's new ballet, "Namouna," at the Opera has thrown Gen. Skobeleff and Bismarck into the background for the moment, but a vague feeling of uneasiness is still noticeable in the utterances of the French press.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--By direction of the Secretary of War, Sergt. Jesse H. Robinson, Signal Corps. will proceed without delay from this city to Lewes, Del., and, having carried out the special instructions received by him from the Chief Signal Officer, will return to this city and resume his duties at the office of the Chief Signal Officer.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 11.--It is perfectly apparent to every one who is acquainted with the history of the usurpations and corruption which have characterized the 17 years of Bourbon rule in Kentucky that the time has come when all the conditions are favorable to a successful political revolt.
ROME, March 12.--Herr von Schloezer, German representative at the Vatican, had an audience with the Pope to-day. The interview was cordial.
The Steam-ship Oder, of the North German Lloyd, landed 975 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday.

What was called an educational mass-meeting was held last evening in the Church of the Divine Paternity, at Forty-fifth-street and Fifth-avenue. The Pastor, the Rev. Charles H, Eaton, introduced the Rev. Dr. James M. Pullman as Chairman of the meeting. Dr. Puliman said that exactly 19 years ago an educational meeting was held in the same edifice.

PARIS, Feb. 27.--A most respectable, conscientious, painstaking company is the society of actors and actresses by whom the Chateau d'Eau Theatre is leased and managed. In popular drama, and with Marie Laure on Marie Laurent to play their heroines, they and generally successful; why, then, do they yield to the demon of ambition and try hightoned drama?

Three men were discovered in the Louvre galleries, a few weeks ago, damaging pictures by the use of red paint--on what provocation is not stated. Two portraits of Francis I., one by Francis Clouet, the other by Richard Bonington, were seriously injured about the head and face. The rascals were arrested on the spot.

CINCINNATI, March 12.--The address of the Committee of Twelve to the Democratic voters of Cincinnati has been much discussed in political circles to-day. The plans of the committee had been carefully kept from the public, and although it was expected that something radical would be done no one was prepared for the news of the committee's action published this morning.

A fire yesterday afternoon in the upper floors of the factory Nos. 140 and 142 Attorneystreet, though of short duration, resulted in the terrible death of a young man and the injury of two others who were at work in the building. The structure is of brick, five stories high, and is occupied by a number of cabinet-makers and wood-workers.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The Rev. George C. Miln preached his farewell sermon to-day in the pulpit of Unity Church-in fact, as he announced it, the last in any pulpit. He spoke rather bitterly of his treatment by Unity Church, and when he had thus introduced his subject, went into an extended definition of his position his puugent phrases smacking decidedly of Ingersollism, eliciting appleuse and laughter at frequent intervals.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 12.--The wind has blown strongly all day from the north-west, a favorable direction; still, the waters have piled themselves up two inches higher in front of the city than the day before. Six inches more and they will overflow the high-water mark of 1874, the highest on record.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--There are indications of trouble in the Louisiana Lottery ring. For several years the company has had an agent in this city, who seems to have done a good business. Washington is said to be a good market for lottery tickets. Hundreds of them are sold to department clerks, and the trade has been stimulated by several large prizes received here.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 12--Fully 100 whites and negroes engaged in a riot yesterday at Third Creek, this State. A negro attacked a white man, and when the latter defended himself more negroes took part, when the whites came to the aid of the man attacked. Troops went to the scene and arrested many of the rioters and placed them in jail.

The Newburyport Herald says the settlement of the estate of Moses Brown, tied up by his will since Feb. 27, 1827, the date of his death, is substantially completed, and this in the space of two years from the death of Mrs. Hale, the life tenant.
BOSTON, March, 13.--Owing to insufficient notice, the audience at the anti-polygamy meeting this afternoon did not exceed 300.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--The Army Appropriation bill, which was reported to the House today, provides for an aggregate appropriation of $27,481,698, based upon estimates aggregating $29,238,887,67, and is an increase of $743,898 over the appropriation of last year.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 13.--A special to the Times-Democrat from Bayou Sara recounts the results of the levee inspections from Baton Rouge to Bayou Sara. Several weak places are reported, but the work of strengthening them goes on.
Minister LOWELL is going down into the English cotton-spinning country to find out what foundation there is for the unpleasant reports about sand in American cotton.

"Twelve Jolly Bachelors," a comic operetts in two acts by John A. Stevens and E.I. Darling was produced for the first time in this City at the Windsor Theatre last evening. Lively action, bright costumes, and light, catching music of the popular order are its characteristics.
Mr. P.T. Barnum had every reason to be satisfied last night with the greeting extended to his "greatest show on earth."

PANAMA, March 13.--Intelligence has just reached here of an appalling earthquake in Costa Rica. Advices thus far received state that four towns have been destroyed. These are Alajuela, San Ramon, Grecia, and Heredia. In Alajuela alone several thousand lives were lost. Those left alive there are homeless. Alajuela is a city of 8,000 inhabitants, 29 miles by rail south-west of Cartago.

Mr. Max Maretzek returned from Cincinnati on Sunday. The fact of his departure had been duly telegraphed to this City, and a TIMES representative was requested to make search for him. Mr. Maretzek's epicurean tendencies are well known, and the principal Italian restaurants were visited in turn, but without success.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 13.--The most brilliant reception ever held in this city took place at the residence of ex-Gov. English to-night, the occasion being the seventieth anniversary of his birth.

The monthly meeting of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game was held last evening at Pinard's, Alderman Robert B. Roosevelt, President, in the chair.

The special committee of the Assembly appointed to investigate the Receiverships of certain insurance companies resumed their labors yesterday morning in the offices of the Continental Life Insurance Company.

At the meeting of the Baptist Pastors yesterday the Rev. Dr. D. Henry Miller, of Greenpoint, presided. Vernon Seaman, a merchant, exhibited a petition to Congress against the passage of the bill to stop Chinese immigration, and it was signed by many of the ministers.

ALBANY, March 13.--The Assembly considered a number of bills of minor importance to-night, and ordered them to a third reading. Progress was reported on Mr. Brooks's bill to secure to primary elections the pristine purity of the country town meeting.

CHICAGO, March 13.--It is estimated that fully $6,000,000 are up in margins in the different banks in this city. What a mess it would make if some one should appeal to the courts in such a way as to cause the locking up of all that cash until a submitted case had been decided in the courts.

Judge Wallace will open the Spring term of the United States Circuit Court on Tuesday, April 4. At a special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday Capt. Ambrose Snow and Capt. Samuel Harding were re-elected as Commissioners of Pilots.
BALTIMORE, March 13.--The Baltimore Conference of the Methodist Episopal Church reassembled this morning. At the religious services Bishop Bowman, who is very ill at St. Louis, was prayed for.
WASHINGTON, March 13.--The Democrats in the House are fast making a record in relation to polygamy.

JACKSONVILLE, Oregon, March 18.--On Saturday night 10 or 12 masked men rode into Linkville, where H.C. Laws, charged with murder, was in custody of Deputy Sheriff J.F. Lewis and Justice Wright awaiting examination.
The recent stringency in the money market has affected pawnbrokers considerably, as they are generally heavy borrowers for their business, and yesterday two failures were reported.
WASHINGTON, March 13, 1882. The national bank notes received for re demption to-day amounted to $342,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $612, 669 51, and from Customs $749,720 53.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 14.--There has just been concluded in Youngstown a meeting of representattve minors from the different bituminous coal regions of the country, the object being to see if something cannot be done to bring about greater uniformity of prices for mining coal.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--The Post Office Appropriation bill was taken up in the Senate to-day, and at the time of adjournment the Holman amendment relating to sub-contracts was the subject of discussion. The Senate committee has weakened it by enlarging the discretion of the Postmaster-General as to its enforcement, and has amended it so that it shall apply only to contracts hereafter made.

The caucus called by the committee of Republicans in the House of Representatives to consider the future action of the party, particularly with reference to the amended rules introduced by Mr. REED, of Maine, has not been called a moment too soon. The condition of the House in regard both to the business actually accomplished and to the ...

NEW-ORLEANS, March 14.--The Hon. George W. McCranie, of the Ouachita Telegraph, sends the following to the Times-Democrat from Monroe, La.: "The situation here is extremely critical. A visit to the levees above and below the city this afternoon showed that they are in great danger, though a large force of men is at work on them. There is not five inches to spare.

The special committee of the Assembly appointed to investigate the Receivership of 10 insurance companies resumed their labors yesterday morning in the office of the Continental Life Insurance Company. There were present Alfred C. Chapin, Chairman, and Assemblymen Haggerty, Welch, Baker, and Erwin.

Mr. George Cox, the former photographer of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, whose testimony in regard to the restorations made in the Cypriote objects was unheeded by the investigating committee, was visited yesterday by a representative of THE NEW-YORK TIMES in regard to the Savage letters. Mr. COX was found in a most pleasant humor, for he stated that Mr. Savage's communications were his perfect vindication.

M. Victorien Sardou's latest comedy, "Divorcons," was sufficiently described in this journal when it was produced at the Thalia Theatre, and it was then suggested that an English version of this play would be found acceptable and amusing upon our stage. At the Park Theatre last night an English version was finally performed. A large audience watched it with marked interest, and was thoroughly entertained by its comical and novel intrigue.

CINCINNATI, March 14.--There is a call out for a meeting of the extinct Democratic Executive Committee for to-morrow evening to arrange for the holding of a convention to make nominations for the Spring election. It is likely, therefore, that there will be two Democratic conventions, each of which will put a ticket in the field.

LONDON, March 14.--In the trial of Dr. Lamson for the murder of his brother-in-law, Mr. Montagu Williams concluded his argument for the defense to-day. He pointed out that it had been proved that Percy John had suffered from neuralgia and rheumatism, for which aconitine is a remedy. There was a missing link, he said, in the case of the prosecution, namely, that it was not ...
BERLIN, March 14.--The Emperor William spoke a long time with Prince Bismarck on Sunday last respecting the recent utterances of Gen. Skobeleff.

The Rev. Samuel P. Hinman, who sues Bishop Hare for $25,000 damages for libel, yesterday finished his testimony in the trial before Judge Van Vorst in the Supreme Court. Mr. Stephen P. Nash, for the defendant, then began his rebuttal, and read from a deposition of Bishop Clarkson several contradictions of what Mr. Hinman had written.

The bulls and bears fought doggedly yesterday for control of the stock market. The bulls won, though their victory was not one over which they seemed anxious to indulge in any special exultation. They were able to score an average advance of less than a single point on Monday's quotations despite their most persistent and vigorous campaign.

ALBANY, March 14.--The Lieutenant-Governor this morning appointed as the Special Committee on Apportionment to redistrict the State for Representatives in Congress the following Senators: Messrs. Grady, (Chairman,) McCarthy, Ellsworth, Russell, Jacobs, Jones, and Baucus. The second, third, and fourth are Republicans, who, ...

TROY, N.Y. , March 14.--Swan, a freight car thief, in jail at Ballston, attempted yesterday to release himself and fellow-prisoners. He feigned a cold in the head, and begged the jailer to give him some snuff. It was discovered that Swan intended to blind the jailer with the snuff and then make a rush for liberty. Swan was shackled.

The Legislature has not thus far shown much alacrity in resuming the task of revising the tax laws, which was left so far from completion last year. It cannot let the subject alone, but there is great danger that whatever it may do will tend to increase complications rather than promote the evolution of a simple and effective system of assessment and collection.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday appointed April 21 as the day upon which Augustus D. Leighton shall be handed in the Tombs court-yard for the murder of Mary Dean. This is also the day which is fixed upon for the execution of the sentence of death upon the murderer William Sindram. Augustus D. Leighton killed Mary Dean in West Twenty-sixth-street on the night of June 6, 1880.

CHICAGO, March 14.--The question of the hour on the Chicago Board of Trade is, "What are the intentions of the bull clique as regards the longer wheat futures?" That the clique is master of the situation so far as April and May wheat is concerned is an admitted fact, but it is laying low on those futures for the present and disposed to force things.

The House of Representatives, by a vote of 199 to 42, has passed the Edmunds bill as it came from the Senate. This is a triumph for the champions of the more recent attempts to suppress polygamy. It is the knell of the "twin relic of barbarism," as it does not seem possible that the infamous practices of the Mormon bigamists can be continued under the new condition of affirms.

Miss Clara Woodward, youngest daughter of the late Robert T. Woodward, was married yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Messiah, corner of Park-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, to Mr. Charles Morgan, son of Mr. Henry Morgan, the banker. The ceremony began at 3 P.M., and was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Collyer, the Pastor of the church.
WASHINGTON, March 14.--The secretary of the Treasury today issued three calls for bonds-- continued 6s--to the amount of $15,000,000, payable in parcels of $5,000,000 each, on May 3, 10, and 17.

The will of Miss Sarah Burr, who died on the 1st inst. in her residence, No. 25 Universityplace, was offered for probate before Surrogate Rollins yesterday. The original will is dated April 3, 1866. Two codicils attached to the document are dated June 30, 1869, and Sept. 30, 1881. After giving $5,000 to each of the Executors named in her will, she gives $5,000 to Hannah M. Kissam and $15,000 to Eliza Tompkins.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--Seret.-Major Theodoro Ewert, Fifth Infantry, having performed the duties assigned him on March 2, will return to his station with permission to delay 10 days en route. The extension of leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability Granted Capt. Frederick Whyte, Ordnance Storekeeper, March 29, 1881, has been still further extended one year on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

LONDON, March 15.--A dispatch from Vienna says: "It is announced to-night that the Montenegrin Army has been mobilized, and that a special mission from Montenegro is about to leave Cettinje for Vienna."

The Republican General Committee of Kings County met last evening, the President, Mr. Edwin Packard, in the chair. It was rumored that a little fight would take place between the factions for the control of the committee, which, it is said, is involed in the settlement of several ward contests now pending.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--The Trunk Line Advisory Commission held its first session to this city to-day at the Board of Trade rooms, all the Commissioners being present. An argument on behalf of the Philadelphia Board of Trade was presented by Israel W. Morris, Chairman of the Committee on Inland Transportation. He first called attention to the geographical element in the transportation problem.

ALBANY, March 14.--The furniture-dealers of New-York City have bean swarming to the capital within the past 24 hours, and this morning they massed themselves upon the floor of the Assembly Chamber and held whispered conversations with a number of the members. WATERBURY, Vt., March 14.--A horrible double murder that occurred last Sunday night has just come to light here. Michael McCaffrie, 50 years old, killed his wife, of the same age, and his mother, 80 years old, and concealed their bodies in the cellar of his house.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--A special dispatch from Reading, Penn., says: "Telegrams from South Bethlehem this morning state that over 100 cases of virulent smallpox have developed since Sunday, and the excitement aroused yesterday continues unabated. On Saturday only three very light cases were known to the health authorities.

OMAHA, Neb., March 14.--It was evident today that the worst of the recent strike has passed over. No further public meetings of working men wore held. All the men who can work advantageously were employed on the depot grounds. The smelting works were running to-day with about one-third of the regular force; the old hands are coming slowly back.

The special committee of the Bar Association of New-York, composed of Charles Price, Dwight H. Olmstead, Herbert B. Turner, Joseph C. Jackson, and John H. Riker, to whom was referred the question whether changes should be made in the manner of transferring title to land in the City and State of New-York, presented its report at a meeting last evening.

ST. LOUIS, March 14.--At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad this morning, the number of Directors was increased from 6 to 13. WASHINGTON, March 15.--A report was submitted to the Senate this afternoon by Mr. Allison on behalf of the Committee on Appropriations, stating the results of their investigation of the contingent fund expenditures of the executive departments. It is signed by all the members of the committee, although the testimony was taken only by Messrs. Allison, Logan, Hale, Davis of West Virginia, and Cockrell as a sub-committee.
Mayor Grace yesterday appointed Joseph P. Kennedy a City Marshal to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation of James C. Kenney.
VIENNA, March 15.--The Presse reaffirms the statement that nothing whatever is known in Government circles in regard to the intention on the part of Montenegro to mobilize her forces.

CHICAGO, March 15.--The head-quarters of the Iroquois Club presented an animated appearance to-day, the occasion being the reception in this city by the club of a large number of distinguished Democrats from outside the city, and a celebration of the anniversary of Andrew Jackson's birthday by a banquet at the Palmer House in the evening.

The Coroner's jury in the case of Bessie Thayer, whose death was supposed to have resulted from eating molasses candy containing poison, coupled with their verdict a recommendation that the case be turned over to the Police for further investigation.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15.--The opening session of the Philadelphia Methodist Episcopal Conference was begun this morning in Paul-Street Church, Frankford, Bishop E.G. Andrews took the chair. The Rev. J.S.J. McConnell having been nominated for re-election as Secretary, he declined...

In the township elections held in Passaic County on Tuesday the Republicans were generally successful. In Acquackanonk a union ticket was run, according to custom, and was elected, most of the officers being Republicans. George V. De Mott (Democrat) was re-elected Chosen Freeholder...

WASHINGTON, March 15.--Mr. J.G. Bigelow, attorney for Sergt. Mason, has prepared a petition for a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that the court-martial had no jurisdiction in time of peace; that even if the court had jurisdiction it exceeded its powers in imposing the sentence aforesaid, as the sentence is in excess of any punishment authorized by law, and void on that account.

The city of Rahway defaulted in the payment of interest on her bonds a few years ago and became bankrupt with a bonded and floating debt of $2,000,000, and every effort since made to relieve her of her finnancial embarrassment has been futile.

The sixth and last chamber music concert of this season by this excellent club was given yesterday afternoon at Steinway Hall. The audience was the largest that has appeared at any of the series, and was both attentive and appreciative.

A meeting of citizens of Queens County was held yesterday afternoon in the town hall at Jamaica, Long Island, to receive a presentation of the plans and financial scheme for building a bridge across the East River from the foot of Seventy-sixth-street to Ravenswood, on the Long Island shore.

Chickering Hall was crowded yesterday afternoon, on the occasion of the twenty-first annual Commencement of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College. One hundred and sixty-three young gentlemen were presented with the parchments which attest their future right to the title of "Doctor."

SCRANTON, Penn., March 15.--A sensation in a verdict of $4,000 damages against Morris Goldwas caused in court here to-day by the Jury bringing smith, in favor of Jeremiah Hawker, whose libels and litigations have occupied public attention in this county for the past few years.

BALTIMORE, March 15.--A terrible punishment was inflicted on Mary Lee, a little colored girl, 12 years of age, by her father, Spencer Lee, at Elkridge Landing, in Howard County, a few miles from Baltimore, on Sunday evening, for a very trivial offense.

CHICAGO, March 15.--The impression is now very general among grain operators here that wheat futures for May and June are as hopelessly cornered as April is, and that the sooner the shorts cover the lees they will have to pay.

The Park Commissioners at their meeting yesterday granted to the Suburban Rapid Transit Company the right to bridge the Harlem River. The structure is to extend from a point near the present terminus of the Second-avenue elevated railroad track across the river to a convenient point in Westchester County.

The project of establishing a day of general benefit performances in the various theatres for the aid of the suffering and needy of the dramatic profession has been received with great favor in the City, and there are, even at this early date, indications that the movement will meet with success...

ALBANY, March 15.--The sub-committee of the Assembly Committee on State Prisons appointed to investigate the charges of cruel and inhuman treatment of prisoners confined in the Sing Sing Prison held a session of four hours this evening.

WASHINGTON, March 15.--The beginning of the examination of Jacob R. Shipherd by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs cannot be regarded as wholly satisfactory. It was expected that he would appear with his documents several days ago, but he asked for a postponement, which was granted.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15.--The publication this morning of the true inwardness of the connection between the National Underground Electric Company, of Camden, and the National Underground Electric Company, of Philadelphia, caused a sensation.

Gounod's "Faust" was performed last night at the Academy of Music to an audience that filled the house. The opera has been from its first presentation a favorite with the musical public, and the secret of its success is not difficult to discover.

The Board of Trade and Transportation met yesterday, Capt. Ambrose Snow presiding. It was rosolved to memorialize Congress in favor of the recoinage of trade dollars into standard dollars, in favor of an early decision of the pending proposition....

BALTIMORE, March 16.--At the session of the Baltimore Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church to-day, the Rev. Joel Brown, Chairman of the Committee on Losses in Church Membership, reported 25 per cent. among probationers and 30 to 35 per cent among "members in full," the principal cause of which is represented to be the "temptations common to all Christian people." Dr. Lord lectured yesterday in Chickering Hall on Anselm-Archbishop of Canterbury, who was not merely a great prelate, but a great philosopher and theologian-the ablest and most profound of all the early scohoolmen.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--In the February volume of consular reports issued by the State Department, Consul Canisius, of Geestemunde, Bremerhaven, shows that the number of barrels of American petroleum shipped to and lying in storehouse at the principal Continental ports was in December, 1880, 1,216,858,
LONDON, March 16.--Queen Victoria and Princess Beatrice arrived at Mentone this afternoon.

Johann Strauss's operetta, "The Merry War," was given for the second time at the Thalia Theatre last night. The composer is most widely known as the author of waltzes and polkas without number, in the instrumentation of which, however, he has shown a technical knowledge of the value of each part of the orchestra.
DUBLIN, March 16--Mr. J. Bryce Killen has been released from imprisonment.

Erastus Brooks.

Rent reductions continue in Scotland Within the past few months in Midlothian reductions of 20, 30, and 40 per cent, have been commonly made, but even at these terms some of the landlords find difficulty in obtaining tenants. Simliar results have been experienced in other Scotch counties.

ALBANY, March 16.--The third oleomargarine bill which has been introduced into the Assembly this session name up in Committee of the Whole to-day, and, after being debated at some length, was ordered by the House to receive its third reading. Its author is Mr. A.B. Sheldon, of Chautanqua.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--Gen. Rufus Ingalls arrived here this morning and assumed his new duties as Quartermaster-General.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16.--There was a large attendance of merchants and business men to-day at the final session in this city of the Railroad Advisory Commission. The principal business was the presentation of an argument by the Maritime Exchange, which took substantially the ground previously covered by other representative....

PHILADELPHIA, March,16.--Signor Rossi, the Italian tragedian, who has arrived in this city to begin an engagement in the Chestnut-Street Opera-house next Monday, says that three years hence he will be able to play all his parts in English. He loves it, he says, because it is the language of Shakeapeare.

A great number of persons with nothing else to do crowded the court-room of the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday morning, and many more stood in a line for hours waiting for an opportunity to enter the room, to hear the testimony in the suit of Caroline Harbeck for an absolute divorce from John H. Harbeck, on trial before Judge Richard L. Larremore.
PERNAMBUCO, March 15.--The American bark T.J. Southard, Capt. Handy, from New-York Jan. 29, for San Francisco, is ashore in the Rio Grande and is leaking badly.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 16.--Perhaps not one of the many rowing contests between Harvard and Yale that have taken place since 1852, the year when representative orews from the two colleges first met, has been looked forward to with the interest which has and will attend the next one, which will take place at New-London, Conn., on the Thames River, June 29 or 30.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--Three speeches were made in the House to-day on the antiChinese bill. Mr. Willis, of Kentucky, spoke at length in favor of the measure and was followed by Mr. E.B. Taylor, of Ohio, the successor of Gen. Garfield.

Mr. George Magrath is an exceedingly ambitious young pianist who comes from Brooklyn, and has on several occasions proved his right to claim recognition as an artist. By way of further demand on public attention he gave the first of two piano recitals yesterday afternoon at Steinway Hall, to an audience of the best composition.

The House of Representatives, during the past two days, has been entertained by a gentleman from Mississippi, Mr. MONEY, who is most anxious that he should be observed and heard by the voters of his "deestrick."

RALEIGH, N.C., March 16.--An adjourned meeting of the Council of State will be held here to-morrow. Gov. Jarvis and Company have attempted to deceive the people into the belief that an extra session of the Legislature is imperatively necessary and cannot be avoided. The pretext is to redistrict the State.

Park Commissioner Salem H. Wales has addressed a letter to Assemblyman Roosevelt discussing legislation to correct, so far as possible, the evils that now, and for many years past have, attended the administration of the Department of Parks.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--The star route cases came up in the Criminal Court today, before Judge Wylie, when it was expected that the indicted persons would be arraigned, and counsel would then develop the course which they intend to pursue in the trial.

Information from Bangkok has been received in this City stating that the King of Siam has decided to construct several lines of telegraph, connecting Bangkok with the British system on the eastern side of the empire and the French lines now extending from Saigon through the Province of Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--Mr. Bigelow, counsel for Sergt. Mason, says he is determined to investigate the subject of Mason's precipitate transportation to the Albany Penitentiary, with a view to ascertaining by what authority Mason was so hurriedly sent off, while a motion for the issuance of a writ of habeas corpus was pending.

Irving continued, all the same, to cherish a sincere regard for Toole, and Toole for Irving.

The story was current in Wall-street yesterday that Mr. Jay Gould and Mr. Russell Sage had quarreled; that both were mad, and bent on war, It was alleged by the gossips of the Street that the recent bull campaign was much too vigorous to please Mr Sage; that, in fact, the big rise in prices had come sooner than was agreed, and had caught him unprepared and entailed heavy losses.

CHICAGO, March 20.--The trade was scarcely surprised to-day to see about 200,000 bushels of corn in the Danville elevator posted "out of condition," but a good many persons were surprised to see the statement that she corn is in a " heating condition and affected by weevil." They declared it to be simply impossible.

ST. LOUIS, March 20.--The clerk of the steamer City of Providence, just up from Vicksburg, gives some information about the floods in the lower river not before published. He says: 'The Parisot Steam-boat Company, which runs steamers up the Yazoo River and its tributaries, has sent into the submerged region of the Yazoo, Sun Flower, and Tallahatchie Rivers the lightdraught steamers Sun Flower, De Smet, and Headlight, equipped for special work.

The residents of Stapleten and Clifton, Staten Island, are agitated over the story of a mysterious murder on the beach, about three miles from the former place, on Saturday. Tho story is told by two small boys, named Patrick Clark and John Lackey, aged 11 and 12 years, respectively.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20.--At the session of the Philadelphia Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcepal Church to-day the Rev. W.L. Gray, from the committee on the legacy left by the late Dr. Scott Stewart, as a nucleus of a fund which shall be used for the erection and maintenance of a hospital in Philadelphia, presented a report accepting the gift and providing for the appointment of 10 clergymen and 11 laymen as Trustees.

BALTIMORE, March 20.--The Trunk Line Advisory commission met this morning at the Board of Trade rooms. After Judges Thurman and Cooley had taken their seats Judge Thurman stated that, owing to severe indisposition, Mr. Washburne was confined to his room and would not be present.

The seventh subscription performance of the Spring season was given last night at the Academy of Music, with Verdi's "Rigoletto," for the first time since the company returned from its travels in the provinces.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the patent case of Gideon-Bantz vs. David Frantz, brought here by appeal from the Circuit Court of the United states or the District of Kentucky.
TRENTON, March 20.--Gov. Ludlow to-day gave audience to a large number of Jersey City and Hoboken residents on the question of the Jersey City and Hoboken Water-front bill.

LONDON, March 20.--The debate on the proposed rules of Parliamentary procedure was resumed in the House of Commons this evening. Mr. Gladstone stated that he would move that the first seven and the last two rules be standing orders. The Marquis of Hartington, Secretary of State for India, declared that the cloture proposal was nothing more than a modification of existing restrictions on debates.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 20.--The Sultan yesterday and to-day requested the attendance of the dragoman of the American Legation, and asked him for particulars concerning the administration of governmental affairs in the United States.

RICHMOND, Va., March 20.--Jake Wilkerson, a negro convict in the penitentiary, was shot last night by one of the guards while attempting to escape. He and four other convicts confined in the same cell had cut a hole through the wall which overlooks the outer yard, and Wilkerson was getting through the hole when shot.

The third week of the trial of the twentyfive-thousand-dollar libel suit of the Rev. Samuel Hinman against Bishop Hare began yesterday before Judge Van Vorst and a jury in Supreme Court, Circuit. The testimony of the day was confined to depositions respecting the scandals. The first document read was the testimony of Miss Mary Z. Graves, of Santee Agency, who deposed that prior to 1879. Hinman's reputation for chastity was bad.

The arrangements for the benefit performances for "Actor" Fund Day," which occurs on April 3, continue to be pushed forward with commendable spirit and with unusual success. The important work of distributing the tickets of admission was begun yesterday under the supervision of Messrs. Lester Wallack, William Henderson, and A.M. Palmer the Committee of Arrangements.

TROY, N.Y., March 20,--At the meeting of the molders on Saturday a committee was appointed to visit the foundries and confer with the shop committees with a view of making some adjustment between the employers and employes. At some of the works the committee was refused admittance, and the men thereupon quit work.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--First Lieut. Thomas H. Bradley has been relieved from duty at the War Department, in connection with the settlement of State claims against the Government, and ordered to join his regiment, the Twenty-first Infantry, stationed in Oregon; and Major Thomas F. Barr, military secretary to the Secretary of War, has been placed temporarily in charge of the duty heretofore performed by Lient. Bradley.

The Aldermanic Committee on Ferries and Franchises met again yesterday to consider the resolution introduced in the Common Council requesting the Legislature to pass the bill reducing the passenger rates on the Thirty-fourth-street ferry to Long Island City from 4 cents to 2 cents. WASHINGTON, March 20.--The case of A.C. Soteldo, indicted for the murder of his brother, and for assault and battery with intent to kill Clarence M. Barton, came up before Judge Wylie, in the Criminal Court, to-day.
LAWRENCE, Mass., March 20.--The strike in the Pacific Mills became quite general to-day, as was threatened. Over 2,000 of the operatives did not enter the mills at the beginning of work this morning.

Sprague Manufacturing Company, shot himself in the right temple at his residence in this city at 5:30 o'clock this morning, dying soon after. Discouragement at the condition of the Sprague matters is assigned as the cause. He leaves a wife and four children.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 21.--About two months ago an old lady in Cherokee County was murdered. Suspicion pointed to two young men named Moon, nephews of the old lady, and the object was supposed to have been a sum of money which she had to the house.

The three-masted schooner Isle of June, which arrived from Nassan, New-Providence, yesterday, is the first vessel built with mahogany frames which has entered this port. She was recently launched at Nassau, where she was built as an experiment by R.H. Sawyer Co.

DUBLIN, March 21.--A canister of powder was dropped last evening into a house on Nelson-street, where several detectives are living. Much damage was done to property by the explosion which followed, but nobody was injured.

The city debt question of Elizabeth, N.J., has practically and definitely settled at the meeting of the Common Council of last night. Elizabeth defaulted in the payment of her bonds three years ago, and since that time she has been living under a provisional hand to mouth system of government.

Capt. P. Owens, of Fulton Market, said yesterday that the largest whale ever placed on exhibition will probably arrive at this port to-morrow. The whale was captured on the 15th inst. near Sag Harbor by a party of 10 men.

BOSTON, March 21.--The Zuni Indians arrived here at 4 o'clock this afternoon and were driven at once to their quarters at the Quincy House. They will be received by the Mayor at noon to-morrow, and by the Governor at 2 P.M. A reception will be tendered them at the Old South Church at 3:30 P.M.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 28.--A second crevasse has occurred at Live Oak Grove. Lumber has been sent to close it. The river here is eight inches below the high-water mark of 1874. Darten, formerly State Engineer under the Louisiana Levee Company, in an interview today expressed the opinion that up to the present time the damage done in the sugar district is not alarming.

NATCHEZ, Miss., March 28.--About 10 o'clock on Monday morning a tornado passed from the north-west a mile north of the town, tearing off the roof of a building, uprooting trees, and tearing down fences. Not much damage was done, as its path was narrow.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29.--For two or three days there have been intimations here that something startling might be expected in connection with the railroad bill. The air has been rife with stories of bribery to secure the passage of the now famous shore front bill, and the promise of something exciting was naturally associated with these rumors.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., March 29.--Intelligence was received here to-day of the murder last night, near Lamont, in Accomao County, of Gilley Bondick, one of the most notorious desperadoes ever known in this State. A feud had existed for several months between Bondick and Ben Young, growing out of the fact that the latter had won the affections of a woman in the county to whom Bondick had been paying attention for some time.

CHICAGO, March 29.--The twenty-eighth annual report of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad has been prepared, and from advance sheets the following facts are obtained: The gross earnings of the company, including all leased lines during 1881, were $21,824,150, of which $16,598,818 was from freight, and $3,616,096 from passengers. The operating expenses, including taxes, were $11,066,514, leaving the net earnings $10,257,635.

RICHMOND, Va., March 29.--The Post Office box of the National Bank of Virginia was robbed of its contents on Sunday afternoon by some one who opended it with a duplicate or false key. The thief took advantage of the excitement caused by the conflagration prevailing at the time to do his work.

KINGSTON, Jamacia, March 18.--A telegraphic dispatch was published here yesterday announcing that the annexation to Jamacia of the Morant and Pedro Cays had been gazetted in London. WASHINGTON, March 29.--The Treasurer of the United States has recently been criticised for having issued an order stopping gold transfers to Philadelphia for gold deposited by national banks in New-York. In reply to inquiries upon the subject to-day. Treasurer Gilfillan said that he had issued no such order, and that the general impression that he has done so is a mistake.

At the time of the death of Stephen H. Knapp, contractor, in 1874, he had a claim for $13,000 against the City for work done by him on the Twelfth Regiment Armory. LONDON, April 3.--Sir Henry Wrixon Becher, Bart., of Creagh, County Cork, Ireland, and Lady Becher were saved from the steam-ship Douro, sunk in a collision off Cape Finisterre with the steamer Yrurac Bat. The names of the 24 passengers who were saved are published, but include no Americans.

NEW-HAVEN, April 3.--The Jeffersonian Club, an organization composed of many of the leading Democrats in New-Haven and its vicinity, celebrated the birthday of Thomas Jefferson this evening. An oration was delivered by William Parsons, of the Register. Speeches were made by prominent Connecticut Democrats, and a number of written declinations were read.

The large hall of Cooper Union was crowded to the doors last night by an assemblage of people who met to protest against the arbitrary arrest and imprisonment, in British jails of American citizens, against their detention in prison on suspicion merely, and without trial, under the Coercion laws, and to demand that our Government take steps to secure their immediate trial or discharge from custody.
The Butter, Cheese, and Egg Exchange yesterday changed its name to that of the "New-York Mercantile Exchange."

LONDON, April 3.--The race on the Tyne this afternoon between Hanlan and Boyd was fairly close, and was won by Hanlan. The starting boats were moored opposite the Mansion House, about 100 yards above the High Level Bridge, and 30 yards apart.

The benefit performances in behalf of the actors' fund, for which elaborate preparation had been made, were given yesterday afternoon at 16 of the principal City theatres and also at Haverly's Theatre in Brooklyn.

The object of the proceedings begun in South Carolina, under the direction of Attorney-General BREWESTER, is to bring to justice the men who willfully and notoriously defrauded the people of that State of their rights at the polls.
The bill introduced in the Assembly on Friday touching foreign fire insurance companies is provoking a good deal of quiet discussion among underwriters.

BALTIMORE, April 3.--At the last weekly meeting of the Baltimore Medical and Surgical Society the Committee of Honor presented the names of several candidates for membership, with its approval, for action on the part of the society.

ALBANY, April 3.--The two bills, presented by Mr. Brooks, of Richmond, and Mr. Hickman, of Erie, regulating and purifying primary elections were the special order of the House to-night. Mr. Hickman advocated his measure, whose chief point is the right granted to challenge voters at primary elections, to swear in such challenged persons, and to make false swearing a perjury punishable as providod by law in cases of perjury.

The annual meeting of the American FishCultural Association began yesterday morning in the rooms of the Directors of the Fulton Market Fishmongers' Association, and will continue this morning and afternoon.

The monument erected to commemorate the fact that Dean STANLEY once dined with Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD has been again attacked and defaced by presumably wicked fiends, who pretended to think that it was erected in honor of Major ANDRE.

CINCINNATI, April 3.--The Republicans of Cincinnati were beaten one year ago by 2,500 majority, because of the failure of the State Legislature to pass another law restricting the liquor trade. They were beaten again to-day by a majority nearly twice as great because, in the interval, amends had been made and such a law enacted.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--The first Monday in each month is set aside in the House for the passage, under a suspension of the rules, of bills called up by members. Several bills were disposed of in this way this afternoon. The first one was Mr. Belford's, explained in THE TIMES this morning, relating to the settlers and miners on the eastern border of the Ute Reservation in Colorado.

A pretty faced and intelligent looking little monkey called Minnie, belonging to the Barnum show, pressed a diminutive image of herself to her breast yesterday, and cast half-affrighted glances through the bars at the crowds. "Minnie presented Jock, the father, with twins yesterday," explained Keeper Sam Hodges.

The recent introduction into the Assembly of Mr. Roosevelt's resolution asking for an investigation of the conduct of Judge Theodorie R. Westbrook and ex-Attorney-General Hamilton Ward has served to recall public attention to the great stock jobbing scandal of last year, which resulted in firmly fastening the Manhattan swindle on the elevatod roads of this City and in putting the Gould-Field Sage clique in control of the rapid transit system.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--Upon the reassembling of the United States Supreme Court this morning the oath of office was administered to Judge Blatchford, and the latter took his seat. But for the temporary absence of Judge Harlan, the bench would have been full, for the first time since Dec. 24, 1878.
The Brown University Base-ball Club, of Providence, R.I., made their first appearance in the field in this City yesterday afternoon in a game played against the Metropolitan nine on the polo grounds.

It is provided by statute that an action for ejectment may be tried twice before a jury. This provision was taken advantage of by the defendants in the suit of Mary Eliza Hynes against Kate McDermott and others. The action is for the ejectment of the defendants from the premises on the north-east corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty-seventh-street.
A resolute effort was made in the House yesterday to get a day fixed for the consideration of the bill authorizing the national banks, under certain conditions, to renew their charters.

The stock market was marked by many peculiar features yesterday. The Vanderbilt and Gould pegs seemed to have been suddenly removed, and prices went down, to the great delight of the bears, who had organized for systematic attacks. Lake Shore, on which recently the entire list has apparently hung dependent, was the chief point of assault.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 3.--Mr. F.M. Nichols, one of the most active and intelligent members of the Executive Committee of the Wolfe Independent Republican Party of Pennsylvania, has severed his connection with that organization, and gives his reasons for so doing in an open letter to the Secretary, Mr. Frank W. Leach, of Philadelphia, which will be published here to-morrow.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., April 3.--A great sensation was erected in this city this morning by the announcement that Jesse James, the notorious bandit and train-robber, had been shot and killed here. The news spread with great rapidity, but most persons received it with doubts until investigation established the fact beyond question.

ALBANY, April 4.--The Canal Board met this afternoon to receive the opinion of the Attorney-General as to its right to remove Frank Hotchkiss, of Whitehall, from his position as Canal Collector, to which he was appointed by the board a few weeks ago.

ALBANY, April 4.--The attempt to strangle the Baker Railroad Commission bill began to-day in the Assembly. The session, in accordance with the new rule adopted last week, commenced at 10 o'clock, and from that hour until 2 in the afternoon the bill claimed the exclusive attention of the House.

The April meeting of the New-York Horticultural society, held yesterday afternoon in Republican Hall. Thirty-third-street, near Sixth-avenue, was marked by an exceptionally fine exhibition of flowers. Viewed as a whole the display presented a variety of form and wealth of coloring that were pleasing in the highest degree.

CINCINNATI, April 4.--Complete returns on member of the Board of Public Works show the result of yesterday's election to be as follows: Total vote polled 36,000, which was about 14,000 below an ordinary full vote.

The local elections in the Western States on Monday showed a general gain for the Democrats. In Ohio, in the city of Cincinnati, they not only polled a heavier proportionate vote than a year ago, but were given decided majorities for offices which the Republicans were confident of carrying.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 4.--The hazing affair at Trinity College Sunday was more serious than at first reported. The primary cause of the hazing was the publication of the second number of the annual college paper called the Jug, which is published by an anonymous board of editors.

The-fifth annual exhibition of the Society of American Artists will be open to artists generally, whether exhibitors or not, at the American Art Gallery, Madison-square, to-day, after 9 A.M.

ALBANY, April 4.--The free canal amendment to the Constitution was a special order in the Senate again to-day, and occupied the whole session. Among the Senators who joined in the discussion were Messrs. Russell, McCarthy, Boyd, Grady, and Roberts in favor of the amendment, and Mr. MacArthur in opposition to it.

Funeral services over the body of the late Cornelius J. Vanderbilt were held in the Church of the Strangers yesterday morning. The church was nearly filled, but aside from the members of the Vanderbilt family few persons of note were present.

DETROIT, Mich., April 4.--A large number of municipal elections took place in Michigan yesterday. Lansing went Democratic on the temperance issue, Flint Republican, Owasso Democratic, Hillsdale Republican, Marshall Democratic, (on the temperance issue,) the successful candidate being opposed by the saloon men.

NEW-HAVEN, April 4.--The April term of the Superior Court commenced to-day. Jones, of Hartford, whose services have recently been secured by the New-Haven counsel for the defense.

The Church of the Puritans, in One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, near Fifth-avenue, was thronged last evening with persons who mourned the death of Columbus Ryan, and who were there to witness the funeral services over his remains.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4.--It is understood here that F. B. Gowen, before taking his departure for Europe to-day, attended an important meeting in New-York, at which Messrs. Garrett, Depew, Knight, and other holders of Jersey Central stock were present.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 4.--This morning Judge Simonton filed a long opinion in the case of the Commonwealth against the Standard Oil Company for the recovery of back taxes due the State.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 4.--On Saturday night at Kokomo, 60 miles north on the Wabush Road, the house of Ed Pritohard was entered, he and his wife chloroformed, and a little girl, not yet 3 years old, taken to an outbuilding and a fiendish attempt made to outrage her.

The hearing of the Hinman-Hare twentyfive-thousand-dollar libel suit before Judge Van Vorst yesterday was devoted to testimony as to the curious forms of marriage among the Indians, and to the reception of the important evidence of the Rev. COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11.--Every indication points to the fact that the Ohio Legislature will pass no bill to redistrict the State for Congressional purposes. The result will be that the districts will be allowed to remain as they are, and a Congressman at Large will be provided for in order that the State may have its full quota.

LONDON, April 11.--The Daily News says that a rumor finds favor in Dublin that Earl Cowper, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, is about to resign, and says it may be taken as proof that, in the opinion of well-informed persons in Ireland, some further step, if not some change of policy, must be wade if order is to be re-established.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--The hearing of the star route cases was resumed in the Criminal Court this morning, the question under consideration being the special plea in abatement made yesterday by the defense, in which it is claimed that the Grand Jury were unduly influenced by the statements of Post Office Inspectors who were illegally allowed to present evidence and pamphlets to the jury.

LA SALLE, Ill., April 11.--An attack was made yesterday by City Attorney Andy O'Connor and some of his friends upon a man named Keegan, whom they accused of sending objectionable dispatches to Chicago, and a general row ensued, in which chairs, revolvers, fists, and bottles were used indiscriminately. Nobody was dangerously hurt, but much excitement prevails and further trouble is anticipated.

A French mining engineer has discovered an extraordinary hot spring near St. Etienne. He was boring for mining purposes, and when he had reached a depth of 1,500 feet he came upon this spring, from which the water rushed upward in a column nearly 80 feet above the surface of the ground. The water is strongly impregnated with carbonic acid.
