If Col. Mapleson can execute the plans which he has formed for his next season of Italian opera in this City, the Academy of Music will be the scene of the greatest musical triumphs any opera-house in this country has ever known.

ALBANY, April 15.--As bare-faced a fraud as was ever perpetrated upon a community is that whereby, it is claimed, the town of Attica, Wyoming County, became pledged to pay a bonded debt to which it never consented. A brief history of the proceeding is as follows: Certain persons in the town of Attica prepared and signed ...

A great deal of interest was excited yesterday by the magnificent auroral display of the night before. Until the day broke the heavens were ablaze with light. The spectacle between 12 and 1 was particularly beautiful, and many remained up to see it.

READING, Penn., April 17.--Several days ago John Gragg, Superintendent of the Reading Cotton Mill, gave notice to the employes that on and after April 20 a reduction of 10 per cent. would be made in their wages.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--An important municipal bond decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to day in the case of the State of Louisiana ex rel. the Southern Bank, plaintiff in error vs. Edward Pillsbury, Mayor of New-Orleans, et. al.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 17.--The new route of the Pennsylvania Railroad, between Long Branch and Philadelphia, was opened for travel to-day. The trains run over the New-York and Long Branch Railroad to Bay Head Junction, below Point Pleasant, and from there over the Philadelphia and Long Branch Railroad and the Pemberton ...

NEW-HAVEN, April 17.--To-morrow will commence the trial of James E. Malley, Walter Malley, and Blanche Douglass, charged with the murder of Jennie E. Cramer. Sheriff Byxbee has made the best disposition possible of all the space in the court-room, and a large body of Deputy Sheriffs will be in attendance. Judge Granger will be on the bench.

The remains of Langley Bruce, the young man who committed suicide in the Great Western Hotel, in Philadelphia, on Wednesday last, were brought to this City yesterday, and placed in the receiving vault in Green-Wood Cemetery.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 17.--The sanguine Democratic belief that no jury could be drawn in South Carolina under the law of 1879 who would convict Democrats accused of violating the Federal Election law, was rudely dissipated by the verdict, wholly unlooked for, against the managers of the Acton Precinct.

Mrs. Mackay, the wife of the Nevada "silver king," has, it seems, of late been greatly exercised by certain reports, freely circulated in the continental press, to the effect that a "matrimonial alliance had been arranged" between her only daughter and Prince Philip of Bourbon.

A minority, a little more than one-third in number of the members present in the House, yesterday again prevented the appointment of a day for the consideration of the bill to authorize the national banks to renew their charters.

The closing of the great house of A.T. STEWART Co., or, in other words, the withdrawal from business of Judge HILTON, has already produced some speculations in the public mind as to the future of Garden City, for not only Garden Citizens, but all intelligent people, have some concern as to the fate of what has so far been a unique and interesting experiment.

It should not be forgotten by those who have most opposed the reactionary legislation of some of the Southern States against the negroes that some Legislatures have passed wise and liberal laws with reference to the education of this race.

The second week of Mr. Mapleson's season of opera at reduced prices was begun last night with the performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin." It was one of those representations that begin in an infelicitous manner, and for some occult reason do not improve.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Secretary Hunt has received a dispatch from Mr. Hoffman, Charge d'Affaires at St. Petersburg, under date of March 31, inclosing a letter from Chief Engineer Melville, dated Jan. 31, and written at a point on his way to the mouth of the Lena, 500 versts (833 miles) beyond Iakutsk.
The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $744,415 64, and from Customs $622,691 33. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amounted to $208,000.

AUBURN, N.Y., April 17.--At an early hour this morning two convicts made a daring escape through the roof of Auburn Prison. They were William Lahey, of Erie, sentenced for 10 years for attempted murder, and Michael Hurley, of Westchester, sentenced for 20 years for burglary. A reward of $50 each is offered.

CINCINNATI, April 17.--Mayor Means was not in town to-day, but it is expected that by Wednesday at the furthest he will issue a proclamation ordering all drinking saloons to be closed on Sundays hereafter, beginning with next Sunday.
The new Sixth Precinct Police Station was opened yesterday, uuder the command of Capt. Jeremiah Petty.

On the seats immediately in front of the platform, in the Spring-Street Presbyterian Church, last evening, sat some six or seven people with bent figures and swart places, gazing fixedly at instruments of strange pattern, and, as the spectators soon learned, of stranger sound.

The Danish steam-ship Hermod, which arrived from Havre yesterday, narrowly escaped being lost in the ice during her recent trip. Capt. Hein reports that he sailed on March 30, and on April 8, in latitude 46 30' and longitude 46 50', encountered a severe snow-storm.

The sixth annual bench show of dogs, under the management of the Westminster Kennel Club, will be opened to the public at 10 o'clock this morning in the American Institute Building. All arrangements for the reception of the dogs were completed yesterday morning, and at an early hour the animals began to arrive, some having been forwarded in crates from distant points by express, ...

It has been decided that the proposed statue of William Tyndale for the Thames Embankment shall be executed by Mr. Boehm. It will be of bronze, 10 feet in height, and occupy a site already granted by the Board of Works west of Charingcross. The cost will be 2,400, of which sum 1,200 has already been guaranteed by subscribers, while several English counties have promised each to supply 100.

GLEN COVE, Long Island, April 17.--The little village of Sea Cliff, which rests upon Long Island Sound, about a mile and a half from Glen Cove, is very much excited over the alleged fall from grace of the Rev. Thomas S. Bradner, a clergyman who has been identified with religious work in this neighborhood for nearly 10 years, ...

At 3 A.M. yesterday the observer of the Government Signal Service office at Sandy Hook was surprised by loud shouts proceeding from off the water not far from the point of the Hook. He immediately ran down to the shore, and guided by the shouts he was soon able to see something floating on the water. By this time he was joined by the night operator of the Western Union Telegraph office.

LONDON, April 17.--It is reported that the American "suspects" now in prison have again been offered liberty on the condition of leaving the country, but that they have refused the offer. Mr. Lowell, under instructions from Washington, has demanded their trial or release.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Mr. Teller retired from the Senate this morning, but not until he had seen his successor properly introduced to that body and sworn in. There was the usual thin attendance when the opening prayer was said by the Chaplain, the Senators straggling in, as they do every day, during the reading of the Journal.

Nearly every class of workmen employed directly or indirectly in the building trade has been engaged of late in striking for higher wages. In most cases, through the thoroughness of their combinations, they have succeeded in attaining their object.
The annual election of officers of the Tammany Society was held in the big wigwam last evening and resulted, as was expected, in the complete success of the regular John Kelly ticket.

An auctioneer stood under the shadows of a very ancient and very rickety step-ladder on the platform of Chickering Hall last night, and looked wistfully out upon the audience of 97 persons seattered in little groups through the house.

ALBANY, April 17.--Attention was called, in a forcible resolution offered by J.J. Costello in the Assembly to-night, to the imperfectly ventilated and overheated chamber. Many complaints have been made by members of late of draughts of air which creep in from somewhere--nobody seems able to determine from what quarter--and inflict numberless evils upon persons of even the strongest constitutions.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--In the present condition of the calendars, members of the House who desire prompt action upon important bills naturally turn to those Mondays upon which action can be taken by a twothirds vote under a suspension of the rules.

Mehemed Ruschdi Pasha, the ex-Grand Vizier, who died the other day in poverty and banishment, was of humble parentage, like so many eminent Turkish dignitaries, and owed his original start in life to the following curious incident. When he was a young infantry Corporal, in the days of Sultan Mahmoud, some ladies of the imperial harem, while shopping in Pera one morning, ...
LONDON, April 17.--Sir William Harcourt, Home Secretary, has written to the High Sheriff of Surrey informing him that a further respite has been granted to Dr. Lamson until April 28.

PARIS, April 17.--An extensive robbery of registered letters from the Central Post Office here has occurred. One hundred and eighty letters were stolen. Some of them were from abroad. The value of the contents of the letters is estimated at 1,000,000f.

The annual fair given by the ladies of St. Ann's Church was opened in Ferrero's Assembly Rooms, in East Fourteenth-street, yesterday afternoon. It will continue daily from 2 until 10 o'clock P.M. until Friday, May 5.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18.--John Schriver went to No. 2,446 Turner-street about 1 o'clock this afternoon, and inquired for Little Webster Cross. She was absent at the time on an errand, and Schriver took a seat in the parlor, saying that he would await her return.
DUBLIN, April 18.--There is much doubt as to the whereabouts of Mr. Parnell. He, it is supposed, intends to surrender in a manner to avoid a demonstration by his friends.

It was stated in Wall-street yesterday, and seemingly on good authority, that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company had just issued orders for the immediate construction of telegraph lines directly into this City.
The long series of years during which there was always a deficit in the Italian budget and the Government was forced, not only to borrow money at 10 per cent., but...

Mrs. Mary Lennon, an Irishwoman, 35 years of age, died at Bellevue Hospital, yesterday morning, the victim of terrible violence at the hands of her husband, John Lennon, a tailor, who, during a fit of drunken rage, stabbed her 19 times with a carving-knife.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18.--E.C. Knight has addressed a letter to the Directors of the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey, in behalf of himself and other stockholders, asking them to designate a place for holding an election for Directors.
The prospects are remarkably good for the consummation of Col. Mapleson's plans for the next season of Italian opera in this City.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 18.--True bills of indictment were returned in the United States Cirbuit Court this morning by the Grand Jury against Henry Dickerson and others of Barnwell County, charged with intimidating witnesses in the cases against the State Election officers arrested for violation of the Federal Election law during the election of 1880.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--Ex-Senator Stephen W. Dorsey appeared in court to-day and pleaded not guilty to the indictment which the Grand Jury found against him in the star route cases, and which his counsel have tried in vain to overthrow.
WASHINGTON, April 18.--The following Message was sent to Congress to-day:
A reception will be given on board the Inman steam-ship City of Rome, lying at Pier No. 36 North River, between 1 and 6 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.
ALBANY, April 18.--The Assembly devoted its attention almost exclusively to-day to the third reading and passage of bills.

Judge Brady, in the Special Term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday denied the application for a new trial fcr William Sindram, who is sentenced to be hanged on Friday for the murder of Mrs. Catharine Crave.

Th Worcester League Base-ball Club met defeat, for the first time this season, on the Polo Grounds, yesterday afternoon, at the hands of the Metropolitan nine, in the presence of about 2,500 spectators.

Several members of the Maritime Exchange have come to the conclusion that their credulity as well as their generosity has been imposed upon by a man having the appearance of an honest sea Captain. Last Saturday such a man appeared at the Maritime Exchange.

Messrs. Everett P. Wheeler and Frederick W. Whitridge, the counsel for the New-York Civil Service Reform Association, recently wrote to District Attorney Woodford urging him to renew criminal proceedings against Gen. N.M. Curtis for the alleged illegal assessing of Federal officeholders for political purposes.
There is an evident disposition in both houses of Congress to make liberal provision for the improvement of the Mississippi River.
All was bustle and activity yesterday morning in the American Institute Building, in final preparation for the opening of the bench show of dogs at 10 o'clock.

CINCINNATI, April 18.--The weight of opinion in this part of the State is that the Republican Legislature which adjourned yesterday, with pressing business undone, has turned Ohio over to the Democrats by a majority that will range from 30,000 to 50,000.
ALBANY, April 18.--The Assembly Judiciary Committee has moved in the Westbrook-Ward matter, which was referred to it for investigation.
WASHINGTON, April 18.--Col. Milton Cogswell (retired) has been appointed Deputy Governor of the Soldiers' Home, District of Columbia, vice Col. Mason, detailed to duty at Columbus, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--In the House today Mr. Calkins, Chairman of the Committee on Elections, called up the Utah contested election case of Campbell against Cannon. Mr. Hazelton, of Wisconsin, was the first speaker.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., April 18.--The following are the particulars of the proceedings in court on the trial of the Ford brothers yesterday: Charles and Robert Ford were arraigned yesterday in the Circuit Court upon an indictment charging them with the willful and premeditated murder of Jesse James. The court-room was thronged to suffocation.
" L'Africaine" was repeated at the Academy of Music last evening, with the substitution of Mlle. Rossini as Selika and Signor Ravelli as Vasco di Gama.

RICHMOND, Va., April 18.--Mr. Mahone seems to have despaired of being able to put through his scheme for gerrymandering the State so as to elect eight Congressmen from Virginia who are to run as Administration candidates.

On Monday night Detective Max Schmittberger, of the Twenty-ninth Police Precinct, arrested Jennie O'Brien, of Tenth-avenue and Thirtyfirst-street, for alleged complicity in the robbery of $3,000 from the room of Willie Edouin, the actor, in the Sturtevant House, on Jan. 16.

BOSTON, April 18.--A census of the churches was taken Sunday by representatives of the Advertiser. It shows a total attendance at the several services at all the churches and religious societies-- about 250 in number--of 124,909.

NEW-HAVEN, April 18.--The trial of Walter E. Malley, James Malley, and Blanche Douglass, charged with the murder of Jennie E. Cramer last August by the administration of arsenic, was begun in the Superior Court, before Judge Granger, to-day.
Three persons have been convicted in the United States Circuit Court for South Carolina of obstructing a Federal Supervisor in the performance of his duty.

The suspension of the Providence Tool Company was the subject of much comment in the hardware trade yesterday, and although it has been known for a long time past that it had a hard struggle it was thought that the concern would be able to pull through, as the business was generally supposed to be increasing.
"When a man says a sensible thing he deserves to be credited with it," said President A.S. Heath, of the American Institue Farmers' Club, at the meeting yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--A sub-committee of the Committee on Ways and Means reported to the full committee to-day a bill providing for the imposition of a tax upon oleomargarine, and requiring that packages of...
Miss Fannie Faulkner, the only daughter of Col. H. D. Faulkner, was married yesterday afternoon, in the Church of the Messiah, at Thirtyfourth-street and Park-avenue, to Mr. John Bishop...

WASHINGTON, April 18.--Discussion was continued in the Senate today upon the Mississippi River Improvement bill, and Mr. Harrison, who had the floor, made a speech favoring an improvement according to the recommendations of the Mississippi River Commission, but opposing any proposition to commit the Government to the task of reclaiming the low lands.
District Attorney McKeon has declared war against the gamblers and yesterday had the satisfaction of seeing four prominent members of the fraternity committed to the Tombs.
It has been rumored among club men for some weeks past that a movement is on foot to wind up the affairs of the New-York Club and merge it into the Turf Club.
BALTIMORE, April 18.--There was a very large attendance at the Concordia Opera-house tonight to hear a speech from Judge Jere S. Black, of Pennsylvania, on the Irish question.

Judge WESTBROOK has written a letter to the Judiciary Committee of the Senate to explain to them "precisely the action taken by him in the proceedings" as to the Manhattan Elevated Railroad, "and on what it was taken." (The italics are the Judge's.)

NEW-HAVEN, April 18.--Fire broke out at 3 o'clock this morning in the furniture warehouse of E.F. Bassett, in Seymour. Two young women and a young man were passing the building at that time and report that they heard the noise of an explosion.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., April 18.--A terrific cyclone swept over the town of Brownsville, Saline County, Mo., at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon.
CONSTANTINOPLE, April 18.--It is said that France has recently made overture with a view to the appointment of Halim Pasha as Khedive of Egypt.
WASHINGTON, April 18.--The examination of Jacob R. Shipherd was resumed this morning before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Mme. Geistinger, who returned from San Francisco yesterday, will appear at the Thalia Theatre on Thursday night in "The Royal Middy."

WASHINGTON, April 18.--The following is the President's Message to Congress recommending an appropriation of $2,020,000 for restoring the Mississippi levees instead of $1,010,000 heretofore recommended for that purpose by the Mississippi Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--President Arthur received this evening, between the hours of 8 and 10 o'clock, the members of the diplomatic corps, the Senators, and the Representatives, with the ladies of their families.

Late in February last Mayor Grace, Controller Campbell, and Corporation Counsel Whitney sent to the State Legislature a bill designed to settle the many questions concerning the taxation of corporations in this City which have arisen under the tax laws of 1880 and 1881, by providing for...
WASHINGTON, April 19.--The National Academy of Sciences resumed its session to-day. At the business meeting voluminous reports on the sorghum sugar industry was presented and read.
LONDON, April 19.--At Reading to-day Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge charged the Grand Jury in the case of Roderick Maclean, who attempted to shoot Queen Victoria, at Windsor, on March 2.
The Commissioners of Docks held an interesting session yesterday in their parlors in Duanestreet, President John R. Voorhis and Commissioners Laimbeer and Vanderpoel being in attendance.

ALBANY, April 19.--At the opening of the Senate this morning, Mr. Grady availed himself of a "question of privilege" to call the attention of the Senate to an editorial paragraph in to-day's TIMES relative to Senate bill No. 164.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 19.--After the roll-call of jurors in the United States Circuit Court this morning, Foreman Shaffer, of the Grand Jury, presented true bills of indictment against J.Y. Hogg and 38 other defendants, of Barnwell County, for conspiracy to obstruct qualified voters in the exercise of the rights of suffrage during the last general election.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19.--The twenty-first anniversary of the organization of the First Regiment of Infantry of Pennsylvania was observed by the laying of the corner-stone of its new armory, at Broad and Callowhill streets.

The subject of the care of destitute Roman Catholic children, for whose maintenance the poor authorities of Westchester County are responsible, again occupied the attention of the Board of Superintendents of the Westchester County Almshouse yesterday.

A respite of 30 days was granted yesterday by Gov. Cornell to Leighton, whose execution was set for to-morrow. The respite was given at the solicitation of the Rev. Dr. Morgan, of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, to give the condemned man more time to prepare himself spiritually for death.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--The seat in the House which has been filled by the Mormons of Utah for 32 years was declared to be vacant this afternoon by a vote of 123 to 79. This vote was taken upon a resolution declaring that Delegate Cannon was duly elected and entitled to his seat, and the 79 votes were cast in the affirmative.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 19.--In 1875 the Legislature passed an act requiring the New-Haven and Northampton Road to stop all regular trains at Plantsville, which had bean a regular station, but had been abandoned by the railroad for a new depot in the town of Southington, about a mile distant from Plantsville Village, in the same town.
Bidding was active yesterday at the public sale of securities in the Exchange Sales-room by Adrian H. Muller . Son. Thie sales made and prices obtained were as follows:
The following open letter, addressed to Mayor Grace, has been sent from Albany by Senator Thomas F. Grady:

With mournful air 89 solemn-visaged citizens, including May Music Festival managers to the number, of a dozen or so, gathered around Ticket Speculators Rullman and Tyson in Chickerins Hall last night to listen once again to the dulcet tones of Auctioneer Draper.
WASHINGTON, April 19.--The speech made by Congressman White, of Kentucky, upon the Tariff Commission bill a few days ago appeared in the Record to-day.

We have not lately seen a more discouraging evidence of the permanence of the Bourbon spirit in the South than the attempt of the Georgia Democratic press to lay upon the independent movement the blame of the killing of young ROUNDTREE, the Athens student, by a negro.

A larger number of visitors were present at the bench show in the morning hours, yesterday than in the forenoon of the first day. In the evening the attendance was very large and fashionable. The judging began with the examination in the small ring of the black and tan setter puppies by Major J.M. Taylor, of Lexington, Ky., and the English setter puppies in the large ring by Mr. J. Otto Donner, of this City.

Under the guise of pleasure, the Twentysecond Regiment performed a hard day's labor yesterday. It paraded down Broadway, took a trip to Philadelphia, paraded in a rain-storm with the troops of tho Quaker City, danced all night, and returned to the City in time for business this morning.

The British steam-ship Mary Louisa, Capt. Gibb, whioh arrived from Newcastle yesterday, brought the entire crew of the steam-ship Renpor, which sailed from West Hartlepool for Boston on March 31, but was caught in the ice and her bows so badly crushed that she finally went to the bottom.

LONDON, April 19.--The race for the City and Suburban Handicap at the Epsom Spring meeting to-day was won by Lord Rossmore's Passaic, formerly owned by Mr. P. Lorillard, Weston rode Passaic, who won by two lengths. Fourteen horses ran, including Lord Ellesmere's ch. h. Wailenstein, formerly owned by Mr. P. Lorillard.
The crisis through which Spain is passing promises to reach its culmination this week in the debate in the Cortes and the vote on the reforms proposed by the Sagasta Ministry.

Mr. Mapleson gave his first representation of Meyerbeer's "Roberto il Diavoio" last night at the Academy of Music. The opera is one of the few that are entitled to be called "grand operas," and demands vocal and dramatic abilities from the principals, full choral and orchestral work, an efficient ballet, and rich costumes and scenery.

The election for officers of the New-York Club was held last evening. There were three tickets in the field--one headed "Regular Nominations," a second headed "Independent Ticket," and a third headed "Reform Ticket."

ST. LOUIS, April 19.--The track of the cyclone which did so much damage in Brownsville, Mo., yesterday, was about 150 yards wide, and extended from the south-western to the north-eastern limits of the town, destroying over 20 of the principal business houses and dwellings.

TROY, N.Y., April 19.--A.A. Prince's carpet store was entered by burglars on Saturday night by means of false keys. The gas was boldly lighted, and carpets and oil-cloths were stolen. Some of the property was discovered yesterday in a second-hand store, where it is said Robert Kine, an ex-Alderman, left it.

Chairman Grady, of the Senate Committee on Cities, rose to a question of privilege in the Senate yesterday, and talked about the proposed legislation affecting taxes on the elevated railroad companies.

The Railroad Commission bill passed the Assembly yesterday by a vote of 106 to 15, so amended as to provide for an election of the Commissioners by the people for a term of three years and to reduce their salaries from $8,000 to $6,000 a year.

A telegram was received this morning by Gen. Cameron, Post Office Inspector for this district, from F.W. Schaurte, Post Office Inspector for the Missouri District, notifying him of the capture of a mail agent on the Missouri Pacific Railroad last night named Parke, who was caught in the act of robbing the mail under his charge while in transit.

CINCINNATI, April 19.--The number of cases of small-pox in this city, which were developed at the rate of from five to ten daily during the cold Winter months, when the disease was supposed to be at the worst, are now being reported at the rate of from 30 to 40 a day.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--The Navy Department has been informed of the loss of the Rodgers by Mr. James G. Bennett, who furnishes a copy of the cable message received from Mr. Jackson, the Herald correspondent.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--The majority report on the bill reported by Mr. Taylor from the select committee to audit the expenses of the late President sets forth: "That after giving such attention to the subject as its importance demands, ...
In the vestibule of St. Thomas's Church, at 8 o'clock last evening, was assembled one of the largest and most brilliant bridal parties witnessed this season.

ALBANY, April 19.--Notwithstanding the protests of Mr. C.S. Baker and his friends, that gentleman's Railroad Commission bill was amended to-day so as to take from the Governor the appointment of the Commissionors, and in this condition was passed through the Assembly.

The series of lectures on the tariff called by courtesy a debate would probably go on for another month if the Committee on Ways and Means should not call a halt and ask for the previous question--a step which we presume will be taken as soon as the committee see any reason to suppose that it would be successful.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--President Arthur's Message in relation to the Mississippi River has plainly given additional courage to the Senators who are most interested in the success of a liberal appropriation and a comprehensive scheme of improvement of the great Father of Waters.

One of the most audacious burglaries ever committed in Westchester County was that which took place in the village of Somers at an early hour yesterday morning. On a square on the line of the principal road leading across the country to Sing Sing stands the old brick building known as the Elephant Hotel.
DARLINGTON, April 19.--Fifteen persons have bean killed by a colliery explosion at West Stanley.

ALBANY, April 19.--The double pay drawn by Clerk Johnson and Journal Clerk Barber was again brought up in the Assembly to-day by the report of Mr. Dimon, Chairman of the Committee on Expenditures of the House.

Annie Walters, the daughter of William H. Vanderbilt's coachman, who was stricken with small-pox, died on Tuesday evening in the apartments of her father over the stables, No. 43 East Fifty-second-street.

Final action was taken yesterday by the Fire Underwriters upon the question of forming a tariff association. Various meetings with this object in view were held, and on March 3 a code of rules, regulations, and rates which seemed to meet general approval was adopted.
LONDON, April 20.--Mr. Forster, Chief Secretary for Ireland, arrived in London and attended a Cabinet meeting to-day.
ALBANY, April 20.--The contract labor system in the State prisons was discussed at great length in the Senate to-day in connection with a ...

WASHINGTON, April 20.--Several important nominations were sent to the Senate today, but most of them had been so positively predicted for some time that they caused no surprise. The list was as follows:

Manager Neuendorff, of the Germanic Theater, is to visit Europe next month for a short time. The Union Universelle de l'Art Culinaire announces an annual exhibition of alimentary products, the first of which will be given at the Lexington-Avenue Opera-house, commencing May 15 and continuing for 15 days.

The severe thunder-storm of Wednesday night did considerable damage in different parts of Westchester County. The thunder and lightning were terrific, following each other rapidly, and the flashes of lightning were unusually sharp and vivid.

A bold and ingenious robbery was committed on Tuesday afternoon at the residence of Mr. Samuel C. Holmes, of No. 134 West Thirty-secondstreet, bonds amounting to over $5,000 having been carried off by the thief.

L.J.N. Stark, A.B. Miller, Ambrose Snow, Henry Clausen, Jr., and Havilah M. Smith, a committee representing the Board of Trade and Transportation, have forwarded to the Legislature a vigorous protest against the passage of Assembly bill No. 455, entitled "An act to incorporate the Terminal Warehouse, Elevating, and Dock Company."

WASHINGTON, April 20.--Not often does it happen that a Senator has so good an opportunity to prove his words by his works as fell to Mr. Frye to-day. In the debate on the Mississippi River Improvement bill yesterday he defended the Senators from the North and East against any charge of illiberality to the South, and declared that he had ...
CALCUTTA, April 20.--Political massacres have been resumed in Mandalay. Kind Theebaw has put to death an inferior wife, two halfsisters, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and 50 of their relatives.

Mr. Seba M. Bogert, who was recently expelled from the Stock Exchange for violation of the Exchange commission laws, has been readmitted to membership. Mr. Bogert's case was a peculiar one, and among the members of the Exchange there was a decided sentiment that his punishment was unduly severe.
The official canvass of the votes cast at the late darter elections throughout Hudson County, N. J., was necessary before it could be determined who were elected to the County Board of Freeholders.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 20.--The Railroad Committee made a unanimous report to-day on its investigation relating to the alleged inaccurate and untruthful report, of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford to the Railroad Commissioners, which investigation was pressed by Mr. H.L. Goodwin, of East Hartford, who for several years has been a thorn in the side of that road.

WASHINGTON, April 20.--Judge Wylie overruled the motion of the star route defendants for a bill of particulars this morning, having decided that he would not wait until Saturday, because counsel for the Government wished that there should be us little delay as possible in the preliminary proceedings.

The long talked of scheme for converting the Desert of Sahara, or at least a part of it, into a lake is about to be carried out. The French Cabinet has approved the plan drawn up by M. DE LESSEPS, in accordance with which a canal is to be dug from the Mediterranean near the Gulf of Gabes to the desert;

PHILADELPHIA, April 20.--The Evening Bulletin has a special from Reading, Penn., which says: "A number or secret emissaries from the Pittsburg iron district ago quitely operating in the Lehigh and Schuylkill Valleys with a view of inducing the men in furnaces and rolling mills to go on strikes.
The Hon. A.A. Sargent, Minister to Berlin, has received his instructions from the State Department, and left here to-day en route for his new post.

The trial in the quo warranto proceedings instituted by Attorney-General Russell on relation of Richard 0'Gorman against Judge William H. Arnoux, of the Superior Court, with a view to oust the latter from the bench to which Mr. O'Gorman claims to have been elected last November.

The code of signals and rules recommended for adoption was completed at the opening of the session of the Association of American Railway Superintendents yesterday, after which the system of car exchange was taken up, and the remainder of the day devoted to that subject.

ALBANY, April 20.--The Governor has signed the following acts: Authorizing the Supervisors of Greene County to borrow money to build a poorhouse; conferring additional powers on the Trustees of School District No. 1 in Lansingburg;
Congress has enacted a law that no bigamous person shell be entitled to a seat in the House of Representatives as Delegate from any Territory.

A large number of prominent citizens assembled yesterday afternoon in the chamber of the Brooklyn Common Councl to protest against the appointment of a commission by the Legislature to deal with the arrearages question and to advocate the appointment of such commission by the Mayor.

NEW-HAVEN, May 2.--This is the ninth day of work done in the Malley trial, and, considering the amount of evidence laid before the jury, fair progress has been made.

The journeymen stone-cutters of Newark have struck for an increase from $3.50 to $4 per day.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 2.--Pleasant weather, a large attendance, three spirited contests, and a fast track were the features of the opening day of the Spring meeting of the Kentucky Association.

The vote by which the House on Monday set apart a day for the consideration of the bill to renew the national bank charters was 150 to 65. The yeas included the votes of 38 Democrats and 1 Greenbacker--Mr. SMITH, of Brooklyn. The nays were all cast by Democrats, with the exception of a half-dozen cast by Greenbackers of one stripe or another.

ALBANY, May 2.--The Senate had up the Railroad Commission bill as a special order again to-day, and spent three hours and a half on it without coming to a vote. ALBANY, May 2.--The report of the special Senate committee on the feasibility of placing telegraph wires underground has been prepared, The committee states that at the threshold of its inquiry it was confronted with the fact that the obstruction of public avenues and thoroughfares in large cities by telegraph poles and structures was permitted in no country but the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--Some time ago Judge Wylie, in the Criminal Court, fixed upon Thursday next as the day for the beginning of the trial of Brady, the Dorseys, and the other persons who were indicted with them. Since that time the indictments against Rerdell and Miss Armstrong have been quashed and Rerdell had been rearrested.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 2.--A special dispatch from Greensburg, Penn., to the Chronicle says: "Last night about 11 o'clock the house of Mrs. Jonathan Stump, three miles in the country, was broken into by three masked men. The women were bound and gagged, and one of them was strung up to the rafters in order to extort information in regard to the place where their money was secreted.

WASHINGTON, May 2, 1882. The President to-day nominated David A. Stewart to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Fourth District of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--The House Committee on Commerce has favorably reported a bill making an appropriation for the establishment of electric lights at Hell Gate. It is proposed to erect two skeleton iron towers from 150 to 200 feet high, one at Hallett's Point and one at Negro Head, on Ward's Island, or at such place as may be chosen by the Lighthouse Board.

The Marine Hospital boat started from the Battery at 10 o'clock yesterday morning upon her regular trip to Bedloe's Island. When near the island, Capt. Joseph Laughlin and Officer Henry C. Henshaw, of the United States Revenue Marine Service, observed that the union jack was reversed on the British ship Orealla, lying just below the island. LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 2.--This city has been in a ferment for the last two days over the saloon question, and the excitement is now at fever heat. ATLANTA, Ga., May 3.--A romantic attempt at suicide occurred here last night. The Particular Synod of New-York of the Reformed Church held their second and final meetings in the church of that denomination in Jamaica, Long Island, yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 3.--The Kentucky Association continued is meeting to-day with a large attendance. The weather was warm and cloudy, and the track was in good condition, but dusty.

The Park Commissioners held a meeting yesterday morning. A petition from the New-York Archery Club to use the lower base-ball ground was granted, and other archery clubs were given permission to practice at Mount Morris Park.
On and after Sunday next the library and free reading-room of the Cooper Union will be closed until Oct. 1 on Sundays.

In Mr. FORSTER'S resignation of the Chief Secretaryship for Ireland we have the first definite and positive assurance that the English Ministry have determined upon a radical change of policy in the treatment of Irish questions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3.--Argument was heard this morning before the Supreme Court in the Cameron will case. This arose upon an appeal from the Register of Wills of Union County admitting the will of William Cameron to probate.

WASHINGTON, May 3.--Mr. Henderson, from the House Committee on Military Affairs, made a favorable report to-day upon a bill adopted as a substitute for several bills relating to retirements in the Army.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 3.--The Hon. Horace Maynard, ex-Postmaster-General, died suddenly at his residence in this city at 1 o'clock this morning. He attended the Republican State Convention at Nashville last week and returned Friday night.
The town of Harrison, or East Newark, a suburb of Newark, on the opposite side of the Passaic River, was visited by a disastrous fire between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning.

The remains of Col. The two concerts of the second day of the May Music Festival were largely attended, the larger audience being present at the afternoon concert. In the evening about 6,000 persons were present. Fully one-third of these were people from out of town.

One of the great needs of the present day is a uniform standard of height among clergymen. At present the clerical army admits recruits wholly regardless of height. It is true that among certain sects the average height of ministers is greater than it is among other sects.

PAUL, Minn., May 5.--A great deal of excitement and uneasiness has been caused at Grand Forks and other district land offices in Dakota by the issue of the order from the General Land Office at Washington forbidding the acceptance of Surveyors' certificates purporting to be issued from Santa Fe, New-Mexico.

CINCINNATI, May 5.--There were 200 new eases of small-pox reported at the Cincinnati Health Office during the week ending last night. During the same period there were 526 cases treated within the city limits, of which 32 died and 136 were discharged as well.

Mr. KASSON, in the House yesterday, presented a resolution that the Ways and Means Committee have leave to sit during recess, and that it be directed to meet for the preparation of revenue bills on the second Tuesday of November.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--Senator Blair was again before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs this morning, and his cross-examination was resumed by Mr. Blount. The witness volunteered to state the amount of the certificate of stock received by him from Shipherd as his retainer. He did so because he noticed (in looking over the report of the testimony) that Mr. Blount had stated that he regarded the question as important.

The statistics of the fisheries of Maine for 1880 having been just published by Prof. G. Brown Goode, Special Agent in charge of fishery investigation, the following facts are presented: The investigation having been carried on by Mr. R.E. Earll and by Capt. C.G. Atkins, they state that the total number of persons engaged in sea fisheries, oysters excepted, are 11,071, with 606 vessels presenting a total tonnage of 17,632.65 tons, with 5,920 boats.
The body of a man, apparently a sailor and about 50 years old, was found floating off Corlearsstreet yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--The Government has not found John W. Dorsey, but warrants have been issued for him and placed in the hands of Government officers in Texas, Vermont, New-York, and the District of Columbia. Detectives and other officers have been instructed to spare no effort which may lead to his arrest.
At the Windsor Theatre last night Miss Lotta made her reappearance. "The Professor" was revived here last night at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 8, 1882. The Chinese bill is now a law, having been signed by the President to-day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 8.--To-day's races were of an excellent character and were well attended. The weather and track were all that could be desired. The betting was very fair, considering the fact that there were two very heavy favorites.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., May 8.--The Michael Davitt Land League, of this place, has passed resolutions expressing abhorrence at the assassination of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Mr. Burke, and calling upon all true leaguers to aid in bringing the murderers to justice.

The C.D. Hess Acme Opera Company gave at the Standard Theatre last evening the first production in this City of an alleged comic opera in three acts entitled "The Widow." DUBLIN, May 8.--A man named Charles Moore was arrested on suspicion at Maynooth last evening. He had traveled by the 4 o'clock train from Dublin. He stated that he had intended to go to Longford, but, feeling ill, had taken a ticket for Maynooth. He almost fainted when he was arrested.

James Seman, an athlete, who advertised himself as "Professor S.J. Dare, the Man Fly," was fatally injured yesterday afternoon by a shocking accident during a tight-rope performance in Flushing, Long Island. Seman was a well-built man, of pleasing address, and has been known for many years as a daring and graceful performer on the tight-rope.

Ex-Secretary Kirkwood is mentioned as a candidate for a position on the Tariff Commission.

Last Tuesday the President of the Mercantile Library made his annual report, and next Tuesday occurs the annual election. It may be recalled that when the past year began it was expected to be a critical one.

CHICAGO, May 13.--A special dispatch from Fort Garland, Colorado, says that Dick Rogers, a cowboy, was shot dead by the soldiers, and that Jim Cation, the Paghas Springs stage robber, was fatally wounded last evening.

The "Independents" of Pennsylvania are not independents in the ordinary political sense of the word. They are Republicans contending against a certain method of party management.

In December last Julia Armstrong sued the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New-York to recover the value of a policy of insurance taken out on the life of her late husband, John M. Armstrong, of Philadelphia, Penn., and assigned during Armstrong's life to Benjamin Hunter.

Mr. F.D. Eagan last night, in the basement of St. Vincent Ferrer's Church, Lexington-avenue and Sixty-sixth-street, spoke of the grievances of the impoverished and oppressed people of Ireland. Mr. Eagan's audience numbered about 400, all or nearly all of whom were members of the Land League. Mr. Eagan is about to return to Ireland, whence he came some months ago to further agitation of Mr. Parnell's cause in this country.

The Woman's Christian Temperance Union celebrated its eighth anniversary last evening at the First Free Baptist Church, in Twenty-fifthstreet, near Eighth-avenue. There were present on the platform Mrs. Rebecca Collins, Mrs. S.B. Smith, Mr. E.J. Hanks, Miss Julia Coleman, and Mrs. J.P. Latimer. The Rev. Dr. Peck presided.

An anniversary sermon in behalf of the American Tract Society was delivered by the Rev. Dr. William M. Taylor, in the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church, yesterday afternoon. In spite of the rain there was a large assemblage, many of those present being ladies. Besides the Rev. Dr. Taylor, the Rev. Dr. John Hall, and the Rev. M.M. Cutter occupied seats in the pulpit, and the last named clergyman participated in the services.
CINCINNATI, May 14.--The Smith Sunday law, which requires that all saloons and places where liquor is sold be closed on Sunday, has now been in force for four weeks.
The "Mascot" will be repeated every night at the Germania Theater by Miss Dora Wiley, Mr. Carleton, Mlle, Cornalba, and the corps de ballet. The performance is admirable.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--With efficient leadership the Independent Republicans of Pennsylvania can this year give Cameronism a blow from which it will never recover.
BERNE, May 14.--Col. Emil Frei has been appointed Minister of Switzerland at Washington. He formerly served in the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--In the House tomorrow committees will be called for motions to pass bills by a two-thirds vote, under a suspension of the rules. It is understood that Mr. Harris, Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, will make another attempt to induce the House to fix a day for taking up the bill appropriating $10,000,000 for six new war vessels.

PANAMA, May 6.--During the last few days there have been fears of a revolution here, in the absence of President Cervera, but the President returned this morning, and was received with a salute of 21 guns. The popular fears have been dissipated, as no violence has been offered him, and an allocution issued by him declares that peace is assured and public order unaltered and unalterable.
The rooms of the Iron and Metal Exchange Company, (limited,) at No. 69 Wall-street, will be formally opened to-morrow at noon.
C.W. Elwell was found dead in his bed yesterday morning at No. 199 Washington-street Brooklyn. Death is believed to have been caused by heart disease.

Immigrants are landing at this port at the rate of more than 17,000 a week, or over 2,000 per day. In April 67,901 were landed, an increase of 8,153 over the arrivals in the corresponding month of 1881, and this proportion of increase is being kept up. It is plain that the unprecedented total of last year is to be far surpassed in 1882.

WASHINGTON, May 14,--The April volume of consular reports, advance copies of which have been issued, contains contributions from more than 50 Consuls and commercial agents. Our Consul at Prescott, Sanford S. Blodgett, recommends that our tariff on several articles now imported from Canada shall be raised.

The Rev. Dr. John P. Newman delivered a sermon yesterday morning in his church at Fortyfifth-street and Madison-avenue on "The Failure of Assassinations." He said that recently all Christendom had been appalled by man's inhumanity to man. Within two years three of the greatest nations on earth have been disturbed ...

The so-called "General" Horse Railroad bill has been passed by the Assembly, with three amendments, no one of which has the least effect in robbing the measure of its objectionable features, and now goes to the Senate, where its authors and promoters will use all their efforts to secure its passage.

ALBANY, May 14.--Mr. Brodsky has a bill well on its way through the Assembly which is likely to be the subject of come debate. It is entitled "An act in relation to advances of money upon warehouse receipts, bills of lading, certificates of stock, certificates of deposit, and other negotiable instruments," a title which gives no clue whatever to its real nature.

The damage caused by the drought last Summer and the recent severe frosts to the strawberry beds in Suffolk County was more serious than at first supposed. It is now estimated that the berry crop this year will not exceed three-fourths of an average yield, if it reaches that figure.

CHICAGO, May 14.--The breaking up of the continuous rain-storm of four days, during which time the temperature has ranged between 40 and 50 , has been followed by clear skies over a wide extent of country, but not with the rise in temperature that was hoped for. Under the brisk wind which prevails the badly soaked ground will dry ...

Better things had been hoped for yesterday, as it had been set down by the steam-boat companies and the managers of pleasure resorts for the opening of the warm season.

LONDON, May 1.--In spite of the reticence of Mr. Gladstone, the forecast of a change in his Irish policy turns out to be correct. Last week and the week before we were led to believe that the Premier would make a frank and exhaustive statement as to the condition of Ireland, with suggestions for its improvement.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--The report of Senator Frye in behalf of the Senate Committee on Claims, on the French spoliation claims, has been printed, and makes a strong argument in favor of the recently reported bill "to provide for the ascertainment" of these claims.

LONG BRANCH, May 14.--There was every indication last night that the wind would change during the night and the storm cease, but this morning, with the exception that the wind was lighter, the weather was the same as it has been during the past four days, the wind being from the north-east. It was raining hard.

CLEVELAND, May 14.--Penwell Rudolph, of Russell, a small town near Akron, was arrested on Saturday on the charge of obtaining money on false pretenses. Some time ago David Tinsler's parents died in Medina County, leaving him a farm worth several thousand dollars, and he began squandering his fortune as rapidly as possible.

PARIS, May 1.--As numbers of my lovely and talented fellow-countrywomen seem to be suffering from a desire to go upon the stage, I propose to tell them how a young native aspirant to dramatic fame managed to get herself a hearing and an engagement.

CUMBERLAND, Md. May 14.--As John I. Davenport, of New-York, has visited Cumberland twice in the past four weeks, much interest has been manifested by the public concerning the object of his visits. The first visit was made on Thursday, April 20, when Mr. Davenport registered at the Queen City Hotel under the name ...

An attempt will be made before the adjournment of the New-York Legislature to supplement the new Excise bill with an act providing for the suppression of adulteration of liquors. The proposed bill is nearly completed and, it is understood, will be forwarded to Assemblyman Alvord for introduction.

After seven years of unrestricted competition the fire underwriters of this City have thought it advisable to arrange a common basis for action and agree upon a tariff of rates. The contention which has been going on during the period named has been a severe one.

The total of exhibits in the French Salon this year is very large, as the following figures show: Pictures, 2,722; drawings, water-colors, and porcelains, 1,328; sculptures, 886; engravings and designs in architecture, 1,730. Besides the Salon exhibition, Paris now has an independent gallery devoted to decorative art, a Salon International, and an exhibition of 150 choice works by Courbet at the Ecole Des Beaux-Arts.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--The famous Cochet claim, which has brought into prominence James D. Mantrop, was up again this morning before Judge Thayer. Mantrop is charged with embezzling 3,000 shares of the stock of the Denver City Consolidated Mining Company, and of disposing of the stock and holding on to $4,500 belonging to Peter Hevener.

The large hall of Cooper Union was about two-thirds filled last evening with compositors and members of sympathizing trades-unions of other branches of labor. The meeting was held under the auspices of Typographical Union No. 6, to protest against "the system of low wages slavery" in the City printing.
The new Iron and Metal Exchange formally opened to-day for the transaction of business at No. 69 Wall-street.

Judge McCarter has decided the suit brought by Mary Luppi to recover the guardianship of her daughter from David R. Winans, of East Orange. Mr. Winans is a man of wealth, living on a beautiful estate. Mrs. Luppi was in the service of his family as a maid of all work 11 or 12 years ago. She had with her at that time the daughter whose custody was the question in this suit.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 15.--Over a week ago William Richards, an Englishman, was arrested in Waterbury, in this State, charged with the murder, near Abercorn, Canada, of Joseph Jackson, whom he met in the vessel which brought him to this country.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--The nomination of Roland Worthington to be Collector of the Port of Boston was confirmed this afternoon by a vote of 38 to 14. There was a much larger attendance of Senators than usual when, at 4:35 P.M., the galleries were cleared of spectators and the big doors were locked to prevent even a whisper of what occurred within from reaching the ears of those without.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--Only one bill of importance was passed to-day under a suspension of the rules and several which deserve more careful consideration than can be given in a 30 minutes' debate were rejected by decisive votes.

The Westbrook-Ward investigation, which was continued before the Assembly Judiciary Committee, at the St. James Hotel, yesterday, was re markable chiefly for the somewhat confusing variety of testimony elicited. Quite a large number of witnesses were questioned, and the various specific matters under investigation were sandwiched together indiscriminately.

CAIRO, May 15.--Since the refusal by Mustapha Fehmy of the Presidency of the Council the Kh dive has resumed his original attitude. Arabi Bey, the Minister of War, desires the maintenance of the Ministry, but his colleagues wish to yield. The commandant of the citadel and several officers have declared for the Kh dive.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., May 15.--At Williamstown last evening the wife of Dr. Belden was so badly beaten over the head with a club by her brother, James Noble, that the injuries will probably prove fatal. Noble had been violently insane for the past two days, and had escaped from his keeper.

WASHINGTON, May, 15.--The Senators from all the States except New-York were not a little astonished and amused this morning by a short brush between Mr. Miller and Mr. Lapham. One of the first bills to come up under the Anthorny rule was that introduced by Mr. Miller, providing for the erection of a public building at Rochester.
Mr. A.Z. Chipman established a just claim to being considered a brave man by appearing at Haverly's Fifth-Avenue Theatre last evening in his "original domestic drama" entitled "A Checkered Life."

DUBLIN May 15.--The Police have made no further progress toward the discovery of the assassins. The report of the arrest of three men at a hotel at Cork was untrue. The man Rush, who, it was stated, drove the car containing the murderers, is a car-owner.

The Atlantic and metropolitan nines played a game of base-ball on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of about 1,000 spectators. The game proved to be a very interesting one, for the Atlantics, instead of being badly defeated, as the majority of those present expected they would be, defeated their adversaries by a score of 5 to 1.

The long-pending pooling agreement between the cable companies was finally ratified yesterday, and coincident with that arrangement was made public the statement that Gould's new cables had formally passed to the control of the Western Union Telegraph Company. The basis of the cable pool was fixed two months ago, the main features of which have been explained in THE TIMES.

A report gained currency yesterday that William McBride, Water Commissioner of Long Island City, had absconded, and interested parties were not long in finding that in was true. At first it was thought that he might have appropriated some of the city's money, but inquiry revealed that he had no handin the receipt or disbursement of the corporation's funds.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--The Senate listened for two hours to-day to speeches on the Bonded Spirits bill, which has been the theme of so much talk in some of the newspapers and the text for a long letter by Secretary Folger.

ALBANY, May 15.--Five vetoes by the Governor were read to the Assembly to-night. Two of them related to the closing of certain public offices on certain days and hours in the Counties of Albany, New-York, and Kings.

The announcement that Mr. Darwin is to be buried in Westminster Abbey will be received with universal approval No other place could so fittingly receive the mortal remains of the greatest scientific discoverer of his age and country. But though public honor will thus go done to his memory, the private dwelling-place of so eminent a man will always remain an object of interest to the educated world.

A sale of rare books, book-cases, engravings, etchings, and original sketches from the collection of the late John A. Riston, of this City, was begun yesterday afternoon at Clinton Hall, and will continue for three days. The effort to induce the Board of Health to treat the bell of the Church of St. John the Baptist as a nuisance has not yet been successful. It is, however, only one of a series of attempts of the same nature which have been made here and elsewhere during the last two or three years, and is an indication of a strong and growing hostility to church bells.

Bliss, Fabyan Co., dry goods commission merchants at No. 117 Duane-street, have been victimized to the extent of $30,337 by the alleged cotton frauds of Green Co., of Columbus, Miss. Mr. Shipherd has been summoned to appear before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Wednesday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 15.--In some quarters in the East the impression prevails that the late storms in the North-west have damaged the growing wheat. Several letters of inquiry have been received requesting information as to the extent of the injury.

The concurrent resolution proposing an amendment of the State Constitution "guaranteeing to cities the right of municipal self-government" was ordered to a third reading in the Assembly yesterday.
It has been difficult lately to obtain seamen for outgoing vessels, and in one instance at least a shipmaster has resorted to the old illegal method of "shanghaing" a green hand.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 16.--The Pioneer Press's semi-weekly crop reports contain a large number from Northern Dakota, which fully confirms the previous estimates of the large increase of wheat acreage in that region.

LONDON, May 16.--Six thousand Swedish and Norwegian emigrants passed through Hull on Sunday and Monday on their way to America.
Justice Pratt, sitting in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday granted a decree of absolute divorce to the plaintiff in the suit of Adelaide Hasbrouck against George W. Hasbrouck.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16.--The Louisville Jockey Club began its Spring meeting to-day under auspicious circumstances. The weather was all that could be desired, sky clear and air deliciously warm.

Particularly is that part of the street between Broadway and Sixth-avenue crowded. and the majority of the people on the street will always be found to be ladies.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 16.--To-day, in the Court of Common Pleas, began the trial of Moses Grinnell of Tiverton, a county town of this county, for the murder of Charles H. Thomas, at Tiverton Four Corners, on Nov. 9, 1880.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The Senate to-day took up the Five Per Cent. Land bill and heard the speech of Mr. Plumb for it and that of Mr. Blair against it. Mr. Plumb, in his remarks, followed closely the argument made by him in his report on the bill, which was introduced...

ALBANY, May 16.--The bill conferring suffrage upon women came up in the Assembly to-day on its final passage. Its consideration afforded entertainment for an hour and a half, in which some funny and some very absurd things were said.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 16.--To-day's proceedings of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South were the most important of the session so far.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The star route trials did not begin to-day, although Mr. John W. Dorsey was unexpectedly produced in court by his counsel, where he pleaded not guilty and gave bail in $10,000 for his appearance hereafter.

RICHMOND, May 16.--The appearance here yesterday and last night of Mr. J.T. Loubat, of New-York, and Mr. E.A. Brougiere, for the purpose, it was supposed, of fighting a duel with Mr. Turnbull, of the came City, caused considerable excitement.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., May 16.--The 300 workmen who were on a strike at Delaware Rolling Mill gave notice to the Superintendent this afternoon that they would return to work to-morrow morning, accepting the company's terms.
WASHINGTON, May 16.--It is understood in Army circles that no more retirements will be ordered until Congress has taken action upon the pending compulsory retirement bill.

Alderman Hawes presented at yesterday's meeting of the Common Council a petition from business men on Fourteenth-street, between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, protesting against the repeal of the ordinance recently passed prohibiting the placing of show-cases on the sidewalks on that portion of the street.

A new operetta, "Captain Kydd," by Mr. Rudolph Aronson--the libretto by Mr. Wallace Peck--is announced for the opening of the new Casino next Fall. It is promised that the work will be produced in the best style.

CHICAGO, May 16.--On Sunday morning John Cretzelo, George Orswald, George C. Knoll, and Otto Gibson, who belonged to the Wolf Lake Pleasure Club, left the City for the lake near Sheffield, Ind., to spend the day fishing.
A cable dispatch announces the death of Gen. Constantine von Kaufmann, Governor of Turkestan. Gen. Kaufmann was born at Maidani, in 1818, his family being of German origin.

The Republican General Committee of Kings County met last evening in the Music Hall, Flatbush-avenue and Fulton-street, Brooklyn, Mr. Edwin Packard in the chair. An exciting contest was expected, and both factions used their utmost endeavors to secure the attendance of all the members.
The Mining Exchanges seem to be awaking to the fact that at least a suspicion of value must attach to the securities in which they deal before the public will consent to place any confidence in them.

Less than a month ago it was announced that one-sixth of the work on the Hudson River Tunnel was completed. Since that time, so rapidly has the work progressed, that one-fifth of the distance between the shores of New-Jersey and this City are now traversed by the completed tunnel.

The sporting gentlemen of this City and Brooklyn were ecstatio yesterday morning over the prospect of a hard-glove contest between Mr. James Frawley, of Long Island City, and Mr. Charles Norton, of England.

NEW-HAVEN, May 16.--To-day the fifth week of the trial of the Malleys and Blanche Douglass for the murder of Jennie Cramer was entered upon with the case tried only so far as to permit of a reasonable foreboding that the side of the State could not be finished for two or three weeks to come.

The exercises of the seventy-fifth annual Commencement of the College of Physicians and Surgeons in Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon were opened with prayer by the Rev. Sullivan H. Weston, D.D. Dr. Alonzo Clark, President of the college, occupied a central position on the platform, which was crowded with representatives of the medical profession.

The arrival in this country of a number of M. Camille Alphonse Faure's secondary or storage electric batteries, by the steamer Labrador, from Havre, last week, was noticed at some length in the columns of THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The House Commerce Committee, in its report accompanying the River and Harbor bill, says that at no time in its history has the United States Treasury been in so good a condition as now to warrant large expenditures in this direction.

ALBANY, May 16.--The Senate had the Supbly bill under consideration this morning, and, after disposing of about two-thirds of the items, made the remainder a special order for to-morrow.

The steam-ship Salier, from Bremen, landed 1,340 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Maynard will deliver his illustrated lecture on "Switzerland" is Chickering Hall to-morrow evening.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The propriety of withdrawing the nominations of Jackson and Kauffman, to be Collectors of Internal Revenue in the Twenty-third and Ninth Districts of Pennsylvania, respectively, was suggested to the President to-day by Senator Mitchell.

LONDON, May 16.--All applications under the Arrears bill, which was introduced in the House of Commons last night, must be lodged by July, 1883. An evicted tenant will be able to apple for relief under the act within six months after eviction. Messrs, Shaw, Parnell, and John O'Connor Power approved the bill.

There does not seem to be any such thing as peace in this world. No sooner did the excitement about SKOBELEFF'S speeches subside than the Dublin murders occurred, and now, while the world is still horrorstricken at the slaughter of CAVENDISH and BURKE, the Turnbull-Loubat quarrel threatens to set all mankind by the ears.
The managers of the Baptist Sunday-schools were fortunate in selecting a pleasant day for their annual parade yesterday, and about 7,000 children turned out in their best clothes for the occasion.

The secrets of the miserly life of the spinster Sarah Burr, who lived and died in squalor and loneliness at No. 25 University-place, leaving $3,400,000 by her will to various societies, were further disclosed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court on the hearing of the contest of her will made by some distant relatives.

RICHMOND, Quebec, May 16.--The fire at Danville burned 40 or 50 houses and rendered 200 people homeless. The fire broke out in Goodbue's tannery about 4 o'clock on Sunday afternoon, and during the two hours between 4 and 6 o'clock the struggle on the part of the residents to save their goods was a hard one.
An election was held yesterday afternoon of officers and a Board of Directors for the New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb at Washington Heights.
CAIRO, May 16.--The Cabinet last evening completely submitted to the Khedive. They kissed his hands and garments, implored his pardon, and expressed loyalty. The Khedive received them coldly.

The twenty-third annual Commencement exercises of the Columbia College Law School took place last evening in the Academy of Music. All the boxes wnd seats were occupied by ladies and gentlemen, and many persons stood in the aisles and corridors.
PROVIDENCE, May 13.--The general condition of trades and manufactures is not very flattering; nearly everybody is complaining of the state of the Spring business.
ALBANY, May 17.--The Senate resumed the consideration of the Supply bill this morning and completed the reading without making any changes of importance.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 13.--The last two years have witnessed many important changes and improvements in the appearance as well as the affairs of this city. At the close of the last municipal administration the prospects were exceedingly gloomy.

ALBANY, May 17.--The Railroad Commission bill was called up again in the Senate to-day, and Mr. Jacobs made his usual motion to recommit, with instructions to amend so as to make the bill take effect next year.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 13.--The trade of Indianapolis was the largest and best ever known in the history of the city during the Spring and entire year of 1881. The returns were larger, the profits were satisfactory, and the collections prompter and surer.

ST. PAUL, May 13.--St. Paul and the tributary country in the North-west shares in a generous degree in the general business prosperity of the country. There are peculiar local circumstances contributing to the growth of business here.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--After visiting the Washington Monument today, under the guidance of Col. Casey, the American Society of Civil Engineers met for discussion at 2 P.M. The Committee on the Preservation of Timber made a verbal report, which was followed by a brief discussion.

"The tyranny of trades-unions," said a wellknown and extensive builder to a TIMES reporter last evening, "was never more manifest than in a recent case which occurred to me. I am having a large amount of building done at the present time, and until very lately have had union men in my employ.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art is a public institution whose revenues are derived partly from private contributions and partly from drafts made upon the tapes paid by the people of New-York.

A dispatch from Albany announces that a man named Joseph Davis, claiming to be a policyholder of the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company, of New-York, has petitioned the Senate to investigate certain charges against that company.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The House Committee on Foreign Affairs met in secret session at 10 o'clock this morning and resumed the discussion which, up to the hour of their adjournment yesterday afternoon, had failed to bring about any agreement relative to the method and scope of the inVestigation.
OMAHA, Neb., May 12.--A careful examination of the wholesale business has revealed a most healthy condition of the same, and a steady increase as compared with one and two years ago.

BOSTON, May 16.--The backward Spring to some extent checks the progress of trade in the city as well as vegetation in the country, but in most respects merchants and traders find the situation satisfactory and promising.

DUBLIN, May 17.--The three men arrested here yesterday on suspicion of complicity in the murders of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Mr. Burke have been released. There is no trustworthy evidence against any of the persons now in custody on account of that crime.

President Lawrence, of the Stock Exchange, will to-day officially summon George H. Kennedy and William J. Hutchinson to appear before the Governors of the Exchange to answer grave charges, which will be formally-preferred at a special meeting of the Governors called for May 31.

LOUISVILLE, May 15.--While the aggregate Spring trade of Louisville shows a marked improvement over the past two seasons, the gain has been in special departments. The present situation is a peculiar one.

MOBILE, May 16.--Trade this season in Mobile has been comparatively duller than last year, though healthier in tone. This dullness would have been much more than overcome if the merchants had taken offerings, but failures last year made them much more careful.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17.--The Louisville Jockey Club continued its Spring meeting to-day. The weather was delightful, the attendance large, and the track fast.

The Board of Trade and Transportation returned yesterday to a consideration of free canals, a directed its Committee on Canal Transportation to confer with committees of other commercial organizations for the purpose of devising and ...
WILMINGTON, May 13.--The business outlook in Wilmington this Spring is encouraging, although there is not that rushing trade expected as was experienced during the past two years at intervals.

NEW-HAVEN, May 17.--Juror Furman told Judge Granger this morning that his daughter was somewhat better, and that the surgical operation which the physicians are to attempt had been postponed in the hope that the patient would gain a little strength.

Mr. N. McGregor Steele, a lawyer, residing in Brooklyn, having been assured by various doctors that he was the victim of an incurable disease, has written a letter to the Brooklyn Eagle stating all the facts in his case and proposing to reward whoever will tell him what his disease is or whoever will cure him.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, May 12.--A review of the Spring trade of this region, with a canvass of the prospects for the immediate future, gives the most satisfactory results.
ATLANTA, May 14.--Trade has been some what later than usual in opening, there being not less than three weeks difference in the weather as compared with last year.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--Quartermaster-General Ingalls has awarded the contracts for clothing, camp and garrison equipage for the various depots for which proposals were opened at the depot in Philadelphia on the 2d inst., as follows; Raymond ...

WASHINGTON, May 17.--Representative White, of Kentucky, in the House, last month introduced a resolution of inquiry concerning the history of the bill to extend the period in which whisky may lie in bond.

The State of Missouri is still mourning for her dead hero, the late Mr. JESSE JAMES. Of course, the Governor, who hired the FORD boys to shoot Mr. JAMES, does not mourn to any great extent; neither do the FORD boys, but, if we can believe the reports ...

Signs of open hostility begin to appear among the merchants of Fourteenth-street; between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, over the showcase question, and a determined contest to see whether the show-cases shall be kept out or taken in seems imminent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13.--The Spring trade of this city is about over. Its condition, taken as a whole, may be described as normal; that is, it has shown a natural increase over last year and the year before, but has not been characterized by speculative advances or declines.

One of the most discouraging features of tho so-called improvement of rivers and harbors is the steady increase of the appropriation made by Congress. Five years ago the appropriation was about $5,500,000.

MILWAUKEE, May 13.--Inquiry among the wholesalers of this city to-day reveals a generally satisfactory state of trade. The increase over the business of 1881 is very noticeable, although there is not the rush and bustle about the houses that were noticeable last year.

The Stock Exchange Base-ball Club met defeat at the hands of the Yale College nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The brokers played a fair game in the field, but could not withstand the heavy batting of the collegians, who pounded the pitching of Denham all over the field, securing 24 singles and a total of 30 base hits throughout the game.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The meeting of the National Jockey Club bean to-day. The weather was clear and bright, but the track was heavy. The attendance was very fine. Among the spectators were President Arthur, Postmaster-General Howe, the Chinese and Japanese Legations, Senators Beck, Davis, and Johnson, and ex-Gov. Pacheco.

BALTIMORE, May 14.--Baltimore merchants are not in their--happiest moods at present for Spring trade has not been entirely satisfactory, nor has it come up to expectations in hardly any of its branches.
DETROIT, May 13.--The Spring trade here has been unusually satisfactory. It has been devoid of speculative disturbances; has been even, healthy, and easy.

RELEIGH, N.C., May 13.--Col. W.H. Tucker, who has been engaged in the dry goods business in this city for more than 40 years, in a talk about the trade of Raleigh this Spring in comparison with that of last year, says that his business, which is nearly all retail, is just as good as that of last Spring.

CINCINNATI, May 13.--Measured by the Clearing-house Exchange, the trade of Cincinnati the present season considerably exceeds that of the Spring of 1881 or of 1880. This is due, however, to an increase in the money value of goods and not to an increase in the mount of goods sold.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 15.--A tour among the leading merchants of New-Orleans affords a mass of information that goes to show that the general mercantile business of this city for the Spring season, commencing Feb. 1, 1882, as compared with that of 1880--81, has suffered a decrease of perhaps one-fourth.
The Yale Alumni Association will hold its last social meeting for this season at Delmonico's to-morrow evening.

ALBANY, May 17.--A bill of Mr. E.C. Sheehy's, nominally to create a pension fund for the Park policemen of New-York, but in reality to increase the salaries of the patrolmen and Sergeants of that force, died peacefully in the Assembly to-day, leaving among the members only a limited number of mournes.
