LEWES, Del., May 17.--The Mallory Line steamer Rio Grande, which was on a voyage from Galveston to New-York, with 90 passengers and a full cargo of cotton, was discovered to be on fire in the lower hold, at about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when she was about 90 miles to the south-east of Cape Henlopen.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The general debate upon the National Bank bill has come to an end and the contest upon the amendments has begun. It is expected that the amendments will be disposed of and the bill passed before the House adjourns to-morrow afternoon.
The year opened with the general expectation among the wholesale dealers of this country of a very large business and with the promise of increased activity in all branches of trade and manufactures.

Several hundred spectators, mostly of the Hebrew faith, gathered yesterday afternoon to witness the laying of the corner-stone of the new building--now in process of erection--of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, on One Hundred and Fifth-street, near Ninth-avenue.
The State Senate was yesterday obliged to lay the Railroad Commission bill over for another day in consequence of the refusal of the Democrats to vote on its final passage.

ST.PAUL, May 17.--The President and two Professors of the State University at Minneapolis were before the municipal court this morning on a criminal charge growing out of the extraordinary performance last night, in which a student was shot by a Professor.

RICHMOND, Va., May 12.--Despite the fact that for the past two years this State has been kept in a continual political agitation, the manufacturers and merchants of Richmond have prospered to an extent unknown to this community since the close of the civil war.
ROCHESTER, May 13.--The year opened with the birghtest business prospects among the merchants and manufacturers, in this city that had been seen for years.
More than 100 physicians assembled last evening in the Hotel Brunswick to celebrate the twenty-third anniversary of the foundation of the Alumni Association of the College of Physicians and Surgeons.
WASHINGTON, May 17.--In executive session this afternoon the Senate confirmed the nomination of Andrew J. Kauffman to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Ninth District of Pennsylvania.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 13.--The country commercially tributary to Memphis has met with more than its usual allotment of troubles during the past year.

HARTFORD, May 16.--The manufacturing industries of Hartford include the Colt establishment, devoted to the making of pistols and guns; the Engineering Company, exclusively engaged in the construction of steam engines; Cheney Brothers, silk manufacturers; Beach ...

ALBANY May 18.--The Railroad Commission bill, which was to be put on its final passage in the Senate again this morning, was postponed until the evening session, at the request of the Railroad Committee, whose Chairman said that more time was needed to examine the amendments made yesterday.

LONDON, May 18.--In the House of Commons this afternoon, on a motion for the second reading of the Repression bill, the Speaker announced that the only paragraph in Mr. O'Donnell's amendment in order was that declaring the bill a fatal obstacle to good government and tranquillity. Mr. O'Donnell denounced the bill.

ALBANY, May 18.--Mr. Crane, of New-York, made a fourth attempt to-day to wrest from the control of the Forty Thieves the bill reducing fares on the elevated railroads to 5 cents. No bill has been so muoh wrangled over during the entire session as this one.
Mr. Charles A. Gillig, of the American Exchange in Europe, (limited,) has just arrived in this City.
WASHINGTON, May 18.--The Senatorial longing for an appropriation, not less than the Senatorial willingness to get rid of the surplus, was manifested repeatedly to-day.
At this late day in the Legislative session a full-fledged charter for the City of NewYork makes its appearance in a mysterious way in the Assembly Chamber at Albany.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 18.--The delegates to the Greenback Labor State Convention continued to arrive slowly this morning, and at 11:05 o'clock, when the body was called to order in the Court-house, not more than 100 delegates were present. Chairman Heath, in calling the convention to order, read a number of telegrams from various delegates announcing that they would arrive in the afternoon.
Delmonico has seldom provided for a more jolly lot of collegians than the 250 members of the Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity, who sat down to dinner in his establisbment last evening.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Map 18.--At an early hour this morning Coroner Knapp was summoned to the County Poor-house, three miles south of Syracuse, by the report that Dr. Henry W. Kendall, of this city, had been shot while attempting to rob a grave in the cemetery attached to the County Poor-house.
FALL RIVER, Mass., May 18.--The operatives in cotton factories here are dissatisfied, and are making overtures which may result in a large strike.

As the engineer of a west-bound train on the Flushing and North Side Railroad was approaching Winfleld station, Long Island, where he was due at 5:47 o'olock yesterday morning, he saw the body of a woman lying on the north side of the track, about 150 feet west of the Thompson-avenue crossing and an eighth of a mile from the depot.

The marriage of Miss Emma Jane Bonner, the only daughter of Mr. Robert Bonner, the wellknown publisher, took place last evening in Dr. Hall's church, in Fifth-avenue, and was witnessed by an assembly of relatives and friends that thronged the edifice.
WASHINGTON, May 18.--Leave of absence for three months, to take effect on or about June 1, has been granted to Second Lieut. Edward T. Brown, Fifth Artillery.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Mr. Taylor, of Ohio, from the House Committee on the Judiciary, has submitted a report on the Ontonagon and Brule River Railroad land grant in the State of Michigan.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 18.--The Louisville Jockey Club continued its races here to-day, five events being on the card, all of which were well contested from the start to the finish.

Mr. Loubat was in his apartments at the Glenham Hotel at 10 o'clock last night, and there was no ono with him. Earlier in the evening he was at the meeting of the New-York Yacht Club. He spent the day in his usual manner, going out of the hotel and returning frequently.
LONDON, May 18.--The Duke of Edinburgh opened the new Eddystone Light-house to-day. After the ceremony luncheon was served.

Several famous English mansions are using or soon will use the electric light. At Alnwick Castle and at Trentham it has already been adopted; the Duke of Portland will soon illuminate Welbeck with it, and the Prince of Wales is said to contemplate its early introduction at Marlborough House.

NEW-HAVEN, May 18.--The first witness in the Malley trial this morning was Prof. George J. Brush, Chairman and executive officer of the Governing Board of the Sheffield Scientific School. He said that Walter Malley became a student in the school in September, 1879. He left it, as near as the Professor could make out from the records, in May, 1880.
BOSTON, May 18.--A cable dispatch from Dublin to the Herald says: "Evictions of tenants for non-payment of rent have been resumed in many parts of Ireland.
WASHINGTON, May 18.--The track at Ivy City was very much improved to-day and was in fair condition. The weather was fine and the attendance good.

The reports which we published yesterday morning of the condition of trade in the various sections of the country afford renewed evidence of the vast extent of our internal commerce--a fact universally acknowledged but not always appreciated.

If the sports of the amphitheatre were attended only by the lower class of people, it would be easy to say that the same love of brutality which induces the dregs of our own population to attend prize-fights characterized the Roman rabble.

HARTFORD, May 18.--The Democratic managers in this State seem to be at a loss what to do in seeking a candidate for Governor this year. There are yet three months in which the search may be prosecuted, but "feelers" are being thrown out thus early in the hope of hitting upon some man who will readily be taken up by the State Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Senator Mahone has become a target for virulent abuse from all the Fuuder papers and politicians in Virginia because he voted, a few weeks ago, with the Republicans to refer the case of Tebbs to the Judiciary Committee.

The sixteenth annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters was held yesterday in the rooms of the local Board of Underwriters. The Senate to-day disposed of the Milson, Spendelow Watson claim for an extension of their patent right in the steam grain-shovel used at Buffalo, by indefinitely pastponing its consideration, the vote being 25 to 21.

MERIDEN, Conn., May 18.--This afternoon Samuel H. Foster, of the prominent hardware manufacturing concern of Foster Co., of this city, assaulted his sister, Mrs. Philip Rand, who refused him admittance to her house, and was soon afterward arrested.

ALBANY, May 18.--The Senate Insurance Committee, of which Senator Kiernan is Chairman, as received a petition of Joseph Davis, a policyholder of the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company. A suit in which a charge of conspiracy to defraud is made against the defendants has been begun in the Superior Court by William E. Badeau against James R. Keene, John D. Prince, James Whitely, Harry E. Logan, Henry C. Oakley, and Maynard C. Eyre. James R. Keene is the wellknown stock jobber.

The difficulty--So far only on paper--between Messrs. J.F. Loubat and Henry Turnbull, of the Union Club, has attracted the attention of the Grand Jury, and subpoenas were issued by that body on Thursday which it was hoped would secure the attendance in the Grand Jury room of all persons supposed to have any knowledge of the affair.

ALBANY, May 19.--The Senate Committee on Cities continued its investigation into the affairs of the Department of Public Works of New-York. John Barry, the sand-dealer, who was on the stand yesterday when the committee adjourned, was recalled.

The Committee on Law of the Board of Aldermen met in the Common Council Chamber yesterday and gave a hearing to the merchants of Fourteenth-street, between Broadway and Sixthavenue, who are interested in the resolution pending before the board to rescind the ordinance recently passed prohibiting the merchants from placing show-cases in front of their premises.

NEW--HAVEN, May 19.--At the close of the session of the court to-day State Attorney Doolittle said that his case way substantially closed. Some of the witnesses who have already testified may be called to supply a few missing links, buy probably the taking of evidence for the defense will commence before Tuesday noon.

Mr. Darwin is reported to have left behind him an autobiography. Among his papers has also been round a sketch of his father, which is said to be almost equal in length to the one of his grandfather, Erasmus Darwin, which saw the light a few years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 19.--The bill to enable national banks to extend their corporate existence was passed to-day by a vote of 125 to 67, but not until nearly six hours had been devoted to the consideration of amendments.

WASHINGTON, May 19.--There was a larger attendance at the races to-day than at any time since the meeting of the National Jockey Club began. The day was pleasant, and the track in fine condition. There were about 5,000 persons present, among them President Arthur, Secretary Folger, and Attorney-General Brewster. CONSTANTINOPLE, May 19.--The situation has undergone an important modification. It is stated that the Porte has completely acquiesced in the action of England and France in Egypt.

BREWSTER'S, N.Y., May 19.--About 5:30 o'clock last evening a team of gray horses drawing a covered conveyance with three seats, the curtains of which were closely buttoned, was driven up to the corner of the avenue leading to the NewEngland depot, at a store kept by Benjamin F. Trumpy.

Augustus v. Leighton, the murderer of Mary Dean, was hanged in the courtyard of the Tombs Prison yesterday morning at 8:46. Leighton, although he was known as a colored man, had so little black blood in his veins that he would have easily passed for a white man in any ordinary assemblage.
The fourth of the May series of off-hand matches will be shot at Creedmoor to-day. John Belly and ex-Judge Cardozo were installed as Sachems of the Tammany Society last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 19.--The leave of absence granted Capt. William R. Livermore, Corps of Engineers, has been extended two months, and leave of absence for four months, to take effect on or about June 28, has been granted Capt. Thomas F. Quinn, Fourth Infantry.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 19.--It is rumored in Winnipeg that General Manager Hickson, of the Grand Trunk Railway, has been appointed General Manager of the Canada Pacific Railway.

BOSTON, May 19.--The annual Spring races of Harvard College took place to-day over the Charles River course, distance two miles. There have been three postponements of the races since last Saturday, and at 1 o'clock today, when the boats took their positions in line, there was a stiff wind blowing up the course that bid fair to cause further delay.

United States Assistant District Attorney Fiero yesterday began the prosecution of Gen. N. M. Curtis before Judge Benedict, in the United Status Circuit Court, on the indictment for receiving political assessments while holding a Government office.

DUBLIN, May 19.--The city Police are new armed with swords. They have not carried such weapons since the Fenian disturbances.
LONDON, May 19.--In the House of Commons this afternoon, Mr. Fawcett, the PostmasterGeneral, announced that the Government had no intention of purchasing telephones.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 19.--A special dispatch to the News-Observer from Marion, N.C., reports the hanging to-day of Stephen G. Effier, white, 25 years old, who was convicted in Burke County, N. C., of wife-murder.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 19.--To-day was set apart as ladies' day by--the Louisville Jockey Club. The attendance was very large and of a brilliant order, on account of the Louisville Cup contest. The weather was fine, the track fast, and the betting spirited and heavy.

CHICAGO May 19.--The wheat shorts appeared very anxious to cover their trades to-day. The orders from these speculators and a fancied brisk demand from the new Milwaukee crowd sent up the price of July and June wheat about 2 cents per bushel.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 19.--During the past Winter the real estate market in Newport has been more active than for several years. There has been no " boom" nor any unnatural inflation of prices. The sales, however, have been numerous...

ASBURY PARK, N. J., May 20.--The one hundred and sixteenth annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Medical Society will be held in Educational Hall next Tuesday and Wednesday. This society is one of the oldest and largest medical societies in the country. Over 300 delegates will attend the meeting.

LONDON, May 8.--It is 3:30 by the great clock at Westminster. The afternoon sun falls bright and gay upon the gilded tracery of the tall towers. The everlasting stream of traffic pours over the bridge that crosses the Thames.

PHELPS, N.Y., May 20.--Prof. Brooks states that he saw Wells's comet with the naked eye last night. It was just visible. The comet is in the constellation Cassiopeia, and at midnight is about midway from the horizon to Polaris.

NORFOLK, Va., May 20.--The Episcopal Council appointed a committee of three clergymen and three laymen to examine the whole question of the diocesan division, and report at the next Council whether the claim of Bishop Whittle to the exclusive right of initiating a movement looking thereto is authorized by the constitution or canons of the Church. The Bishop consented to serve as Chairman of the committee. The Council then adjourned sine die.

Joseph Cobb died yesterday morning in Hull, after a lingering illness, of Bright's disease. He was 74 years old. For more than 25 years he had occupied the position of wharfinger for the old Boston and Hingham Steam-boat Company.

DEAL BEACH, N. J., May 20.--The wrecked steamer Pliny is rapidly being torn to pieces by the surf. This morning she began breaking up very fast, and the beach was soon strewn with the debris that floated ashore.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20.--The Louisville Jockey Club continued its races to-day. The weather was cloudy and warm, and the track fast. The attendance was large and the betting fair.
WASHINGTON, May 20.--The Grand Jury presented Montfort C. Rerdell for indictment to-day, and at the same time presented the other persons, one excepted, who were originally indicted with Rerdell.

A salute of 100 guns was fired on Sacramento-street hill last evening, by direction of the Democratic State Central Committee, in honor of the approval of the anti-Chinese bill by the President. The Chinese, over whose heads the clouds of smoke rolled ominously, seemed to take considerable interest in the matter, as if they fully understood its significance.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--In the Police Court to-day, William Gould, Charles Kerr, and Charles Elms were sentenced to 60 days each in jail for selling Louisiana lottery tickets. Kerr and Elms were also charged in another case with engaging in the business of selling Havana lottery tickets.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 20.--The printing cloth market continues quiet in demand, with light sales, and quotations continued at 3 7/8c. for 64 squares and 3 7-16c. for 60 by 56 cloths. Production for the week, 160,00 pieces; sales, 95,000 pieces; deliveries, 122,000 pieces, and stock on hand, 571, 000 pieces, showing a gain of 38,000 pieces over last returns.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 19.--A story rich with romance is being developed in connection with the discovery of another heir to the estate of the late Ahira Cobb. Mr. Cobb was a very wealthy man, his estate being valued at about $1,500,000. Some nine years ago his son, Elmore, E. Cobb, married a young woman named Minnie Goodman. The marital relations of the couple were unhappy.

It is likely that many people who have a secret apprehension that they may, sooner or later, be called upon to testify before a Congressional committee are very much relieved by the result in SHIPHERD'S case.

BOSTON, May 22.--The championship meeting of the Harvard Athletic Association took place this afternoon at 4 o'clock on Jarvis field. The first event was the mile malk. W.H. Herrick, '82, at once took the lead, and walked the mile by himself in fine shape, His time was 7:52 . D. Baxter, '83, was second, in 9:19 and E.P. Mills, '85, was third.

The efforts of the Board of Emigration Commissioners to secure from the Legislature an appropriation for the support of Castle Garden and the other institutions under their charge have naturally turned the attention of the public to the manner in which the business of the board has been conducted.

BOSTON, May 22.--When the hour for the opening of business came this forenoon the Pacific Bank was found to be closed, and the following notice was soon after posted on the glass screen above the counter near the Cashier's closed windows:
NEW-YORK. "A subscriber" is informed that a Spanish dollar bearing the date of 1812 is worth no more than its specie value--88 cents.
LONDON, May 22.--Sir John Holker has resigned his position as Lord Justice of the High Court of Appeal on account of ill-health.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22.--This was "Clark day," named in honor of the President of the club, and the association had arranged for a grand day's sport, but the rain of yesterday and this morning caused a light attendance in comparison with previous days, despite the fact of the field being thrown open to the public. The track was in wretched shape, and unsafe in places.

There was a notable gathering of clergymen at yesterday's session of the Baptist Pastors' Conference. A large number of delegates to the national anniversary were present and their interesting addresses took the place of the regular Monday programme.
WASHINGTON, May 22.--The majority in the House were unable to transact any business whatever to-day, and when an adjournment was reached no progress had been made toward taking up the Mackey case.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--The steam-ship British King, from Liverpool, which reached this port this afternoon, was searched by half a dozen detectives for persons who might have been connected with the Phoenix Park; assassination. Two or three men of suspicious appearance were closely questioned, but only one was arrested.

MUSCATINE, Iowa, May 22.--There are new and startling developments in the McMenemon patricide, 12 miles west of here, telegraphed saturday. The girl Mary, who on Saturday declared that she shot her father in self-defense; her brother, and her older sister are here in jail.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--The Independent movement in Pennsylvania is a potent reality. It has shaken the Republican Party of the State to its centre, and has created something more than a complication.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 22.--To-day is cold and gloomy. There was a flurry of snow in St. Paul this morning and the thermometer was below freezing point for several hours. The cold weather of the last three days, with almost continuous rains, in the northern part of the State has delayed seeding, which, with good weather, would have been finished.

The trial of Gen. Newton M. Curtis on an indictment charging him with receiving money for political purposes from Federal employes while he was himself an officer of the Government, was continued yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Benedict.

LONDON, May 23.--In the House of Commons this afternoon, Mr. Gladstone moved that the various stages of the Repression bill and the adjourned debate on the Arrears of Rent bill have precedence over all other business until the House shall otherwise order.

QUEBEC, May 23.--The steamer Peruvian, which has been 26 days out, arrived in port tonight in tow of the tug Rocket and steamer Acadian, from St. Pierre-Miquelon. Her passage was both eventful and tedious, owing to ice, snow storms, fog, and damage to the screw. At one time showed her safety to a providential change in the wind.

The following business was transacted at the Exchange yesterday, Tuesday, May 23. Fairehild De Wailtearss sold by order of the Executors, two two-story brick houses, with lots, each 14.5 by 87.9, Nos. 12 and 14 Horatio-st., south side, 151 feet west of Greenwich-av., for $12,000, to J.I. West.

Two alarms were sounded in quick succession over the wires of the Fire Department for a fire which broke out at 1:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the four-story building No.747 Broad way, which runs through to Mercer-street, where it is known as No. 12 Nellson-place. The building was originally two separate structures, but they are now connected on the first and second floors, above which they are still separate buildings.

ALBANY, May 23.--The Senate Railroad Committee heard arguments to-day on the General Street Railroad bill that is being pushed by Sharp, Conover, and other street railroad jobbers. Mr. Deane, of the Corporation Counsel's office, appeared in opposition to the bill, which he analyzed in very much the same manner that it has been done in THE TIMES.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23.--The Louisville Jockey Club continued its Spring meeting to-day. The weather was cloudy and warm, the track heavy, the attendance large, and the betting fair. The officers of the day were the same as yesterday, with the exception of the Judges, who were Gen. Robinson, George N. Stone, and Lew Tarlton.

NEW-HAVEN, May 23.--This, the twenty first day of the Malley trial has unquestionably brought much relief to the prisoners, it being evident that the State Attorney has failed to prove that Jennie Cramer was killed by arsenic administered by either James or Walter Malley or Blanche Douglass.

An investigation by the Sanitary Committee of the Board of Health into a complaint against the bell of St. John the Baptist's Protestant Episcopal Church in Lexington-avenue, near Thirtyfifth-street, was begun yesterday. Prof. C.F. Chandler, the President of the board, was in the chair.

CHICAGO, May 23.--A large number of reports from points in Iowa give further details of the damage by frost on Sunday night, and indicate that last night's cold wave was equally severe. PARIS, May 23.--M. Roustan had an audience with President Grevy yesterday, prior to his departure for his new post as French Minister at Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--By a vote of 38 to 12 the Senate this afternoon passed the bill re-establishing the Court of Commissioners of Alabama Claims, for the distribution of the unappropriated moneys of the Geneva award.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The persistent refusal of the Democrats to allow public business to be done and the failure of the majority to secure the attendance of several Republicans have caused the loss of another day in the House.

WASHINTON, May 23.--Alexander H. Stephens says that he has authorized no one to say that he would accept a nomination from the Independents. He has written a letter defining his position. He will accept a nomination for Governor from the regular Democrats of his State and no other.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., May 22.--A dispatch to THE TIMES was sent from here on April 26 showing the condition of the crops along the valley of the Hudson. The estimate was made with care, the summary being based upon information received from 40 points on both shores of the Hudson River. The estimate has proved accurate so far in nearly every particular.

ALBANY, May 23.--The House suspended all order of business for three quarters of an hour today to listen to the reading of the report of the committee appointed to investigate insolvent insurance companies and the abuses of their Receivers. Mr. Chapin, the Chairman, read the introduction to the report prepared by himself.

ALBANY, May 23.--The digest of the voluminous testimony taken by the Assembly Special Committee on Receiverships, in the examination into the affairs of the Continental Life Insurance Company, was presented to the House to-day, and, without being read, was ordered printed.

A remarkable story of fraud is reported from Plymouth. For some years past a Mrs. Down has been conducting a boarding-house at Devonshire-villas, and up to six months since there lodged with her an old lady, Mrs. Beater Tizard. Shortly after Mrs. Tizard left her house a scheme appears to have entered the mind of Mrs. Down, the ultimate exposure of which has led to the present proceedings being taken.

CAIRO, May 23.--An interview has taken place between Arabi Bey and the French Consul in connection with the efforts to induce Arabi Bey and the rebellious army officers to leave Egypt, but it was without result. Arabi Bey maintained that the country was with him in favor of determined resistance. The Consul replied that Arabi Boy was ill-informed, as the Chamber of Notables were almost unanimously against him.

ALBANY, May 23.--The Railroad Commission bill came up once more for a third reading as the special order in the Senate to-day, when Mr. Jacobs made his usual motion to recommit and amend by inserting the first section of the Assembly bill, making the Commissioners elective.

Our Berlin correspondent, describing the new electric railway there, already referred to in a telegram, says that the system, which has been in use in Berlin for more than a year, has not proved a financial success. It has also been found that there is some inconvenience attending the transmission of the electric current through the rails.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 23.--Charles W. Fonda, the embezzling Cashier, who stole several thousand dollars from the Gonstantine National Bank 18 months ago, pleaded guilty in the United States Court here this morning, and was sentenced by Judge Withey to five years' imprisonment at the Detroit House of Correction.

The Allegheny nine again met defeat at the hands of the Metropolitan Club, on the Polo Grounds, yesterday afternoon, in the presence of about 1,000 spectators. Arundel and Keenan composed the "battery" of the Allegheny Club, while O'Neil and Clapp filled a like position for the home team.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Prices of wheat and corn took a sharp tumble to-day. All the markets were lower. They started on a decline early, in spite of colder weather and bad news from the West; then turned about noon, closing relatively firm. Wheat eased off first, owing to the less favorable advices from Europe.

The members of the Produce Exchange voted yesterday to make next Monday a holiday. John Smith, a painter, while painting the horse at No. 95 Grand-street, yesterday, fell from the fourth story into the yard, and was instantly killed.

LONDON, May 23.--The Epsom Summer meeting began to-day. The race for the Woodcote Stakes for 2-year olds was won by Beau Brummel. Mr. Lefevre's br. f. Hauteur was second and Mr. T. E. Walker's b.c. Tyndrum third.

The Jersey and Guernsey cattle comprising the Brightside herd, owned by Richard M. Hoe, of West Farms, N.Y., and the Waccabuc Farm herd, owned by Herbert Mead, of Lake Waccabuc, N. Y., were sold at auction, at the American Institute Building, yesterday, by Peter C. Kellogg Co. The attendance was large, but the bidding lacked spirit, prices, with few exceptions, ranging low.

CHICAGO, May 24.--To-day the Board of Trade of this city showed its good sense in adopting, by an overwhelming majority, the new rule with regard to Winter wheat.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24.--The Yale base-ball nine easily defeated the nine from Amherst College at Hamilton Park this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--After 20 years of neglect the gallant seamen who manned the little Monitor in her desperate fight with the rebel ram Merrimac, in Hampton Roads, seem about to be remembered in a substantial way.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24.--A dispatch from Tucson, Arizona, this morning states that John H. Weber, a night watchman there, while crazed with liquor, fired several shots among a crowd of people, and a young man, named C.M. Hinton, was instantly killed. Weber is in custody.

The steam-ship City of Alexandria, of the Alexandre Line, which arrived from Vera Cruz and Havana yesterday, brought the crews of the threemasted schooner Silverwing and the bark Pepita, which were wrecked during "northers" in the Gulf of Mexico.

ALBANY, May 24.--In response to a resolution, the Attorney-General sent a communication to the Senate this morning, in which he says there are now in process of liquidation in this State 16 life insurance companies, 24 fire insurance companies, 18 savings banks, and 1 trust company.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 24.--The Official Messenger publishes the regulations agreed upon by the committee of the Ministers and approved by the Emperor on the 15th inst.

The controversy in regard to the first steam railroad train operated in this country is as yet unsettled, but the preponderance of the evidence would seem to show that it was the train run over the Albany and Schenectady Road in 1831.

LONDON, May 24.--The race for the Derby Stakes, at the Epsom Summer meeting to-day, was won by the Duke of Westminster's ch. f. Shotover. Lord Bradford's b. c. Quicklime was second, and Mr. P. Lorillard's ch. c. Sachem third. Mr. H. Rymill's b. c. Bruce, the favorite, came in fourth. The time of Shotover was 2:45 3-5. The betting against Sachem at the start was 8 to 1.

NEW-HAVEN, May 24.--Charles I. Way, not 20 years old, station master at East River, on the Shore Line Road, this morning, though grievously wounded in a single-handed contest with a gang of train-wreckers, saved an express train by an exercise of courage and fidelity rarely exhibited.

One "W.A.C." writes to THE TIMES asking, "Will it do me any harm to eat shoe-blacking?" This is a question which cannot be answered in a brief and careless way without injury either to the manufacturers of shoe-blacking or to " W.A.C."
CHICAGO, May 24.--The Tribune's Springfield special gives extracts from advance sheets of the forthcoming report of the Illinois Department of Agriculture.
BALTIMORE, May 24.--The second day of the meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was more largely attended than the first. The track was in better condition, but not fast.

Alfred D. Emory, aged 20, of No. 157 West Forty-sixth-street. stock clerk in the employ of Lord Taylor, Broadway and Twentieth-street, and Joseph Irving, the proprietor of the "Gotham," a basement drinking place, at No. 35 Bleeckerstreet, were arrested on Tuesday evenine by Inspector Murray and Sergt.
WASHINGTON, May 24, 1882. Jacob R. Shipherd preached in the Congregational Church at Falls Church, Va., last Sunday evening.
A meeting of the General Passenger Agents of the roads west of the western termini of the trunk lines was held at the office of Commissioner Fink yesterday.
POTTSVILLE, May 24.--The town of Shenandoah went wild with excitement to-day over an explosion in the Kohinoor Colliery which resulted in the death of five men and the injury of several others.

CAIRO, May 24.--The Situation is hourly becoming worse. Arabi Bey states that he will only resign at the bidding of the Porte and after the withdrawal of the fleets. The number of loyal notables is daily diminishing under threats of personal violence.

MYSTIC, Conn., May 24.--Capt. Albert C. Burrows, of the steamer Rio Grande, is at his home again, in this village, after the perilous voyage from Galveston to New-York. Capt. Burrows comes honestly by his coolness, self-possession, and courage in time of great peril or danger.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--The ticket made up by the Independent Republicans at their convention in Horticultural Hall to-day is strong enough to beat Cameron's ticket and good enough to deserve election. It is only in moments of uncontrollable enthusiasm that the independents indulge in predictions of triumph for themselves, however.

A temporary Receiver for the New-York City and Northern Railroad Company was appointed yesterday by Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers. The suit in which this proceeding took place is brought by the New-York Loan and Improvement Company.

ALBANY, May 24.--The Assembly to-day, by a majority of 20 votes, agreed, if the Senate will concur, to adjourn on June 2. The resolution fixing this date was presented by Delcour S. Potter, of Saratoga. Coming as it did from a member of the Judiciary Committee, who is regarded as an opponent of any and all hostile proceedings against Judge Westbrook, it created, it must be confessed, some little distrust.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 24.--In the General Assembly to-day, the Rev. James Wilson, for the Board of Foreign Missions, presented the annual report. Judge Strong, of Washington City, gave an account of the work during the past year, calling attention to some obstacles with which the board had to contend.
At the San Francisco Opera-house the last nights of "All at Sea" are announced. "The Professor" may be witnessed during the present week at the Windsor Theatre.
The Spring games of the New-York Athletic Club will take plane to-day. All of the British vessels in port yesterday were gayly decorated with flags and bunting in honor of the Queen's birthday.

ALBANY, May 25.--The Senate has at last succeeded in passing a Railroad Commission bill, with only one dissenting vote, that of Mr. McCarthy, who has from the beginning opposed any commission whatever. The bill as passed is the same as introduced by Mr. Boyd, except that it is not to take effect until Jan. 3, 1883. It gives the appointment of the Commissioners to the next Governor.

Three men were fatally injured yesterday morning by an accident at the new tunnel of the New-York, Lake Ontario and Western Railway, at Union Hill, N.J. A number of men were engaged in setting a drill in shaft No. 4, when a section of work on the side of the tunnel fell from its place upon the tunnel floor.

ALBANY, May 25.--Although the Democrats began weeks ago to prepare an Apportionment bill it was not until to-day that they submitted the result of their labors to the Assembly. As the date for a sine die adjournment has already been fixed for June 2 by the Legislature, only a week remains ...

In one way and another Gen. CHALMERS, of the "Shoestring" District of Mississippi, has made much disturbance among his Democratic friends in and out of Congress. In the first place, it was a great strain on the average Democratic Congressman's conscience to be obliged to defend ...

After a long interval of rest. Gilbert and Sullivan's "Pinafore" was sung last night. To say that this most clever satire is "familiar in our mouths as household words" is so manifestly true that it will hardly warrant repetition, and yet it was evident yesterday evening that the audience enjoyed the representation quite as much as ever before.

ALBANY, May 25.--The Assembly Judiciary Committee met to-night to hear arguments of counsel in the Westbrook-Ward investigation. Preliminary to the opening of the argument counsel on both sides submitted a number of orders for allowances to counsel. Chairman Poucher then declared the evidence closed.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 25.--Yesterday noon, near House Mountain, 16 miles from Knoxville, John Walker was killed by Andrew Evans. Walker, with a sack of meal on his back, was passing Evans's house and was accosted by the latter. Words passed, when Evans ran at Walker, seizing him by the collar.

The Superintendent, Inspectors, and Captains of the Police of this City enjoyed a dinner together last evening at the Brunswick Hotel. The Hon. Thomas C. Acton presided, and among the invited guests were Recorder Smyth, Judges Gildersleeve and Cowing, Surrogate Rollins. Police Justices Gardner and Patterson.

LONDON, May 25.--At the Epsom Summer meeting to-day, the race for the Royal Stakes was won by Lord Bradford's 4-year-old b.c. Limestone, Lord Hastings's 3-year-old ch. f. Silver Bell was second, and Lord Rossmore's (formerly Mr. Lorillard's) 4-year-old b.c. Passaic, third. Eleven horses ran. The following is a summary:

WASHINGTON, May 25, 1882. The committee appointed to make arrangements for a public reception of Lieut. Danenhower upon his arrival in this city met at Willard's Hotel to-night, but after a short interchange of views adjourned until to-morrow evening, when the details of a programme will be agreed upon.

The cause of Chinese missions was the principal theme of discussion at the morning session of the Home Missionary Society of the Baptist Church yesterday. The Rev. Dr. H.M. WASHINGTON, May 25.--District Attorney Corkhill, speaking of the Guiteau case to a Star reporter to-day, said there was only one move that Mr. Reed could make before the courts, and that was to apply for a writ of habeas corpus. He said that no court could grant a writ de lunatico inquirendo ...

Our correspondent at Atherstone telegraphs that eight of the gallant men who attempted the rescue of the imprisoned colliers at Baxterley have died of the injuries they received, and that four or five others are not expected to recover. The attempted rescue was one of those heroin efforts for ...

CHICAGO, May 25.--The May Music Festival is, thus far, a great triumph. The vast Exposition Building has been crowded at every performance, and the audiences have been most enthusiastic. The first concert on Tuesday night, which closed with a generous selection from "Lohengrin," embracing all the salient parts of that noble work, opened the week with brilliant success.

WASHINGTON, May 25.--Adjt.-Gen. Drum and Col. Barr, of the Secretary's office, have gone to Leavenworth, Kan., to inspect the military prison there. They will be gone about a week. Gen. McKeever is acting as Adjutant-General.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 25.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Peninsular Railroad of Maryland, at Pocomoke City to-day, the consolidation with the Peninsular Railroad of Virginia for the purpose of extending the road to Cherrystone was confirmed.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 25.--At to-day's session of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, the Committee on Revisal submitted a report recommending the elimination of the word "South" from the name of the church, and also to change the name of the ...

Already a project has been started for rearing in Westminster Abbey some appropriate monument to the memory of Charles Darwin. A bust has been talked of, and if the funds permit it the intention is to found, in addition, a scholarship bearing Darwin's name, the object of which shall be to foster scientific research.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 25.--One of the largest and most representative meetings of iron manufacturers that has been held in this city assembled at the rooms of the Iron Association today to discuss the situation with reference to the coming June lock-out.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 25.--The afternoon session of the Presbyterian General Assembly yesterday was occupied mainly in hearing the report of the Standing Committee on Publication. The special committee on the same subject submitted a majority and a minority report, and an animated discussion ensued. The measures adopted were:

The race of homing pigeons for the cup offered by William Simpson, President of the National Columbarian Society, will take place July 1 or the first fair day thereafter, the birds to be loosed from Steubenville, Ohio, a distance of 343 miles from here.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 25.--The first case of fraudulent insurance in this part of the West has just been revealed by a suit brought by the NewYork Life Insurance Company against its agent here, F.A. Studdart, for insuring a fictitious person for $5,000 and collecting the amount.
LONDON, May 25.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Mr. Gladstone stated that he would propose that the House adjourn tomorrow until Thursday next.

CHICAGO, May 25.--A Tribune's special from Topeka says that very little damage has been done to grain in Kansas by the recent cold weather and frost. Vegetables and fruit have suffered, but wheat and corn are uninjured.

Letter from Portree (Skye) to the London Standard. To the stranger accustomed to the symmet rical cottages of rural England, a Highland cottar's bothy appears a miserable edifice. BERLIN, May 25.--Prince Alexander, of Bulgaria, has arrived here. SOFIA, May 25.--The Czar has promised his support to Prince Alexander, and has advised him not to use his powers too unrestrictedly, and to select counselors belonging to no party.

Following up the very simple experiment of transporting young shad, the details of which were published in THE TIMES of Friday last, the United States Fish Commissioner forwarded yesterday 1,000,000 young shad from the hatchery at the arsenal in Washington to Mr. E.G. Blackford, the ...

ALBANY, May 26.--The Senate devoted the session to the third reading of bills, a hundred or more having accumulated in that order of business. Among the first taken up was Senate bill No. 326, introduced by Mr. Grady, entitled, "An act to provide for the equalization of assessment and taxation in certain cases." Mr. F. Lansing asked for some explanation of this bill.

The semi-centennial anniversary of the American Baptist Home Missionary Society was commemorated by the National Baptist Convention yesterday by a series of "jubilee" services in the First Church, in Park-avenue, and in the Academy of Music. The attendance was larger than on any day during the sessions of the National Convention.

LONDON, May 26.--A memorial signed by 47 Liberal members of Parliament has been presented to Mr. Gladstone urging a reduction of the period in which the Repression bill shall be in force and modification of the clauses in regard to intimidation, public meeting, and the press. It was Mr. George Russell, Liberal, member for Aylesbury, who, in the House of Commons last night, approved the Repression bill, not Mr. Charles Russell, member for Dundalk.

The annual parade of the Police force, which was postponed on Thursday because of the rain, took place yesterday afternoon in the sunshine. The line of march was from the Battery up Broadway and by the reviewing stand on the plaza at Union-square. The procession started shortly after 8 o'clock, with Superintendent George W. Walling as the commanding officer. The force was divided into four battalions, each battalion being headed ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 26.--The stockholders of the Pittsburg, McKeesport and Youghiogheny Railroad to-day authorized the directory to issue $2,250,000 in 6 per cent. bonds. This is Vanderbilt's line to the coke country connecting with the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad at this point.

BALTIMORE, May 26.--The third day of the Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club, at Pimlico course, drew together a larger audience than gathered on either of the preceding days. The track was heavy, but the races were well contested, and good time was made under the circumstances.
The honor of acting as escort to the President of the United States on Decoration Day has been conferred upon the Old Guard.

ALBANY, May 26.--The Democrats attempted to take the preliminary steps in the Assembly to-day to advance their Apportionment bill, but were defeated. Mr. McClelland, Chairman of the Sub-Committee on Apportionment, moved that rule No. 28 be suspended. This rule requires a two thirds vote to make a matter a special order of business.

A TIMES reporter learned from Controller Campbell yesterday that the example set by the elevated railroads in trying to escape taxation has been followed by the horse-car railroads in this City, who have introduced in the Assembly a bill [No. 403] relieving them from all taxation except the payment to the City of 2 per cent. of their gross receipts.

About 150 gentlemen sat down in the large dining hall at Delmonico's last night at the annual dinner of the New-York Free Trade Club. There was no attempt made at decoration, and the music for the occasion was supplied by Graham McAdam, the Secretary of the club, who was the piano-forte accompanist for the free trade songs which were sung by the company.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--The Democrats, Temporarily aided by some of the Republicans, made an attempt to reach a compromise in the Mackey-O'Connor case to-day and failed. The House adjourned at an early hour, and the Republicans held a caucus immediately afterward. The result indicates that the day for compromises has passed and ...

The Metropolitan nine yesterday afternoon easily disposed of another American Association Club--the Alleghenys, of Pittsburg--on the Polo Grounds, in the presence of a large number of spectators. The New-York men batted the pitching of Arundel with apparent ease, and secured 17 singles, with a total of 25 base hits, during the game.

About three weeks ago Minister and Mrs. Hunt gave their farewell reception prior to their departure for Russia. A little incident in connection with that reception is now given showing the simplicity of our republican institutions. The night in question was a fearful one; rain fell in torrents, and there seemed to be no cessation to Jove's tears.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--Au hour and a half on Thursday and more than an hour today were used up in the Senate in discussing a bill proposing to reimburse " a Creek orphan fund," established so long ago that none of the Creek orphans whom it was then proposed to help can be less than 50 years of age, and directing that more than $250,000 shall be paid ...

The New-York Loan and Improvement Company is making rapid progress in its work of putting an end to the existence of the New-York City and Northern Railroad Company. It took another judgment against the railroad company by default in the Supreme Court yesterday. The amount of this judgment is $923,697.49. An execution was issued to the Sheriff as soon as the judgment was ...

LONDON, May 26.--The race for the Oak Stakes for 3-year-old fillies took place to-day at the Epsom Summer meeting. The track was somewhat heavy from yesterday's rain. The last betting was six to four on Geheimniss, five to one against Nellie, five to one against St. Marguerite, twenty, to one against Incognita, and twenty to one against Lady May.

For Richard Wagner's recent journey homeward from Italy King Louis, of Bavaria, sent his private saloon carriage to Venice, whence the composer was taken with his family over the Brenner pass to Munich and Beyreuth. King Louis, it is said, will be one of the witnesses at the coming wedding in Munich of Hans von Billow's daughter Danella.

To a TIMES reporter who asked him what he thought of the passage by the Legislature of the bill relieving the elevated railroads from all taxation except the payment to the City of 4 per cent. on their gross receipts, Controller Campbell declared yesterday that the measure was an outrage upon the community, and added that the best statement he could give of his views on ...

WASHINGTON, May 26.--Adjt.-Gen. Drum has issued a general order providing that hereafter a revolver shall form part of the equipment of each company Sergeant of all arms of the service, instead of solely to the cavalry, as at present.
LONDON, May 26.--The Departmental Committee has reported that the Channel Tunnel is defensible, but suggests that the opening be carried further inland, where means of defense are more complete.

The Assembly yesterday failed to reconsider the vote by which the bill was passed relieving the elevated railroads of this City of more than half their share of taxation. The responsibility now rests with the Governor to defeat this infamous piece of legislation, in behalf of the most impudent monopoly of modern times.

ST. PAUL, Minu., May 26.--A large number of crop reports from points in Northern Minnesota agree in the favorable showing. The weather in the whole region is clear and cool. The soil is in good condition and rapidly drying out, and early sown wheat is up and looking well. Wheat seeding is completed in Minnesota except at a few points north of Glyndon, in the Red River Valley, where some still remains to be done.

The house was crowded, and among the persons present were Samuel Sloan, Charles H. Russell, Cyrus W. Field, Russell Sage, School Commissioner Wood, James A. Roosevelt, Peter Cooper, Edwards Pierrepont, William Libby, ...

Arrangements had been made for the marriage on Wednesday last of Col. Henry C. Lockwood, of the law firm of Lockwood Lockwood, of No. 128 Broadway, to Mrs. Frances H. Walker. Both were residents of this City, Mrs. Walker living in Harlem. The parties were to have been quietly married at Mrs. Walker's residence by the Rev. D.B. Ray at 7 o'clock in morning.

The strike of the boiler-makers assumed a new feature yesterday, the union calling in all its members who had gone to work for the firms who were paying the 10 per cent, advance and ordering them to stay out until all the employing boilermakers in this City and Brooklyn should grant the advance demanded. The Brooklyn Police authorities announce that they have finally given up anything like a systematic search for George A.W. Stuart, the absconding Secretary of the Brooklyn Board of Education, who fled last September after stealing, in the course of 10 or 12 years, over $250,000. When Stuart first fled the Police professed to believe that he was accompanied by his wife.

CAIRO, May 26.--The ultimatum of the English and French Governments further prescribes the interning in the interior of Egypt of Abellah Pasha and Ali Fehmy Pasha, who, next to Arabi Bey, are the leaders of the military party. The diplomats here consider it almost certain that the Ministry and the military party will reject the ultimatum.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26.--The Jockey Club were favored with beautiful weather again to-day. A programme of six events was presented, and all proved to be capital contests. The attendance was large, the track fast, and the betting fair. The judges were John S. Clark, Gen. Robinson, and Capt. Cottrill.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 26.--The Journal's correspondent has made an investigation this afternoon regarding a report current in New-Haven today that the story of Charles Way, the young station agent at East River, on the Shore Line Road, who gave a wonderful account of his discovery of train wreckers the other night, is not wholly believed by the railroad people.

Scott, colored, and Mrs. Adam Wilson, who have just been tried at Chesterfield, S.C., for the murder of Adam Wilson, the husband of one of the accused, have bean acquitted. BOTON, Mass., May 26.--The will of the late Ralph Waldo Emerson was found among his papers, and has been filed for probate. He gives all his real estate, with the exception of his house and homestead estate in Concord, equally to his three children, Edward Waldo Emerson. Ellen Tucker Emerson, and Edith Emerson Forbes, wife of William H. Forbes, of Milton, and their heirs, ...

Lynde Stetson, the associate counsel of the committee, further considered the action of Judge Westbrook in connection with the Manhattan Company litigation and the correspondence ...

The Governing Committee of the Union Club, at a meeting held on Thursday evening last, expelled Mr. Loubat from the club by an almost unanimous vote, and passed a vote of censure on Mr. Turnbull. The governors present at the meeting were Messrs. William Constable, William II. Appleton, Samuel D. Babcock, Christopher C. Baldwin, John H. Draper, J. Bowers ...

BOSTON, Mass., May 26.--There was an attendance of 3,500 people to witness the races of the closing day of the Spring meeting of the Myopia Club at Mystic Park this afternoon. The weather was fine and the track in fair condition.

NEW-HAVEN, May 26.--In the Malley case to-day, the early part of the session was devoted to strengthening the proof that Walter E. Malley and Blanche Douglass were at Branford Point Friday evening, Aug. 5. This part of the defense was completed. A movement for the organization of an Exchange for the hay trade in this City has been in progress for some time, and the first steps to establish one were taken yesterday. It is a matter of surprise in commercial circles that such an institution has not been already established. The principal crops raissd in the United States in 1880 were valued at $2,131,051,859.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27.--Political matters remain about as they have been. There is somewhat of a lull just now. The State Conventions of both parties have been called, and the attitude each party will assume with respect to the question of the pending amendments is so well settled that there is very little to agitate the people.

The Grand Marshal of the Decoration Day parade, accompanied by the members of his staff, will attend memorial services at St. Paul's Church this afternoon. Dahlgren Post, No. 113, and J. Rice Post, No. 29, will not as escort from the cottage in Union-square to the church.

The Veteran Corps of the Ninth Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., celebrated the twenty-first anniversary of the departure of the regiment for the seat of war during the rebellion by a dinner at the Westminster Hotel. There were about 70 persons present, to whom an excellent...

Washington items are to the effect that whenever the sombre ceremony now appointed for June 30 shall have been performed GUITEAU'S brain will be dissected and examined with the purpose of making his sanity obvious to ocular inspection.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Senator Cameron arrived at the Continental Hotel early this morning and was soon in conference with several well-known business men, representing the commercial, financial, and manufacturing interests of the city and State, with reference to supporting the ticket.

Land in corn-growing parts of England is falling off in value. A small estate in one of the eastern counties, which four years ago was valued at $125,000, was put up at auction three weeks ago, and the highest price offered for it was $45,000. It comprises 400 acres, and was bought in by the Trustees.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 27.--In the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day the Moderator presented the following telegram, received last night from the Southern Assembly, now in session at Atlanta, Ga.:

PARIS, May 27.--There was another Academic feast at the Institute on Thursday, when M. Cherbuliez was solemnly received into the bosom of the Immortals by M. R nan. This is the third time within a few months that R nan has been called upon to deliver a speech before his august brethren, and right well did he again acquit himself of the task.

Throughout his life Hawthorne led a two-fold existence--a real and a supernatural. As a man be was the realest of men. From childhood to old age he had great physical strength and power. His massive head sat upon a strong and muscular neck, and his chest was broad and capacious.

One instance of promiscuous slaughter is remark able for the high esteem to which it sometimes raised its chief perpetrator. In the famous war between the citizens of Client and the Earl of Flanders there was no worse episode than when the Lord d'Anghien took the town of Grammont by storm one fine Sunday in June, and showed no mercy to man, woman, or child.

LOUISVILLE, May 27.--The Louisville Jockey Club brought their Spring meeting to a close today with a grand programme of 10 races. The weather was cool and showery, the track in good condition, attendance large, and betting good.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 27.--Crop dispatches from the southern part of the State are more favorable to-day than at any time since the cold rains. Reports from points on the Sioux City line, from St. Paul south-westward to the State line, say that the weather is warm and bright. Further south in Northern Iowa, the weather is cooler and cloudy, with occasional rains.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26.--The continued wet weather is having a decided dampening effect on the season here. Over 100 cottagers have arrived, but the number would be larger if May had been a Spring month in reality as in same. The plentiful rains, however, have made beautiful Newport's unrivaled lawns, and the trees are putting on their Summer dress with much rapidity.
WASHINGTON, May 27.--The Republicans presented in the House to-day, as a proposition to offset the one submitted yesterday by the Democrats, the resolution adopted by the Republican caucus.
WASHINGTON, May 27.--The PostmasterGeneral recently sent to the House a statement relating to the mail service, and declared that in his opinion postage on second class matter should be abolished.
The last days of Knickerbocker life in New-York were past days when Mr Dayton sat down in his late manhood to recall what he could about them, and the associations that clustered about their memory.
The Metropolitan Casino is to be opened on the 10th of June. It is stated that performance will be given including operettas, ballet, and miscellaneous concerts by full companies.

The eunuch is a great personage in the harem or palace. His power is almost absolute. There is no limit to his control. The chief eunuch in a palace is styled Kislar Agaci; he is black, and takes the position of the second man of the Empire, ranking with the Grand Vizier.

BALTIMORE, May 27.--The Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club closed to-day. The weather was fair-and warm, and the attendance was the largest of the meeting. The fields were small but the races mere very fine and some of the most noted horses in the country were engaged in the contests.

A decree absolutely divorcing Leopold Schepp from Marietta Schepp was made by Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, in March last. The suit which was thus terminated, was began by Mr. Schepp in January, and was tried before a Referee, upon whose report the decree was based.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--Special orders, May 15, are amended so as to direct Capt. William H. Gill, Military Store-keeper, to report to the officer in charge of the depot of the Quartermaster's Department at Philadelphia, for assignment to duty on June 30, to relieve Capt. John F. Rodgers, Military Store-keeper.

ST. LOUIS, May 27.--Reports from Lebanon, Mo., give the details of a tragedy which has occurred near Bennett's Mill, 14 miles south-west of that place. A bad feeling had existed during the past weeks between George and William Matthews and some of their neighbors. Yesterday a disturbance occurred between George Matthews and James Ford, both the Matthews boys at the time being intoxicated.
The Rev. Robert Collyer will preach this evening at the Church of the Messiah on "Memories of a Battle-field."

Before the Senate Committee on Corners and Futures in Grain and Other Food Products, yesterday, Harlan A. Pierce, for many years a writer on commercial topics, said that the system of corners and futures was detrimental to legitimate business and transportation. It was a fact that members of the Produce Exchange who at one time were in the commission business were now ordinary brokers.

The Knickerbocker Canoe Club had their first monthly contest for the Commodore's pennant yesterday, but adverse winds and tides combined to make the sailing race a failure. The proposed course was from the club-house on the Hudson River, at the foot of Eighty-sixth-street, north to the pier at the foot of Ninety-sixth-street.

Miss Clara Morris will appear as Mercy Merrick to-morrow night at the Boston Park Theatre.

CHICAGO, May 27.--The decision of the committee on the April wheat corner continues to be the leading topic of discussion on 'Change, and there are some new phases of the matter which promise to be interesting. Some of those who are fiercest in their denunciation of the setting price yesterday are to-day more inclined to find fault with the rule than with the committee.

The bill introduced into the Assembly by Gen. George H. Sharpe providing for the closing up of the affairs of insolvent corporations is now pending before the Senate. The most prominent feature of Assemblyman Sharpe's bill is the provision by which the State Treasurer is made the State Receiver, and making the Attorney-General the counsel to the State Receiver.

Let us consider briefly what manner of man Arthur Schopenhauer was. His life may be read at large in the pages of Gwinner, Frauenstadt, and Lindner, and in the instructive little English work which Miss Zimmern has compiled from these and other sources. As to its external incidents, it is soon told.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met in Mayor Grace's office yesterday and made the annual appropriation for the expenses of the Excise Department for the current fiscal year. President Mitchell, of the Excise Board, said that the Excise Commissioners desired an appropriation of $83,200, an increase of $12,000 over the amount given them last year.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 1,--The question of redistricting the State under the new census came up in the Democratic caucus at Baton Rouge last night. As the districts now stand the First and Second Districts have 3,700 votes less than their proportion, while the Third has 18,000, the Fifth 13,000, and the Sixth 8,000 too many. The matter had been referred to a committee, which recommended only one change in the Congressional districts.

All the members of his family, residing in Rome and Genoa, were hastily summoned, but they had scarcely departed for his bedside when the news came that Gen. Garibaldi was dead. His death occurred at 6:30 o'clock last evening.

NEW-HAVEN, June 2.--Confidence in the success of Yale in the coming contest with Harvard on the Thames, at New-London, on the 22d inst., fluctuates among the critics who have lately paid attention to the practice of the Yale crew.
The Paterson Board of Education last night approved of a contract for another public school building, to be built in the First Ward. This will make 12 public school buildings in the city altogether.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 2.--Bishop Gilmour, of the Cleveland Catholic Diocese, to-day issued a card to the ladies of the Land League, threatening their excommunication unless they renounce all relations thereto.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--The methods by which the Government was defrauded in the star mail service were effectively described to the jury to-day by Col. George Bliss, counsel for the Government in the star route cases, who spoke for about four hours and a half.

Mme. Materna appeared in a concert in Music Hall, Boston, last evening, before a crowded and enthusiastic audience. Her air from "Rienzi" was received with great applause, and she was obliged to yield to an encore. Candidus's Walkure song was also encored.

CATLETTSBURG, Ky., June 3.--A train of cars steamed into the Catlettsburg station at 2:30 o'clock this morning, and from it alighted several hundred masked men. The train came from Ashland, and the mission of the men was to avenge the fate of the Gibbons children at that place in December last.

CLEVELAND, June 4.--The Cleveland Rolling Mill Company will start to-morrow, provided enough non-union men can be obtained to man a single turn. The strikers held a meeting to-day when several speakers urged them to hold out and to refuse to go to work until their demands have been agreed to. They then held a secret meeting, the result of which could not be ascertained.

NEW-BERNE, N.C., June 4.--Henry Bryan, (colored.) who has been on trial for the last two days for the murder, on Feb. 1, of J.M. Agestine, an employe of the Midland North Carolina Railway, has been acquitted, the verdict of the jury last night being that he was insane.

RICHMOND, June 4.--The proposition to remove the body of Thomas Jefferson from the old graveyard at Monticello, in this State, and place it in a cemetery in Washington, meets with widespread indignation in Virginia. ST. LOUIS, June 5.--The St. Louis Jockey Club began its Spring meeting to-day. The weather was fine, and the grounds of the association seldom presented a more attractive appearance. JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 7.--The twnetysixth annual meeting of the New-York State Press Association commenced here to-day, 150 representatives being present. This evening ex-Gov. Fenton presided over the meeting. A.W. Tourgee delivered an address and a poem was read by Will Carleton.

LONDON, June 7.--The House of Commons this afternoon resumed the discussion of the Repression bill. In debate on an amendment offered by Mr. Charles Russell, Liberal member for Dundalk, defining intimidation as threats or acts of violence to person or property, or incitement thereto, Mr. Dillon defended ...

WASHINGTON, June 7.--Second Lieut. Charles B. Satterlee, Third Artillery, has been detailed as Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the Michigan Military Academy, Orchard Lake, Mich., July 1, relieving Second Lieut. George R. Cecil, Thirteenth Infantry, who has been ordered to join his company.

A wrestling-match of the superlative degree and of the catch-as-catch-can order is to take place in this City on the evening of July 8 between the two most noted wrestlers of the age, Mr. Edwin Bibby, ...
ST. LOUIS, June 7.--The St. Louis Jockey Club was favored with fine weather again to-day. The track was in perfect shape, the attendance large, and the betting brisk.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 7.--At the instance of the fathers of two of the Trinity College students who were "hazed" by members of the Senior Class last April, prosecutions have been brought against the 13 students who were suspended by the Faculty, and who have recently returned to the city. There was a special hearing in the case in the Supreme Court to-day. The offending students pleaded nolle contendere, and were fined $10 each and costs.

CHICAGO, June 7.--Mrs. Scoville, sister of Guiteau, has given to the press a copy of a petition addressed to President Arthur, asking for a stay of execution in the case of Guiteau until a commission of competent ...

ST. LOUIS, June 7.--After a long debate, which occupied the entire morning session, the International Typographical Union adopted a resolution leaving the question of abolishing the sub list system to the subordinate unions.

The members of the Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club made merry at Hubel's restaurant last night. Three long tables, with covers for about 25 persons each, were completely filled by the members of the club and their guests. At the head of the central table sat the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, President of the club.
The estate of the late Richard H. Dana, of Boston, has been appraised at $106,297.
LONDON, June 7.--At the Ascot meeting today the race for the Ascot Derby Stakes, for 3-year olds, was won by the Duke of Westminster's ch. f. Shotover, the winner of the Derby Stakes at Epsom, ...
The Irving Bowling Club gave their Summer reception last evening in the Terrace Garden, at Fifty-eighth-street and Third-avenue.

The lawyers occupying offices at No. 152 Broadway have been annoyed recently by sneak thieves, who have carried off many of their lawbooks.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., June 7.--The reunion of officers of the Union and Confederate Armies upon the battle-field of Gettysburg, for the purpose of defining the positions of the various commands, commenced here to-day.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 7.--A dispatch has been received from Capt. C.E. Bennett, Seventh Infantry, in command at Fort Sisseton, Dakota, stating that 35 lodges of Indians are encamped within three miles of the fort.
PHILADELPHIA, June 7.--At a meeting tonight of the committee appointed by the Board of Directors of the Keely Motor Company to try to adjust the differences between Mr. Keely and certain ...

HARTFORD, Conn., June 7.--The monthly report of the State Board of Health, published today, says that lung diseases hold the front rank. Consumption has been as fatal as lung fever, and there has been a large percentage of deaths from bronchitis and congestion of the lungs.

The annual inspection and muster of the Second Division, N.G., S.N.Y., took place yesterday at the Prospect Park parade ground. All the regiments in the division were present and took part in the various drills, but the Twenty-third and Forty-seventh Regiments were not inspected, ...

A large number of persons attended the meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday. Among those present were several representatives of the elevated railroads, who had come for the purpose of inducing the board to reconsider their refusal to allow the erection of a station at Battery Park and Greenwich-street.

TROY, N.Y., June 7.--A marble company at Fair Haven, Vt., is making tablets commemorative of Gen. George A. Custer and the heroes of the Seventh Regiment, United States Army, who were massacred by Indians at the Little Big Horn, Montana Territory, on June 25, 1876.
WASHINGTON, June 7.--The River and Harbor bill promises to become so large and costly that it will be difficult to secure its approval by the President.

CIVITA VECCHIA, June 7.--A telegram from Caprera announces that the family of Gen. Garibaldi have decided to abandon the cremation of his body, owing to the practical difficulties in the way of its accomplishment. The body will be interred, provisionally at least, at Caprera on Thursday.

About three weeks ago a man who gave his name as John Adams was taken to Police Headquarters, Newark, by a farmer named Marcelles. The man applied to Marcelles for work, and, as he appeared to be anxious to make a living for himself, the farmer have him employment.
The English version of the "Merry War" is already well rehearsed at the Germania Theater, and will soon be produced with all the attractions of a large company and the best scenery and costumes.
The rival Republican associations of the Twelfth Assembly District met last evening at their respective head-quarters.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 7.--Heavy forest fires are raging in the vicinity of Merrillan, this State, and much damage is being done to standing timber. None of the towns is considered in danger.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 7.--The anticipations of trouble about the rolling mills to-day were not realized, due partly to the ample preparations made by the Mayor and Police and the efforts made by the leading strikers to preserve order. The Police were about the works all day, and none of the men were molested, except by taunts on their way home from work. The number of men at work yesterday was by no means enlarged to-day.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June. 7.--The Republican State Convention held in this city to-day was, strictly speaking, a representative body and, in point of intelligence, has seldom been surpassed if equaled in the history of Ohio conventions. The morning session, at which the preliminary organization was effected and committees were appointed, was largely attended, many representative Republicans other than delegates being present.

The Benevolent and Social Order of Lambs made merry last evening in Washington Park, on the East River, between Sixty-ninth and Seventieth streets, where they gathered with their friends of both sexes, to the number of several hundred.
TORONTO, Ontario, June 7.--Hanlan is feared to be dangerously ill. The doctors say that, even if he recovers, he cannot possibly row at Winnipeg.

EMPORIA, Kan., June 7.--The Greenback and Anti-Monopoly Convention to-day nominated D.J. Cole for Congress from the Third District, and S.H. Wood, of the Kansas State Journal, for Congressman at Large.
BOSTON, June 7.--At the annual meeting of the shareholders of the Franklin Telegraph Company, of this city, today, the following were chosen Directors: E.P. Morgan, Augustus Schell, Norvin Green ...
Messrs. Gustav Schwab, Charles S. Smith, and James W. Elwell, comprising the Pilotage Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, met yesterday ...

ALBANY, June 6.--The busy members of both houses, in casting about for subjects to legislate upon or existing laws to tinker, did not overlook the topic of insurance. As a result, a number of statutes are now to be added to the list of session laws of 1882. The one of all others which has attracted attention is that fathered by Assemblyman Raines, an insurance agent of Ontario.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--Mr. Rollins, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, to-day reported to the Senate a substitute for the bill introduced by Mr. McPherson to regulate the promotion of graduates from the Naval Academy and appointments in the Navy. The principal feature in the bill is a provision directing the Secretary of the Navy to ...
