RALEIGH, N.C., June 7.--The Independent Liberal State Convention met here to-day. William Johnson, of Mecklenburg, called the convention to order and was then elected President.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7.--Capt. Fenwick, of the British steamer Strathairly, was arrested to-day on a charge of bringing to this port 326 Chinese passengers in excess of the number allowed his ship by law. He was released on bail.
Cardinal John McCloskey, by a deed recorded in the Register's office yesterday, transferred to the Roman Catholic Church of All Saints property ...

The letter which we printed yesterday morning from the Chairman of the Cameron convention to the Chairman of the Republican State Committee is a very valuable contribution to the history of the party in Pennsylvania and throughout the country.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 7.--The seventysixth annual session of the Reformed Church of America, formerly the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, met in the First Church of this city to-day. The Rev. E.P. Ingersoll, D.D., of Brooklyn, was elected President, and the Rev. William Ormiston, ...

The Masonic Grand Lodge resumed labor yesterday morning, Grand Master Taylor presiding. The session was opened with prayer by R.W. and Rev. Brother Charles W. Camp, Grand Chaplain. A communication was received from M.W. Elwood E. Thorne, Past Grand Master, announcing the death of Robert Former Bower, General Grand High ...

It was learned in well-informed insurance circles yesterday that all the preliminary arrangements looking to the reinsurance of the Watertown Insurance Company by the Sun Insurance Company of London have been completed. The contract, however, cannot be signed until ...

WASHINGTON, June 7.--The President this afternoon sent to the Senate his nominations to fill the commission authorized by Congress to inquire into the tariff and suggest legislation. The names were identical with the list furnished to THE TIMES last night and were as follows: William A. Wheeler, of New-York, Chairman; John L. Haves ...
CHICAGO, June 7.--There was a big boom in July wheat on Change to-day. In the morning the price was $1 30, at the close of the call $1 33, and the later quotation was $1 34.

There arrived in the East India Docks of London a fortnight ago a sailing vessel laden with the first consignment of frozen meat which has been sent to England from New-Zealand. The ship had been 98 days on the voyage, and during all that time the chambers containing the meat had been kept at 20 below the freezing point. The meat consisted of 5,000 sheep, and is said to have arrived in fine condition.

NEW-HAVEN, June 7.--Maxwell Evarts, son of ex-Secretary William M. Evarts and a member of the Sophomore Class of Yale College, is the owner of a fine healthy badger. He also owns a rat terrier named Fannie.

Miss Grace M. Hustace, daughter of Mr. William Hustace, was married in St. Thomas's Church yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Morgan to Mr. Edward Van Zandt Lane. The ceremony took place at 4 o'clock. The church was crowded. The chancel was decorated with ferns, palms, palmettoes, and flowering plants.
This will be the fourth day of the meeting of the American Jockey Club, and as it is "Derby Day" there will doubtless be a large crowd present.

WASHINGTON, June 7, 1882. Mr. Sparks, of Illinois, denies that in the colloquy which occurred in the House yesterday between Mr. Cox, of New-York, and himself, he made use of the expression "You little scamp," and Mr. Cox says he did not hear any such expression.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7.--The incorporators of the proposed Vassar Hospital, provided for in the late Matthew Vassar's will, are John G. Vassar, Irene B. Vassar, O.H. Booth, James H. Weeks, Dr. I.M. Cleveland, Henry L. Young, and S.M. Buckingham.

ALBANY, June 7.--The annual election for Directors of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, held here to-day, resulted in the re-election of the following board: W.H. Vanderbilt, Cornelius Vanderbilt, W.K. Vanderbilt, F.W. Vanderbilt, Augustus Schell, Samuel F. Barger, Chauncey M. Depew, James H. Rutter, J. Pierpont Morgan, Cyrus W. Field, of New-York; Chester W. Chapin ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 7.--The American Medical Association resumed its session this morning. Dr. Charles Denison, of Colorado, offered a statement, the substance of which was that a misapprehension existed in the minds of many persons as to the liberty of action ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 7.--The Penn National Bank has purchased for $80,000 the old brick building at the south-west corner of Seventh and Market streets in which it has so long been held that Jefferson wrote the Declaration of Independence. The old building will be torn down and a bank structure erected on its site.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 7.--The Greenback State Convention met here to-day, with 300 delegates in attendance. The usual committees were appointed, and speeches were made by Gen. Weaver, D.P. Stubbs, and others.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--In the House to-day Mr. Sparks apologized to Mr. Cox for the personal remarks made by him yesterday. The House went into Committee of the Whole and resumed consideration of the General Deficiency Appropriation bill. On a point of order raised by Mr. Holman the clause was ruled out appropriating $1,800 to pay William H. Johnson, attorney in fact, or Assignee of certain Supervisors of Election in New-York City.

President Lawrence formally announced to the members of the Stock Exchange yesterday that the Exchange Governors had expelled William J. Hutchinson from the board. The charge and specifications upon which Mr. Hutchinson was tried were read from the rostrum by Secretary B. O. White, the members of the Exchange assembling ...
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 7.--The Greenback State Convention had to-day 50 delegates, 1 per cent. of the whole number appointed by counties.
MADRID, June 7.--A depot of muskets, ammunition, and swords has been discovered near Barcelona. Several arrests have been made in connection with the discovery.

The lawn-tennis tournament of the St. George's Cricket Club, open to all comers, for singles and doubles, began at the club grounds, in Hoboken, yesterday. The number of entries was not large, and the attendance of spectators was very small.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 8.--After the flurry of the State Convention, when men of eager and wide political experience have expressed their opinions and made their estimates, it is clearly apparent to the casual observer that the platform and ticket approved by the Republican convention yesterday does not and will not meet with the approval of the majority of the citizens.
The letter of the Rev. Nowman Smyth, D. D., accepting the call to the Centre Church of NewHaven, Conn., was read to the congregation on Sunday, and is as follows:

Mr. Edward Parsons, of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon, at the residence of the bride's father, to Miss Florence C. Sheldon, daughter of Mr. Henry Sheldon, No. 124 Pierrepontstreet, Brooklyn Heights.

CAIRO, June 8.--Dervisch Pasha has arrived here. The mission comprises 58 persons. It is understood that the leaders of the military party intend to apply to Dervisch Pasha to effect a reconciliation between themselves and the Khedive.

"The development of the Wells comet," said Prof. Boss, of the Dudley Observatory, yesterday, "so far as concerns the throwing off of a tail, has been disappointing to astronomers in general, and particularly to me, in view of the glowing predletions which I made during the first weeks after its discovery.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 8.--Pursuant to a call extensively issued throughout the State, a convention of merchants, manufacturers, and producers of the State of New-York assembled at Association Hall, in this city, at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

Complaints have of late years been often made in Germany of the fast increase of shortsightedness among young people at school, and similar ones are now heard in France. A committee appointed to investigate the subject have reported that the cause of the evil lies in the schoolbooks, which are printed in fine type on white paper.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--In the Senate to-day, Mr. Blair's resolution calling for information as to the quantity of land embraced in the land grants to certain railroads, with the quantity patented and the amounts accruing for roads constructed, , was adopted.

The Masonic Grand Lodge was in almost continuous session from 9 o'clock yesterday morning until after 6 o'clock in the evening, the greatest portion of the time having been consumed in the election of officers. Grand Master Taylor called the brethren to order promptly at 9 o'clock, and there was an unusually large attendance of representatives.

LONDON, June 8.--Mr. J.R. Keene's 4-yearold b.c. Foxhall, at the Ascot meeting to-day, won the race for the Gold Cup, value 1,000 sovereigns, with 200 sovereigns for the second, and 100 sovereigns for the third, added to a subscription of 20 sovereigns each, half forfeit.
If the local authorities in the Southern States, more particularly in South Carolina, have nothing to conceal, their conduct in the matter of managing their election machinery is most extraordinary.

RICHMOND, Va., June 8.--The Republican, or anti-Mahone, State Committee, at a meeting held to-day, issued a call for a State Convention to meet here for the nomination of a Congressman at Large, and to determine the policy to be pursued by the Republicans who...

ST. LOUIS, June 8.--The attendance at today's races of the St. Louis Jockey Club was very large, and the grand stand was filled to overflowing. The weather was bright and very warm, and the track was fast, but very dusty. The betting was the heaviest during the meeting.

YOKOHAMA, May 20.--The census returns compiled by the General Register Bureau for the year 1881 give the following as the population of Japan: Males, 18,423,274; females, 17,935,720. These figures show an enormous yearly increase. Serious fires are reported from Inaba and Yechigo Provinces.

BOSTON, June 8.--The races to-day, the third day of the June meeting, at Mystic Park, were quite interesting, and the attendance was larger than yesterday. Two races were trotted--one for 2:38 class, with a field of six, and the other for 2:29 class, with a field of 14.

ALBANY, June 8.--A law, the operations of which will be watched with great interest, is that protecting primary elections and conventions of political parties in Brooklyn, and punishing offenses committed thereat. Should it remedy the evils of the existing method of conducting these assemblages, it will doubtless pave the way for a general law of similar import, applicable to the whole State.

The Seventh Regiment, Col. Emmons Clark commanding, turned out yesterday 603 strong, rank and file, to punish the targets at Creedmoor. Company B. Capt. Steele commanding, exhibited 79 men, and led the other companies in point of number.

DENVER, Col. June 8.--There were no changes or new developments in the railroad situation yesterday. The Rio Grande and New-Orleans rates remain at the same low figures, and the latter road is doing a very large passenger business.

Next Sunday [May 21] and the following days have been appointed for the solemn opening of the railway across the Alps between Lucerne and Milan. By the achievement of the longest tunnel, the St. Gothard route, which was at all times the most sublime and picturesque, becomes also the shortest and easiest--the most eligible way into Italy.

WEST POINT, June 8.--When the Cadets come to the hotel to see their friends they must inscribe their names in a book, together with the names of those whom they wait upon. The scene about this book is quite animated, especially in the morning and evening hours.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 8.--The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated E. A. O'Neal for Governor by acclamation. He is a native of Alabama.

All who have visited that island which will ever be held sacred in the ecclesiastical history of Scotland--the island of Iona--will remember that the guide, in explaining the relics and pointing out the graves of saints and Kings, also refers to the interment, some sixteen or seventeen years ago, of 19 American seamen,

WASHINGTON, June 8, 1882. The President has not yet determined upon the membership of the commission provided for in the Geneva Award bill. Judge Wells, of Michigan, a member of the former commission, and Mr. Charles, R. Train, of Massachusetts, are being strongly urged for appointment.
The American Medical Association, now holding its annual meeting at St. Paul, Minn., is supposed to represent all the socalled regular physicians of the United States.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 8.--The union effected by the iron manufacturers at their long secret session yesterday is, strange as it may appear, looked upon as a step in the right direction by the officers and leaders of the Amalgamated Association.
Upon the result of the election for members of the Legislature in Oregon was staked the sole hope of the Democrats of holding the United States Senate after March 4, 1883.

LONDON, June 8.--Debate on the Repression bill was resumed in the House of Commons this evening. Mr. Charles Russell's amendment, defining intimidation as threats, or acts of violence to person or property, or incitement thereto, was rejected by a vote of 45 to 266.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 8.--The postponed examination of R. Porter Lee, late President of the suspended First National Bank, on the charge of embezzling funds of the bank, and Herman J. Hall, as accessory thereto, brought by Robert H. Stevens, one of the depositors, was held this afternoon. No additional facts of interest were elicited.

The first silk-rearing exhibition ever held in the United States was opened yesterday in Turn Hall, under the auspices of the North American Silk Exchange. The exhibits thus far received were arranged on long tables in the centre of the hall, and here the visitor was shown the process of silk-making as carried on by the silk-work.

When the modified code of medical ethics was adopted by the State Medical Society in February last it was predicted that the section permitting regular practitioners to consult with legally qualified physicians of the homeopathic school would result in the exclusion of the New-York delegates from the American Medical Association,

The fourth day of the meeting of the American Jockey Club cannot be recorded as a success, for although there was a fair attendance of spectators, the two great events of the day were failures, as Forester galloped away from his competitors in the Belmont Stakes and Thora had merely a walkover in the Westchester Cup, the broken-down...
We regret to notice indications that the nominations to the Tariff Commission are not received with that perfect accord among the supporters of the measure which was to have been expected.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--The examination of witnesses in the star route case began today, but, until afternoon the prominent features of the day's session were Judge Wylie's remarks about the jury and Judge McSweeny's...
WASHINGTON, June 8.--The Finance Committee of the Senate this morning considered and reported for confirmation the Tariff Commission nominated yesterday by the President.

LONDON, May 23.--While in Manchester about a week ago I took occasion personally to examine the actual condition of affairs regarding the cotton frauds alleged to have been committed by American sellers, for since Manchester and the surrounding towns make up one of the largest cotton-consuming districts...

CHICAGO, June 8.--Mr. Underwood, the Dixon miller, who paid 142 in this market recently for wheat to grind, is not quite so much of a bull as he was then. He has just returned from a trip through Southern Illinois and gives a glowing account of the Winter wheat prospects.
Mr. Moncure D. Conway contributes to Harper's Weekly an interesting article upon Emerson in England, which includes the following beautiful letter from Mr. Emerson to Mr. Carlyle:

WASHINGTON, June 8.--The Windom Committee commenced this morning its investigation of the charges of corruption in connection with the passage through the House of the Bonded Spirits bill. Hawthorne Hill, of the Louisville Courier; A.C. Buell, of the Washington Critic, and...

The Detroit nine, who hold second place thus far in the race for the championship of the league, were the opponents of the Metropolitans yesterday on the Polo Grounds. This was the first appearance of the Michigan men in this City this season, and the base-ball goers turned out in full force to witness the game of this club, which has defeated the best nines in the country.

The Republicans of Ohio who met in convention at Columbus on Wednesday had a rather delicate task to perform. The administration of Gov. FOSTER has been highly creditable, and on general grounds there was little cause for dissatisfaction or division in the party.

LA CROSSE, Wis., June 8.--The Republican and Leader has reports to-day from La Crosse, Vernon, Monroe, Trempealeau, and Buffalo Counties, giving a statement of the condition of the crops and an estimate of the probable yield of the coming harvest, which is unusually late.
A special meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration was held yesterday afternoon to consider the recent cases of ill-treatment to passengers on steamers of the Royal Netherland Steamship Line.
The fourth annual excursion given by the Hon. John H. Starin to the Grand Army of the Republic and the veterans of the Army and Navy took place yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9.--Very little progress was made by the Government in the star route trials to-day. Mr. Merrick undertook to introduce the confession of Rerdell, and failed. Rerdell is one of the defendants, and the story of his confession was told on the witness stand a few weeks ago in the Police Court by exAttorney-General MacVeagh, ex-PostmasterGeneral James, and Inspector Woodward.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 9.--The American Medical Association adjourned at noon. The closing session was largely devoted to routine business. The following officers were elected: President--Dr. J.L. Atlee, of Pennsylvania; Vice-Presidents--Dr. Eugene Grisson, of North Carolina: Dr. A.J. Stone, of Minnesota;

POWHATAN, Va., June 9.--Armistead Gray, colored, was hanged at noon to-day at Powhatan Court-house, for the murder of Lincoln Gray, his own son, a lad of 14 years. The hanging was entirely private, in accordance with the State law, the only persons present being the court officers, physicians, and two representatives of the press.
WASHINGTON, June 9.--First Lieut. William E. Birkhimer, Third Artillery, has been relieved from duty in the Signal Service and will join his battery.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9.--The ceremonies of the day began at 9 o'clock with the arrival of Secretary Chandler and Gov. Blossom, of Florida. They were received at the Naval Academy by the officers, the marines, and a salute of 18 guns from the United States ship Santee. At 10:30 the battalion of Cadets formed and marched in squads to the chapel.

The eighth annual regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association was rowed yesterday over a mile course on the Harlem River. That part of the river between Third-avenue and Macomb's Dam presented quite a holiday appearance.
LONDON, June 9.--Mr. Bourke, who was assassinated at Ardrahan yesterday, recently informed the authorities that he knew he would be shot.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 9.--A special from Perham, Minn., to the Pioneer Press, says: "John Tribbetts, the boy murderer, was brought to Perham yesterday morning. He was taken off the train at Frazer and brought the remainder of the distance by carriage.

CHICAGO, June. 9.--The Tribune's special from Springfield gives advance sheets of crop reports prepared by the Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture. The showing as to Winter wheat gives promise of an exceptionally large yield. The army-worm has stripped off the blades in some of the southern counties, but no reduction of yield is anticipated by wheat-growers who have had experience with this insect.

WASHINGTON, June 9.--"Get all you can, and keep all you can get," ought, if one may judge from Mr. Sherman's argument in the Senate to-day, to be the motto which the United States Government should stitch upon its flag. It does not seem altogether unnatural

WEST POINT, June 9.--Taps did not send the Cadets to bed to-night. The strict military discipline was unbent, and the young men were permitted to plunge into a mad whirl of pleasure which was incompatible with the rules of the post. West Point presented a scene such as is seen only once a year.

The appearance of Mr. Bancroft's two volumes upon the Constitution of the United States, some extracts from which we have a few weeks ago, map be considered in some respects a notable event in American literature.
MADDALENA, June 9.--The family of Garibaldi will leave Caprera soon to reside on the mainland.

The death Of GARIBALDI will prove an irreparable blow to the Italian republicans. Although he was absolutely incompetent as a political leader, his name was a tower of strength, and the fact that GARIBALDI called himself a republican was an argument which brought many recruits to the "League of the Democracy."
WASHINGTON, June 9.--The debate upon the provisions of the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill has shed some light on the pension question.

Five or six gentlemen are now on trial in Washington for conspiring to defraud the Government. It is charged that these eminent persons, by various devices, procured augmentation of mail service over many lines of transportation, and that said increase of service was uncalled for, and that the work was not done in many cases.

It is unfortunate that the muddle which the Legislature made with the Railroad Commission bill left it in the Governor's hands in such a shape that it is vulnerable to the attacks of the enemies of regulation in any form. There are features in the measure

CAIRO, June 9.--The Government has deferred the payment of half of the land tax, so that the fellaheen will not be forced to sell their crops when all the Europeans have left and the banks have refused to give credit because of the insecurity prevailing.

One of the most numerous and distinguished audiences ever assembled at a concert was present last night at the Academy of Music to hear Mme. Materna. It is a matter of local musical history that at the late unfortunate Musical Festival this eminent artist disappointed the public.

The steam-ships Britannic, of the White Star Line; England, of the National Line; Mosel, of the North German Lloyd; City of Montreal, of the Inman Line; Rhynland, of the Red Star Line; and Anchoria, of the Anchor Line, will sail for Europe today with full passenger lists.

John Carlson, of No. 212 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, entered Rushton's drug store, in Sixth-avenue, on Thursday evening, to make some purchases. On turning to pay for the articles he had bought, be discovered that his purse, containing $3, which he alloyed he had laid down on the counter of the store, was missing.
Francis Mangin, Jr., was yesterday appointed a Detective Sergeant under Inspector Byrnes. Mr. Ralph Wells will deliver an address in DeWitt Memorial Church to-morrow evening.

An anecdote of Bismarck that is 30 years old has come to light in Germany in a new book on "Prussia at the Diet." Bismarck, in 1853, was sent to Darmstadt to smooth over certain differences that had arisen in the Diet between Prussia and that State.
ST. LOUIS, June 9.--There was a large concourse of spectators on the grounds of the St. Louis Jocey Club to-day. The weather was warm and the track was very dusty. The betting was brisk.

LONDON, May 24.--Associated with our modern isthmian games, the famous race which the Duke of Westmoreland's Shotover has won to-day, with Mr. Lorillard's Saehem at his heels, will be remembered in history as one of the two occasions during 36 years when Parliament did not adjourn.

CHICAGO, June 9.--There was something very like a panic in corn to-day on 'Change under the belief that there is a great deal of corn back in first hands, and that there was never before so large an area planted in corn as now, and that it never looked better. SAN FRANCISCO, June 9.--A dispatch from San Jose says: "Mrs. Guadalupe Flores was assassinated on the street at Los Gatos last night. Her former husband, John Warsly, recently released from the penitentiary, it is supposed murdered her in revenge for her having obtained a divorce and remarried during his incarceration."

PITTSBURG, June 9.--There is nothing new to report in iron circles to-day. An unusual quietness prevailed in all circles. New developments are loosed for next week, it being rumored that two or three mills will endeavor to start with nonunion men.

CHICAGO, June 10.--There was an accumulation of tragic horrors to-day in Chicago, including a murder and suicide, the discovery of two bodies in the river, and the fall of a woman from the window of a building. Mary Seyboldt, 85 years old, wife of Casper seyboldt, a baker, murdered her four children this morning and then committed suicide.
ST. LOUIS, June 10.--The St. Louis Jockey Club continued its meeting to-day. The attendance was large, the weather warm, and the track in excellent condition. The betting was heavy.

CHICAGO, June 10.--John Medairy, a bookkeeper in the employ of the Traders' Bank, stole a box containing about $800 from that institution Thursday night and now languishes in jail. The twenty-third annual regatta of the Alcyone Boat Club was rowed yesterday afternoon at Bay Ridge. BOSTON, June 11.--The circular from Washington on behalf of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee assessing prorata amounts for the Autumn campaign, which each of the 700 employes of the navy-yard has received, excites much comment in the yard and outside. DUBLIN, June 11.--The Irish Bishops have issued an important address to their flocks, promising the support or the clergy to the people in peacefully agitating for their rights, but condemning as the worst enemies to the country men who recommend illegal courses, particularly those belonging to secret societies. The Bishops, in their address, point out that what is morally wrong cannot be politically right.

VIRGINIA, Nev., June 3.--All the men who were imprisoned in the Alta drift, and who were safely brought to surface at midnight last night, are doing well and feeling well to-day. They say they did not suffer from hunger, though they were 65 hours without food. What they most wanted was ice. They had plenty of drinkable water, but a fever of the stomach made them wild for ice.

The Trustees of the East River bridge met yesterday, with President Henry C. Murphy in the chair. He announced that the annual election for Preside and and Vice-President was in order, and requested Controller Allan Campbell, of this City, to preside.

ROCKHILL, S.C., June 12.--At about 1 o'clock this morning the negro John Johnson, who so brutishly outraged the person of the little white girl, Alice McDowell, yesterday morning, was taken from the guard-house by a crowd of about 100 masked men, and hanged to the limb of a tree on Main-street, about 40 feet from Robertson's Hotel.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 12.--The iron situation developed nothing of importance to-day, and quiet reigned supreme at the head-quarters of both the manufacturers and workmen. President Jarrett, of the Amalgamated Association, who is in St. Louis, was heard from to-day.

--"Singleheart and Doubleface" is the title of Mr. Charles Reade's new novel. --M. Louis Blanc is said to be engaged in preparing a complete edition of his works. --An effort is being made to get a bust of Robert Burns placed in Westminster Abbey.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--It is expected that nominations to fill the vacancies in the Tariff Commission will be agreed upon in Cabinet meeting to-morrow. Among those mentioned as candidates for Mr. Wheele's place is Mr. Samuel Haines, of the firm of Graham Haines, hardware merchants, of New-York.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 12.--A peculiar accident happened this morning in saw mill in North St. Louis. A five-foot circular saw burst with an explosive noise, and one of the pieces struck a workman named Joseph Spelman on the back part of his head, completely severing the right side of his skull and laying bare the brain.

LONDON, June 12.--In the House of Lords this afternoon Lord Dalhousie moved the second reading, of the bill legalizing marriage with a deceased wife's sister. The House, however, by a vote of 128 to 132, refused to order such action.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 12.--To-day's races were poorly attended, owing to threatening rain, and the betting was light. The track was in fair shape. The first race was for a purse of $250, for all ages; $50 to the second; three-quarters of a mile.

CAIRO, June 13.--According to the engagement between the foreign Consuls, Dervisch Pasha, the Khedive, and Arabi Pasha, by which the Khedive undertakes to maintain order, Arabi Pasha strictly obeying his commands, Arabi Pasha also undertakes to stop seditious meetings and preachings and the hostility of the native press. The arrangement is generally regarded as rendering Arabi Pasha master of the situation.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 13.--The Empress was safely delivered of a daughter at 8 o'clock this morning. The child will be named Olga. The public buildings are decorated with flags in honor of the event.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 13.--The strikers, seeing defeat inevitable and crowing alarmed over the coming result, are growing desperate. Over 1,200 men were at work in the rolling mills to-day. MONTREAL, June 14.--The steam-ship Pera, from this port for Great Britain, has foundered off Cape Race. The steam-ship Lake Manitoba, which has passed Father Point inward, has on board the Captain, officers, engineer, and part of the crew of the Pera, who were picked up in two boats. The other boats of the Pera have not yet been heard from.

LOUISVIILE, Ky., June 14.--Memories of the ante-bellum days were recalled in a vivid manner to-day, in this city, by the sale into slavery for one year of John Hanson. John is, as the advertisement posted on the Court-house door states, "an able-bodied man of color, about 40 years of age, sound in every respect, with the exception of a rheumatic trouble of the lower limbs."
President Berk A. Hinsdale has accepted the position of Superintendent of Instruction in Cleveland, Ohio.

BOSTON, June 14.--The New-Hampshire Club held its annual dinner at the Revere House this afternoon. There were 260 gentlemen present, many of whom are residents of New-Hampshire, and others who, although citizens of Boston, claim New-Hampshire as the place of their nativity. Among the prominent guests of the club were Secretary of the Navy Chandler, Senator Frye, of Maine; Collector Worthington, of Boston, and Gen. N.P. Banks, all of whom spoke on national affairs.

ALEXANDRIA, June 14.--The bodies of the engineer of the British iron-clad Superb and the two seamen of the Helicon, who were killed in the riot on Sunday, have been buried at sea, as it was deemed imprudent to risk the danger that might have arisen from a funeral on shore. INDIANAPOLIS, June 14.--The most terrible calamity that has befallen this city for years was the sudden and disastrous flood of this morning. WASHINGTON, June 15.--Among the reports recently received by the State Department is one from our Consul at Auckland about the rabbit skin trade of New-Zealand. Its relation to commerce with this country is remote, but the facts are interesting. CLEVELAND, June 23.--At 6:20 this morning, without a moment's warning, a mighty wave, 12 feet high, and traveling with wonderful velocity, struck the south shore of Lake Erie. The auction of the numismatical collection of the late Charles L. Bushnell, which was begun on Tuesday, at the rooms of Messrs Bangs Co., was continued yesterday, the sales of the day amounting to $1,649. LONG BRANCH, June 24.--Long Branch, the belle of the beach, is now potting the last touches to her elaborate toilet, and in a few days will be ready for the Summer's campaign. WASHINGTON, June 24.--The intimation conveyed in THE TIMES'S dispatch of last night that the Attorney-General would to-day refuse to grant any of the requests made on Guiteau's behalf was justified by the official announcement from the mouth of the Attorney-General at 10 o'clock this morning that the Cabinet had last night decided not to interfere with the execution of the sentence of the court.

WASHINGTON, June 25.--The weather was very sultry in this city on Saturday, and the largest audience of the season gathered on the lawns behind the White House to listen to the usual concert by the Marine Band and to enjoy the breeze that swept up from the Potomac.

A report has been circulating in the Cuban colony of the City for the past week to the effect that Seflor Criado, the Cuban patriot, and a gentleman of wealth, had left a large sum of money to found a Cuban college in this City. Seflor Criado was a prominent revolutionist, and he died a few weeks ago in Havana.

WASHINGTON, June 25.--The report of the Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy at Annapolis, after stating the organization of the board with Commodore Samuel R. Franklin as President, expresses the high estimate in which the visitors hold the value of the institution to the country.

In London has been founded a national society for the suppression of juvenile smoking. One of the leaders in the movement is the eminent teetotaler, Dr. Benjamin Ward Richardson. Letters in approval of the society's aims were read from the Earl of Aberdeen, Mr. Samuel Morley, and others.
MADRID, June 25.--The Official Gazette publishes a bill introduced by Sefior Camacho, Minister of Finance, reducing import duties on coal, cotton, leather, and other raw material.

ALGONA, Iowa, June 25.--Twenty houses were demolished and 5 persons were killed and 25 injured in the southern part of Clay County by the hurricane yesterday. In Emmetsburg five houses were blown down and other damage was done.

"Let us unite in prayer," said the Rev. C.H. Taylor, D.D., Pastor of the Hobart-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, as he and seven others emerged from the auditorium into the lecture room of the First Presbyterian Church at South Fourth and Sixth streets, Brooklyn, Easters District, last night.

The funeral of the late Edmund Benjamin, the unfortunate young oarsman who was drowned in New-London, Conn., last Friday, took place from the residence of his parents, No. 43 East Sixty-seventh-street yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--Mr. Pendleton spoke to-day in the Senate at great length and with more or less of his characteristic eloquence in favor of civil service reform, as taught by, and as he pretends it has been truly exemplified by, the Democratic Party.

WICHITA, Kan., June 26.-Two-thirds of the 100,000 acres of wheat in this county have been out and is now in shock. The average yield will be unprecedentedly large and of the finest quality. The farmers declare that they never saw such fine grain.

LONDON, June 26.--A memorial has been presented to Lord Granville, Foreign Secretary, signed by 44 members of Parliament, praying that the British representatives be instructed to press the suppression of the slave trade as one of the objects of the conference at Constantinople.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--Guiteau's death warrant was signed by Clerk Meigs, of the Criminal Court, this morning, the seal of the court attached, and the document immediately sent to Wardon Crocker, at the District jail. The men who load and unload freight for the railroad companies whose lines terminate here have shown their power over the commercial interests of the City. They could not have done this unless their demands had been substantially just.

BOSTON, June 26.--The bark Wild Hunter, Capt. Treat, from Savannah, via Boston, for Re val, has been burned at sea, 90 miles past of Sambro, Nova Scotia. The crew were saved, by the American fishing schooner Colorado, and arrived at Halifax this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 26, 1882. In the Senate to-day the House concurrent resolution for final adjournment on July 10 was tabled temporarily without dissent.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--An Army retiring board having found Lieut.-Col. Robert S. Williamson, Corps of Engineers, incapacitated for active services on account of disability incident to the service, he has, by direction of the President, been retired from active service.

Aldermen Brady, Wells, and Strack, of the Common Council Railroad Committee, listened to arguments in favor of and against the building of a railroad over the route proposed by the Suburban Rapid Transit Company.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--Mr. Ingersoll resumed the cross-examination of the sub-contractor Anthony Joseph, in the star route trials, before the Criminal Court this morning. Several letters from the sub-contractor to the Dorseys were read by Mr. Ingersoll.

The Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy at Annapolis has made the interesting discovery that the buildings in which the Superintendent and the Cadets are quartered are in such an unsafe condition that they are liable to fall at any time.

ST. PAUL. Minn., June 26.--It was impossible to get particulars of the accident on the Manitoba Railway Line from Wilmar or Atwater up to 1 o'clock this morning. It was learned at the dispatcher's office of the Manitoba Railway last evening that three of the wounded men had died during the day at Wilmar.
CHICAGO, June 26.--The Chicago Driving Park Association began its running meeting today. Saturday had been fixed upon as the opening day, but a rain-storm necessitated a postponement.

CHICAGO, June 26.--Both cereals and provisions went booming upward on 'Change to-day. The continued storms have been very bad for grain. Washouts on the railroads have diminished receipts both of hogs and breadstuffs, and all this comes upon stocks reduced to very near the minimum point.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26.--About half the miners in the Clearfield region are on strike to-day, six mines being idle in the vicinity of Houtzdale and four near Phillipsburg. A complete suspension or a resumption of work will, it is thought, be decided on in a few days.

All the approaches to the railroads in Jersey City yesterday were picketed with policemen. The picket guards were instructed the moment the advance guard of freight-handlers showed themselves in any neighborhood to report the fact to Police Head-quarters.

As the Army Appropriation bill went to the Senate it provided that in computing the length of service which entitles an officer to additional pay the time of his service on the retired list shall not be reckoned in.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 26.--The meeting of the State Republican Central Committee in this city on Friday last brought many representative Republicans together, and from some members of that body information has been obtained in confirmation of previous dispatches to THE TIMES regarding the political outlook in Ohio.

In the Supreme Court, Circuit, Brooklyn, the suit of the Board of Education against Alderman Harry O. Jones, of that city, to recover $250,000, set down peremptorily for yesterday, was called soon after the court opened. Mr. DeWitt, for the plaintiff, answered "ready." The defendant was not represented by counsel.

NEW-HAVEN, June 26.--The number of strangers in New-Haven to-day to attend the opening exercises of Commencement at Yale College was not large, but many arrivals are expected in season for the meeting of the Alumni to-morrow morning.

Secretary Jackson, of the Board of Emigration, has received a communication from M.A. Kursheedt, the Managing Secretary of the Hebrew Emigrant Aid Society, stating that "he was instructed to inform the Emigration Commission that this society will not take charge of any Russian refugees or other Jewish immigrants who may hereafter arrive in this city."

WASHINGTON, June 26.--The Navy Department is in receipt of advices from Engineer George W. Melville, dated Lena Delta, March 25, 1882, in which he gives a detailed account of his operations up to that date, and full particulars of the finding of the remains of De Long and his comrades.

There was a long and interesting discussion at the meeting of the County Medical Society last evening, in which Prof. Jacobi, Dr. E.G. Rawson, Dr. Carpenter, the Secretary of the society, and Prof. F.R. Sturgis, its President, participated.

SCHENECTADY, June 26.--Quiet and hard work has been done today by the parties immediately interested in the bitter struggle now going on between the Faculty and President Potter for the control of Union College. The annual meetings of the Board of Trustees and the Alumni Association take place to-morrow forenoon, and as the battle is to be fought at these meetings this has been the last day for preparation.
With four political parties in the field, Tennessee threatens to rival Maine. A half-dozen or more of the "war Governors" still survive to rejoice in the restored Union.

ALEXANDRIA, June 26.--An uneasy feeling continues to prevail along the Suez Canal. It is rumored that a number of cases containing explosives, accompanied by men in uniform, have arrived at Ismaila, and have been deposited in unoccupied public buildings, under the supervision of the Governor.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--The House yesterday, after some time had been devoted to District of Columbia business, went into Committee of the Whole, Mr. Camp, of New-York, in the chair, on the bill to reduce internal revenue taxes.

LEWISTON, Me., June 26.--Delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which will be held in this city to-morrow, are arriving in considerable numbers. The prospect is that the more distant parts of the State will not be represented.

OMAHA, June 26.--Telegraphic communication having been re-established to-day over the wires prostrated by the storm on Saturday night and Sunday forenoon, the full extent of the damage from hail and wind has been ascertained.

LONDON, June 27.--The Daily News says an examination of the weapons left behind by the murderers of Mr. Bourke and the trooper Wallace, near Ardraban, Ireland, on June 8, shows that they bear the same private marks as are borne by the rifles seized at Clerkenwell.

NEW-HAVEN, June 27.--In the Malley trial this afternoon State Attorney Doolittle announced that the prosecution had closed its case. Mr. Jones, of counsel for the defense, stated that the defense had nothing further to offer, and then proposed to submit the case to the jury without argument, this being done with Blanche Douglass's consent.

The Cotton-seed Crushers' Association, an organization whose membership comprises most of the larger cotton-crushing concerns of the South and West, held the first session of their annual convention in the Directors' room of the equitable Insurance Building, in Broadway, yesterday.

In 1880, the first year in which Gov. CORNELL had an opportunity to apply the pruning-knife to the extravagant appropriations of the Legislature for alleged deficiencies which are massed together in what is known as the Supply bill, that measure came to him with items aggregating more than $1,500,000.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--In the Senate today Mr. Morrill, from the Finance Committee, reported a bill to further regulate the investment of the Pacific Railroad sinking fund, and gave notice that he would call it up tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--Guiteau retired last night at his usual time, about 8:30 or 9. He slept well and appeared much refreshed this morning. He ate heartily at breakfast and was cheerful and less taciturn than usual. After breakfast, he took about a half-hour's exercise in the corridor in front of his cell, mostly a slow walk.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--The House to-day resumed the consideration of the Internal Revenue bill. Mr. Springer moved to recommit the bill, with instructions to the Committee on Ways and Means to report back a bill abolishing all internal revenue taxes except those on bank circulation and distilled spirits.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 28.--Crop reports from a wide region of country to the Pioneer-Press indicate that the anxiety felt for the growing grain on account of the storms of last week was premature, if not absolutely without foundation.

WASHINGTON, June 28.--Major Israel O. Dewey, Paymaster, has been relieved from duty in the Department of Texas and ordered to Detroit, Mich. He will relieve Major Edmund H. Brooke, Paymaster at that place, and will report by letter to the commanding General, Department of the East.

Probably no boy in all New-York was ever more astonished than was "Jake" Dushki, a young Polish match-peddler, about the hour of 5 yesterday afternoon. Jake is a Forsyth-street gamin. His stock in trade, as he was stealing a ride on the rear platform of a bobtail car at the hour named, was 11 boxes of matches. He valued the matches at 10 cents a box.

The Governors of the Stock Exchange held their last regular meeting for the Summer months yesterday. A few securities were listed, and there was a discussion of a new phase assumed by the long-pending elevated railway controversy, Jay Gould and his confreres having taken further steps in their efforts to impose upon Metropolitan shareholders.

EASTON, Penn., June 28.--The Commencement exercises at Lafayette College closed to-day with the orations by the graduating class. The exercises were held in the open air on the Campus in front of the old college building.

The long line of freight-laden trucks which have been seeking access to the pier and bulkhead of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, at the foot of Chambers-street, since Monday was completely broken yesterday. Inasmuch as yesterday was not a legal holiday the general suspension of business in the City was remarkable. When the leading dry goods men started the movement to give their employes a two days' holiday, extending over the Fourth of July, it was hardly expected that trades-people generally would give it support.

PANAMA, June 24.--The Chilian President's Message has been well received in that country. It is thought to indicate a decided wish on his part that the occupation of Pern should cease directly any Government can be formed promising to possess more stability than Montero can boast.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--There was no formal celebration of the national holiday in this city beyond the firing of salutes, the general hanging out of flags, and the suspension of business. Egypt, Tunis, Algeria, Morocco, are shaking with the same convulsion which has stirred Persia and Afghanistan.

A cream-colored high hat was the badge of office of the Chairman of the Tammany Society's meeting to celebrate the one hundred and sixth anniversary of American independence. It was worn with much dignity by the veteran Charles S. Haswell. Grand Sachem Augustus Schell was not present, so Mr. Haswell, as the Fatger of the Council, took his place.

The rain drizzled drearily down on the grounds of the Williamsburg Athletic Club at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the track was damp and heavy. The programme of sports which has been prepared by the club, however, was carried out to the letter. The number of spectators was not large. The first event was a 100 yards' run, handicapped, for which there were a dozen entries or more.

Mr. John Lord Mitchell, one of the victims of the recent disaster on the New-Jersey Central Railroad at Parker's Creek, died between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday at No. 34 West Twenty-fourthstreet. The Yale College nine, the champions of the American College Association, played a game of base-ball with the Metropolitan Club in a drizzling rain on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of between 400 and 500 persons. Notwithstanding the disagreeable weather both teams played a splendid game in the field.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--The star route trial will not be resumed until Thursday morning, just five weeks from the day when it began. About two-thirds of the record evidence and testimony relating to the routes named in the indictment have been put in by the prosecution.

LONDON, July 4.--The Press Association reports that there is reason to believe that decisive military action will be taken in Egypt, probably within 24 hours. The Cabinet met in Sir William Harcourt's room in the House of Commons this afternoon and consulted with the Duke of Cambridge, Commander-inChief of the Army. It is rumored in the lobby of the House that Alexandria will be immediately bombarded.

These three volumes complete the series of neat, handy, and attractive commentaries on the books of the Old and New Testaments. The carefully arranged notes extend over a wide range of exegesis and illustration, and contain numerous citations from eminent scholars and homilists.

The Fourth of July regatta of the Palisade Boat Club, of Yonkers, took place yesterday morning on the Hudson over the club's one-mile course, which extends from the club-house to the dock at the foot of Ludlow-street. Yonkers.

The most prominent figure at the dinner given by the Lelands to the Veterans of 1812 at the Sturtevant House, yesterday, was that of the Hon. Thurlow Weed, the veteran editor and statesman. Mr. Weed reached the Sturtevant House about half an hour in advance of the other veterans, and was led to the parlor by Mr. Jerome Leland.

BUFFALO, July 4.--The ceremonies of the city's semi-centennial anniversary to-day drew from the neighboring cities and the country around here a very large number of sight-seers. The procession, which was several miles in length, was advertised to start at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

They were of the class who were bound to go to the island, rain or shine, and generally they came prepared with rubber coats and cloaks and umbrellas.

WALNUT HILLS, CINCINNATI, June 30.--This picturesque suburb is a historic place, and some of the ancient dwellers have made it famous. Time was, not so very long since, when the roads were horrible, and the way up the hillside something to keep brisk people out of the neighborhood.
CHICAGO, July 4.--The race-track was slow and slippery. There was a high, chilly wind blowing. The attendance was fair and the betting heavy. The judges and starter were the same as yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 4.--Fresh arrests have been made during the past few days. Among those arrested are two Uhlan officers, who were found distributing revolutionary proclamations. One account says these officers were among those specially charged to protect the Emperor.

The cricketers of the Staten Island Club had an enjoyable celebration of the holiday yesterday. LAKE GEORGE, July 4.--The inter-collegiate race is over. During the morning the lake was perfectly smooth, but at 4:30 o'clock, when the crews were preparing to go to the start, a south wind suddenly arose, and Referee Garfield announced a postponement of the race. Within 15 minutes the wind died away and the crews were ordered to row.

DUBLIN, July 4.--A man was shot dead early this morning in Seville-place. It is supposed that he was killed by Fenians. A person passing at the time noticed three men apparently disputing with each other. Pistolshots were heard. One of the men fell and the others ran away.

Connor, Samuel Sloan, Sidney Dillon, Jose F. De Navarro, Grenville M. Dodge, and Cyrus W. Field from their positions as Directors of the Metropolitan Company.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--Three physicians, Drs. Lamb, Hartigan, and Sowers were selected to conduct the autopsy upon the body of Guiteau by the group of physicians summoned or invited to be present. Dr. Lamb, the surgeon connected with the Medical Museum, who operated at the autopsy in Elberon, did the work in this case. All took notes.

These military days recall to the old settlers the first days of glorious war in this place, now just 50 years ago. The great chief of the Sacs and Foxes, Black Hawk, threatened our North-western frontier settlements, and there was universal dread that he might overrun them and then destroy us. So Gov. LONDON, July 5.--A correspondent at St. Peterburg says that, according to good information, Dr. Weimar, who was sentenced to exile in Siberia, is still in the Fortress of St. Peter and St. Paul. The authorities lately have shown much anxiety as to the safety of the ground underneath the fortress and the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul, in which are the tombs of the Czars.

CHICAGO, July 5.--A Tribune special from McLeansboro, Ill., says: "Wheat is about all harvested in Hamilton County. The acreage was not so large as in former years, but the yield was much better, averaging about 15 bushels to the acre. Oats are in fine condition, acreage larger than usual, and the yield will be 35 to 40 bushels per acre.

A meeting of the cap-finishers was held last eveninag at No. 116 Eldridge-street, for the purpose of devising measures to secure an increase in their wages. Up to the middle of last Summer good capfinishers were earning from $18 to $20 per week. About that time, however, wages gradually began to fall until they are now less than half the former rates.

State Controller Ira L. Davenport was one of the passengers of the Bothnia, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday morning. He has been in delicate health for some months, and at one time during the past Winter his system became so enfeebled that he was obliged to abandon Albany, with its dry, bracing atmosphere, and seek the milder climate of Virginia.

Signor Mario is reported to have quite recovered from his serious illness and to be looking very handsome. His hair and beared are white, his complexion is roseate, and his eyes are as dark and piercing as ever. All his English friends have been extremely kind to him throughout his illnes. He has returned to his favorite pastime of using the tools of a carpenter, and making various articles as his fancy prompted.

RED BANK, N.J., July 5.--The first annual regatta of the Nameless Yacht Club, under the rules of the New-York Yacht Club, was held today, and was the cause of much enthusiasm on the part of the club in spite of the rain. A number of flags were raised throughout the town in honor of the event. Nineteen yachts were entered for the race, and all presented themselves for measurement.

It was not until the year 1879 that naturalists became aware of the existence of a new species of hair-pin. Up to that time there had been but two varieties of hair-pin--the straight and the corrugated. These were of about the same size--the full-grown hair-pin attaining a length of four inches--and were found throughout Europe and America.

The first concession to the striking freight handlers was made yesterday. Thirty-four Greeks employed in the house of the New-Jersey Southern Railroad at Pier No. 8 North River, were turned away yesterday morning and the old men called bank. The company paid its hands 17 cents an hour before the strike, and the men returned on an offer of $50 a month for 10 working hours a day and 20 cents an hour for overtime.

Mail advices from Yokohama to June 13 say: The latest census gives the population of Japan as 30,358,994; males, 18,423,274; females, 17,935,720, an increase of 3,000,000 since the last previous census in 1873. This increase, however, is in part attributed to the growing accuracy in collecting returns, the earlier estimates having been too low. The population of the three principal cities is thus distributed: Tokio, 979,084; Kioto, 830,829; Osaka, 587,998.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Capt. William P. McCann has been detached from the command of the flag-ship Pensacola on the reporting of his relief, and ordered to return home; Midshipman C. O. Atwater from the Jamestown and ordered to special duty in the Bureau of Navigation; Passed Assistant Surgeon D.M. Griteras from the Naval Hospital, Philadelphia, and ordered to duty at the Naval Academy.

The representative nine of Troy was taken into camp by the Metropolitan nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of 1,500 spectators. The batting was even on both sides, each nine gaining 13 singles, with a total of 17 base hits.

Judge Cullen, sitting in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday granted judgment of foreclosure in the case of Henry M. Leverich against the Far Rockaway Branch Railroad Company. The amount is $75,000.

READING, Penn., July 10.--There is great excitement all along the Schuylkill River for a distance of over 60 miles owing to the dark greenish and soapy appearance of the water and the deposit of a white substance on the stones and grass along the banks.

VINCENNES, Ind., July 10.--A train on the Terre Haute and Evansville Railroad broke in two and caused a terrible wreck yesterday. Three men were caught between the cars and two of them killed. One was Frank Conner, of Terre Haute, Ind., and the other is supposed to be James O'Connell, of Youngstown, Ohio. Andrew McIntyre, of Vincennes, lost an arm, and will probably die.
PARIS, July 10.--The Gaulois professes to know that Gen. Skobeleff committed suicide in order to escape an exposure of his connection with the Nihilists.

CINCINNATI, July 10.--The Cincinnati Wesleyan College will, by order of the court, be sold at auction to-morrow for debt. The institution has been in existence for 40 years, and has an honorable history. It has a large body of Alumnae, prominent among whom is Mrs. R.B. Hayes.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--By a very pronounced majority the Senate to-day incorporated in the River and Harbor bill the amendment appropriating $500,000 toward the improvement of the Washington and Georgetown Harbor and the reclamation of the Potomac flats.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 10.--Intelligence has been received here of a murder committed in Mecklenburg County, the victim being the daughter of Maria Daly, (colored) who was killed by her mother. The New-Jersey Supreme Court at Trenton, Judges Depue, Van Syckle, and Reed on the bench, yesterday decided the long-continued dispute over the patronage of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders. The decision is virtually in favor of the Republicans, though its practical effect will only be to give them control of the clerkships.

CHICAGO, July 10.--The great feature of the markets to-day was a sharp advance in the longer futures on wheat. The good foreign demand for the article made operators think that futures had been discounted too much, and fears that war is actually breaking out in the Old World helped to increase the demand, especially as wheat is low compared with other grain. The receipts of wheat were larger.

The scandal caused by the imprisonment of the Rev. Mr. GREEN has at last aroused the English Bishops to action. They have brought forward a bill which provides that the Privy Council or a Judge of an ecclesiastical court may, upon the representation of the Archbishop of the Province, order the release of any clergyman imprisoned for contumacy.

CHICAGO, July 15.--The markets were very weak again to-day, but not so much so as yesterday. There had been a widespread calling of margins early in the day, and the bears were jubilant over the idea that prices were going to tumble to a very much lower point. The markets did not go exactly as they wanted them to.

The game of base-ball on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the Worcester (League) nine and the Metropolitan Club was witnessed by about 2,500 persons, and resulted in the defeat of the former by a score of 6 to 2. The League players did not do as well in fielding as the Metropolitans, and for that reason were defeated.

The employes of James McCreery Co. had their fifth annual games yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Athletic Club Grounds, at Eighthavenue and Fifty-sixth-street. LONDON, July 15.--The news from Alexandria to-day is of a more reassuring nature, and there is every prospect that within the next 24 hours perfect quiet and order will reign in what is left of the city. Admiral Seymour telegraphed at 11 o'clock last night that the great fire was no longer spreading, and that the plundering of the Bedouins and Arabs had almost ceased.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18.--Newport has long lacked suitable yacht head-quarters, and the newly organized Narragansett Yacht Club promises to supply this need.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 18.--Yesterday Dr. Miles called in Dr. Jones, of the State Board of Health; Dr. Chaille, of the National Board, and a number of other physicians to examine a corpse at Charity Hospital.

Louis Zeimer, Henry Zeimer, Samuel Zeimer, and Henry A. Thorne were yesterday arrested for conspiracy to defraud the Government. The three Zeimers are members of the firm of Zeimer Feldstein, ...

The Union-Square Theatre Company will leave New-York for San Francisco on the 25th inst. Messrs. Benham and Scanlon's Miniature Ideal Opera Company will present "Patience," performed by 80 young persons, at Wallack's Theatre on July 31. This performance was given with success in Boston.

The Board of Trustees of the Actors' Fund of America held another meeting at Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon to receive a proposed code of by-laws. Lester Wallack presided, and Manager Daniel Frohman was Secretary.

SARATOGA, July 18.--This is the fourth of the regular days' racing. The weather is bright and moderately warm. The attendance is good, the track fast, and the betting fairly active. Officers of the day: Judges--Col. R.W. Simmons, W. J. Montague, H. Shepworth, Gordon C. Fellowes; Starter--Major Wynn; Secretary--Charles Wheatley; Timers--J.H. Smith and P.J. Duryea.

LONDON, July 18.--Order is now being rapidly restored in Alexandria, through the measures taken by Admiral Seymour. Last night was a quiet one comparatively.
A prisoner giving the name of Harry Smith was arraigned by Assistant District Attorney O'Byrne, in General Sessions, yesterday, on a charge of obtaining goods by false pretenses.

MONTREAL, July 18.--Last night a 2-yearold child of Melvin Smith, a wealthy gentleman of this city, was abducted. Mr. Smith was away from home in the early part of the evening, and on his return was met by a friend who told him his little boy was ill.

As announced some time ago in THE TIMES, the commercial organizations of the City have banded together to further means looking to the adoption at the polls this Fall of the constitutional amendments making the State canals free of tolls.

The excursion steamer Plymouth Rock had another collision while proceeding to Rockaway Beach yesterday afternoon. This time she was struck by a schooner which was sailing close to the wind, and across the bows of which she was attempting to steam. The Plymouth Rock sustained some injuries, but was able to proceed to Rockaway, white the schooner was obliged to put back for repairs.

CHICAGO, July 19.--There was hardly so much doing on 'Change to-day, though grain was active and there was a moderate volume of trading in provisions. Prices were unsteady, but there was some reaction from previous weakness, and the tone was comparatively steady.

A mass-meeting, called by the Central Labor Union, to express sympathy for the striking freight handlers, was held on the plaza in Union-square last evening. At the centre of the plaza, directly in front of the cottage, a platform for the use of the English speakers was built. Provision was made for the speakers in ...

WASHINGTON, July 19.--One contested election case was disposed of in the House today, after several hours of tedious, discordant wrangling and confusion, and another was put fairly under way and will doubtless be disposed of to-morrow. Mr. Tillman, of South Carolina, who held his seat on the ...
ATLANTA, July 19.--The Democratic State Convention met in this city at noon with a full list of delegates, save from two counties. It was organized without difficulty.

CONCORD, July 17.--There was an unwanted scene in this quiet village this morning. The fourth session of the School of Philosophy was announced to begin at 9 o'clock, and long before that hour you could see quiet and thoughtful people wending their way by Mr. Emerson's home to the Hillside Chapel, which stands within the inclosure of Mr. Alcots's former home, the Orchard House.

LONDON, July 19.--Dispatches received from Egypt to-day give little bearing upon coming movements. As an indication that the emergency, as far as regards a demand upon the navy, has passed over, it is stated that the ships of the reserve squadron have been ordered to return to their several stations.

In accordance with Mayor Low's resolution providing for a weekly report of the progress made with the bullding of the East River bridge, the following was sent yesterday by President Henry C. Murphy to the Mayors of both cities:

Coroner Merkle yesterday concluded his investigation of the Gutermuth murder mystery without having solved it. In resuming the hearing he took occasion to refer to some of the lax methods of the Police which had been brought to public attention during the inquest.

BOSTON, July 19.--The Republican State Committee meets next Saturday to arrange for the State Convention, and with this meeting the political campaign, so far as the Republicans, at least, are concerned, is generally understood to formally open. But, in fact, it has been open for some time.

GALVESTON, July 19.--The Democratic State Convention reassembled at 10:45 o'clock this morning. The contesting delegation from Dallas County was admitted on equal representation on the floor. Judge John Hancock, of Travis County, was elected permanent Chairman, with a Vice-President from each ...

NEWPORT, July 19.--This afternoon's polo games in point of spirit and good playing were a decided improvement over Saturday's, though the small number of riders--four-gave opportunity for only individual plays. J.O. Greene, of NewYork, very acceptably fulfilled the duties of umpire, and the contestants were thus divided:

The information called for by the Secretary of the ...

PITTSBURG, July 19.--There is nothing new in the iron strike to-day. A number of strikers have accepted situations tendered them by a Colorado iron firm, and will start in a few days for their new homes. The firm had no difficulty in getting all the hands needed, as the men manifested considerable eagerness to try the West.

The House yesterday disposed of the contest of SMALL versus TILLMAN in the Fifth District of South Carolina. SMALLS was seated by a strict party vote; the Democrats almost unanimously refused to vote, while Mr. CALKINS, of Indiana, voted that TILLMAN was not entitled to his seat, but ...

Yesterday was the third day of the midsummer meeting of the Monmouth Park Association, and although the weather was sultry and oppressive, there was a large attendance of spectators. An attractive programme had been provided, and the six races which were contested brought out the enthusiasm of the crowd.

The examination room of the Jefferson Market Police Court was crowded yesterday by spectators interested in the proceedings instituted by Messrs. Aymar and Bach, of the Racquet Club, against Patrolmen Ringler, Lehne, Weeks, and Phelps for assault and battery and illegal arrest.

There were no new developments in connection with the freight handlers strike in Jersey City yesterday. For the first time since the strike commenced the usual daily meeting was dispensed with. The strikers, however, gathered in and about Hamilton Park, and quietly discussed the situation.
Tables recently issued by the Bureau of Statistics furnish the most complete presentation of the immigration movement to this country procurable anywhere.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--The Sanitary Committee of the Board of Health presented to the main body to-day a report on the impurities in the Schuylkill River, which occasioned some alarm a week or two ago. Examinations and analysis made by Drs. Taylor and Cresson trace the trouble ...

SARATOGA, July 19.--Last night's rain made the track heavy. The weather was bright and warm until the finish of the third race, when the heavens suddenly became clouded and a heavy shower broke, lasting for half an hour. The attendance was very good, despite it being an extra day. The ladies were present in large numbers.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--Judge Wylie made an important announcement in the Criminal Court to-day, declaring that the Government had submitted enough evidence to carry the question of the existence of a conspiracy to the jury. The bearing of this ruling can best be shown by a brief review of the course of the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--Gen. J. Rufino Barrios, President of the Republic of Guatemala, and his party, including Senor Don Fernando Cruz, Minister of State, arrived in this city this morning and proceeded quietly to the quarters selected for them at the Arlington Hotel. There was no official reception.

COLUMBUS, July 19.--The crowds which put in an appearance to-day guarantee a convention of the largest dimensions. The contest as it now appears will reach far beyond the mere work of nominating a State ticket. It is likely that there will be a bitter contest between the factions to gain control of the party ...
A company of children from Boston will sing in "Patience" at Wallack's new theatre, beginning Monday evening, July 31.
Michael Kurtz, alias Michael Sheehan, who is known to the Police as "Sheeny Mike." one of the most expert and notorious burglars in this country, was a prisoner at Police Head-quarters yesterday.
For five months past Senator Ben H. Hill, of Georgia, has subsisted on liquid food alone.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The completed report of the Department of Agriculture on the condition of crops for the month of July shows that there is an increased area in potatoes in nearly every State and Territory--the natural effect of the high price. This increase amounts to about 7 per cent. Condition is also high, falling little short of 100 anywhere and averaging 102.

At a meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday, a communication was received from Topographical Engineer E.B. Van Winkle asking the Commissioners to take some action in regard to an assault made on Assistant Engineer Stephen S. Haight, of the department, on June 23, by Col. James F. Mooney, of the Department of Public Works, and a well-known Westchester politician.
WASHINGTON, July 19, 1882. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $412,496.87, and from Customs $1,157,606.96. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amount to $159,000.

While it cannot be established that his errand ...

ALBANY, July 19.--The Greenbackers had so much trouble in fixing up their platform to suit the conflicting views of the delegates that they could not open the convention this morning till an hour or more after thetime appointed.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Superintendent of Mounted Recruiting Service will cause 22 recruits to be prepared and sent, under proper charge, to Maricopa, Arizona Territory, for assignment to Troop H. Sixth Cavalry.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--Mr. Beck's amendment to the Internal Revenue bill, reducing the tax on tobacco to 12 cents a pound, was adopted to-day, upon the heels of a long and somewhat uninteresting discussion of the tobacco question. Twenty-nine Senators, including Messrs. Jones, of Nevada, ...

The steamer Rhode Island, of the Providence Line, and the steam-ship Alhambra, of the Quebec Steam-ship Company, met in collision early yesterday morning in the middle of Long Island Sound, a few miles from New-Haven. Although the crash was tremendous and the results disastrous to both boats, none of the passengers were injured. Edward Marshall, ...

The Medical Society of South Carolina, at a special meeting held in Charleston on the 12th inst., appointed Drs. J. Ford Prioleau, F.L. Parker, and Manning Simons as a committee to frame resolutions expressing the views of the society as to the professional conduct of Dr. R.A. Kinlock, a fellow-member, in the case of Mrs. Loughton Reid. This lady died on June 21 while under the influence ...

WASHINGTON, July 20.--In the House today, Mr. Calkins, of Indiana, called up the resolution offered by him yesterday, reciting that it had been asserted by Mr. Blackburn, of Kentucky, that a mistake made by the tally clerk in footing up a roll call was a falsification of the record, and directing a special committee of three members to inquire into the matter.

The second extra day's racing at Monmouth Park yesterday was of a sensational character, and repaid those who made the long journey to the course in the oppressive heat. The attendance of spectators was light, as the programme was not especially, attractive yet, in close and brilliant finishes the contests of yesterday were collectively superior to those of any preceding day, and the time made was very fast.

WASHINGTON, July 20.--The entire day in the star route trial was devoted to argument upon the question of the admissibility of Mr. Walsh's testimony, and the court will give a decision to-morrow morning. The most prominent feature of the proceedings was Mr. Merrick's admirable and eloquent argument for the Government, an argument worthy of his high reputation as a lawyer and an orator.
It is understood from leading Republicans that no more contested election cases will be called up for action during the present session of Congress.

The Orion nine, a Philadelphia organization composed of colored ball-players, were the opponents of the Metropolitans in a game played on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of about 1,500 persons. The colored men were a failure as ball-players, and presented a mirth-provoking spectacle, which was heartily enjoyed by the spectators.

Miss Fanny Parnell, sister of Charles Stewart Parnell, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of paralysis of the heart at the family mansion, in Bordertown, N.J. Miss Parnell was subject to attacks from the heart, and would sometimes be in an apparent trance.

Less confidence in the immediate success of their movement was expressed yesterday by the striking freight handlers. It was plain to see that the railroads were handling freight with no great difficulty. Help, and plenty of it, was to be obtained, and the railroads received every pound of freight that came to their houses.

Michael Kurtz, alias Michael Sheehan, alias "Sheeny Mike," the thief and bank burglar, who was arrested for complicity in the burglary at the Banca Italo-Americana in the Staats-Zeitung Building, was arraigned before Justice Smith at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. In his company were arraigned John Love, alias Lowery,

Robert M.G. Dodge, of No. 137 Cumberland-street, Brooklyn, was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, charged, on complaint of George W. Alger, President of the Emporium and Franklin Fire Insurance Company, No. 237 Broadway, with disorderly conduct.

invest a Fourth of July celebration with international characteristics, to make it the pleasant meeting-ground of a social reunion among the leading resident Americans of London and their English friends.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 20.--Newport is receiving a visitation of July fog, which is dense at night and during the day lifts for a few hours to allow people to get the bearings, whe it envelops the town and harbor for the next night.

LONG BRANCH, July 20.--The nine members of the Tariff Commission were present at the first formal meeting of that body, which was held at the West End to-day. The President, Mr. John L. Hayes, of Massachusetts, occupied the chair.
