ATLANTA, July 20.--Upon the assembling of the Democratic State Convention this morning Mr. Bacon's name as a candidate for Governor was withdrawn from the contest by reason of the abrogation of the two-thirds rule. Alexander H. Stephens was nominated upon the call of counties, receiving 325 votes.

In the report which the Insurance Commissioner of the State of Massachusetts has recently issued he calls attention to the necessity of providing some better means for the protection of insurance contracts. The class of contracts specially referred to by him are those made between fire insurance companies and the holders of the policies.

The Century for August, which has just been issued, contains in its "Topics of the Time," a very thorough account of the controversy in regard to tha Metropolitan Museum of Art and its Director. The whole ground has been carefully examined, and all the testimony has been weighed. Commencing with the first charge against the integrity of the Cesnola collection, which appeared in the Art Amateur of August, 1881, the article concluded ...

If the circular alleged to have been sent by the Secretary of the Navy to the officers and employes of the Government under his direction be correctly described, the inference that hes been drawn as to its motive is not only a fair one, but is inevitable.

The result of the preliminary skirmish along the Democratic lines in Ohio is a defeat of THURMAN and JOHN G. THOMPSON. It may fairly he said that THOMPSON represents the machine and ex-Senator THURMAN.

CHICAGO, July 20.--It was remarked to-day that the recent advance in foreign freight rates was the thing that knocked wheat prices, but that freights could scarcely keep up at a high point on this crop. The paying of sixpence will set numerous vessels on the way for New-York, and there is little corn to compete with the wheat that will be carried across the ocean.

His Majesty the ex-King of Zulu-land is about to make a visit to England. A committee has been appointed to represent the Netherlands at the International Fisheries Exhibition to be held in London during 1883.

The nomination of ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Georgia is calculated still further to complicate the somewhat mixed politics of that State. Mr. STEPHENS occupies a peculiar position among Southern Democrats.

LONDON, July 20.--While the English forces are doing little or nothing, Arabi Pasha, according to the dispatches received from Alexandria and elsewhere, is making the most of the delay in strengthening his position and seeking to make alliances with his neighbors.

In estimating England's weakness as a military power we have drawn attention to the fact, remarks the United Service Gazette, that the sum total of forces at her command to operate abroad would on emergency be about 16,500 men, which number might be increased by calling out the reserve.

FORT SNELLING, Minn., July 20.--The second day's shooting of the Western Rifle Association took place to-day under very favorable circumstances. The weather was fine, the attendance large, and the shooting of some of the contestants excellent.

A commotion was caused on Wednesday night on board the steamer Jesse Hoyt, which plies between Sandy Hook and this City in connection with the New-Jersey Southern Railroad, conveying passengers to Long Branch, by David Scott, a fish-dealer in Fulton Market, living at No. 1,017...
WASHINGTON, July 20.--It is not often that a political speech made by a Republican at the expense of a Democrat is enjoyed by the Democrats as thoroughly as it is by the Republicans.

PROVIDENCE, July 20.--Owen Donnelly, 36 years old, porter for Mason, Chapin Co., wholesale druggists, was arrested this morning by a policeman concealed in the store, just as he had robbed the safe of six packages of gold leaf. The robberies had continued several months. At Donnelly's house was a stock of stolen goods valued at $1,500. In the Justice's court he pleaded guilty, ...

Two coarse-looking women of middle age, and a young man of 25, of good appearance, stood at the bar of the General Sessions Court yesterday, having been called up for sentence by Assistant District Attorney O'Byrne.

RED BANK, July 20.--Track-master Marshall, of the New-Jersey Central Railroad, whose home is at this place, has sworn out an affidavit against Alexander Kier for manslaughter. Kier, it will be remembered, is the section foreman who built the switch on the bridge at Parker's Creek, where the recent great railroad disaster occurred.

Fireman Michael Commerford, whose heroism in the rescue of imperiled lives in a tenementhouse fire in January marked him as the most de serving among several candidates for the Bennett medal, yesterday received the reward for brave devotion to duty.
Cardinal McCloskey, has gone to Ogdensburg. He will be the guest of Bishop Wadhams. THE TIMES has received $25 for the Sick Children's Mission, which sum has been forwarded to the proper quarter.

SARATOGA, July 20.--This was the fifth regular day of the races. The attendance was large, the track in fair shape, and the betting lively. The officers of the day were: Judges--Col. R.W. Simmons, W.I. Montague, and C. Fellowes; Timers-- T.J. Dwyer and J.H. Smith; Starter--Major J. Gwynn; Secretary and Clerk of Scales--C. Wheatley.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 20.--The day for the Democratic State Convention opened bright and cool--one well calculated to bring about a more harmonious feeling among the disturbing elements within the breasts of the old Moss-backs and the clique of young Democrats backed by the Cincinnati Enquirer.

The Royal Agricultural meeting, held this year at Reading, promises to resemble the Royal Academy Exhibition in that, although there may not be a conspicuous sensation in the show, there will be found average excellence everywhere.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 20.--A paragraph appeared in the newspapers recently to the effect that Gen. Beauregard was in 1870 offered the command of the Egyptian Army, but that the tender was subsequently withdrawn through the influence of George H. Butler, than United States Consul at Alexandria.

Gen. Newton M. Curtis, a Special Agent of the Treasury Department in the New-York Custom-house, was convicted recently of receiving money paid to him as assessments by Federal employes, and to be used for political purposes. His counsel, ex-United States Attorney-General Smith, moved, before the United States Circuit Court, in which the conviction was had, for an arrest of judgment and a new trial.

Whenever a mule dies in Atlanta, Ga., the sympathetic Constitution makes a news item of it. A youth of 3 years is one of the heavy dragoons in a performance of "Patience" being given in Memphis, Tenn.

BOSTON, July 20.--Sporting society in this city has not yet recovered from the shock which it received on Monday night when the news was telegraphed from New-York that Mr. John L. Sullivan, of Boston, had failed to "knock out" Mr. Tug Wilson, of England, in the Madison-Square ...

WASHINGTON, July 20.--The conference report on the River and Harbor bill was presented in the House to-day, but as a long debate upon it was threatened it was withdrawn. The committee has reduced the aggregate amount of specific appropriations contained in the bill, as it passed the Senate, about $350,000. BOSTON, July 20.--One of the best proofs which ticket brokers could have to offer in order to show that railroads and steam-boat corporations find it to their interests to encourage them was exhibited in the treatment which the brokers received while on their way from New-York and Western and Southern cities to attend the fourth annual convention of the American Ticket Brokers' Association held in the Hotel Brunswick, in this city, yesterday and to-day.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 20.--The First District Democratic Congressional Convention, which met here to-day, nominated Lyman Redington, of Rutland.
CHICAGO, July 21.--There was much waiting--anxious waiting--for to-day's announcement of the decision in regard to Spring wheat for June. It came at noon, and came like a clap of thunder to many.
When the social history of London comes to be written there will be no more pathetic chapter than that which records the rise, decline, and fall of curates.

It may fairly be said that Senator PENDLETON made the best of a weak cause in his speech at the close of the Ohio Democratic convention, on Thursday last. The time has passed when a party platform carries with it any special significance.

The case of Robert Johnson, a carman, against the Merchants' Dispatch Transportation Company, was called for trial in the Eighth Judicial District Court, Justice Gedney presiding, yesterday. The case was an outcome of the freight handlers' strike.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21.--The idea of the purchase of the charter and franchises of the Philadelphia and Chester County Railroad by the Baltimore and Ohio Road has been abandoned.
In a letter to the London Times, Mr. G.F. Stephen, a son of Sir James Stephen, writes as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 21.--The House Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day directed Representative Kasson to report to the House, with a favorable recommendation, a substitute agreed upon by the committee for Representative Rosecrans's bill "to incorporate the Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua."

There was a collision off the Battery about 10:30 o'clock last night between the iron steamboat Pegasus and a mysterious craft supposed to be either an ice barge or a car float. The Pegasus was on her way up from Coney Island, and was due at Pier No. 1 at 11:15, but was ahead of time.
--Mr. G. Barnett Smith is engaged in writing a "Life of Channing." --The third divisional volume of Dr. Robert Hunter's "Encyclopaedic Dictionary," is promised during the month.

ST. LOUIS, July 21.--A band of counterfeiters has been arrested by the Police. Their names are William Hall, alias Wiakler; W.H. Perry, alias Weaver, alias Bennett, alias Bassett; Mollie Hall, alias Newton, and William Anderson. The gang is believed to have been manufacturers of spurious coin.

A St. Petersburg correspondent states that the arrest of Nihilists has resulted in the imprisonment of 47 persons altogether. In the lodging itself there were two men and one woman. A fourth member of the party had been captured on the Nicholas Bridge while returning home.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--Some days ago a report was current about the capital that a statement had been forwarded to the House Committee on the Judiciary containing charges of a serious nature respecting the psssage of the Texas Pacific Land Grant bill.

The Hon. W.H.H. Bingham, of Vermont has so far recovered his health as to be able to go out.
The lard-refining firm of W.J. Wilcox Co., of No. 41 Broad-street has become financially embarrassed, and yesterday announced a temporary suspension of business.
The country has received the recent change in the management of the Military Academy at West Point without comment because the true inwardness thereof was not apparent.

There will be music on the Mall in Central Park this afternoon, commencing at 4 o'clock. Annie Felt, 8 months of age, fell out of the fourth story of the tenement-house No. 14 Ludlowstreet, yesterday, to the yard, and was killed.

The outlook for the striking freight handlers was no more reassuring yesterday than it was the day before, and it was quite evident that only a heavy and prolonged rush of freight would compel the railroads to surrender.

BOSTON, July 21.--The July meeting at Beacon Park closed this afternoon under circumstances of a peculiar character, so far as concerns the rulings of the judges, J.F. Haynes, of Biddeford; Joshua Wilkins, of East Braintree, and Ira Blokford, of Boston.

We told last week of the meeting between the late John S.C. Abbott and Cullen Sawtelle (classmates) so pathetically related by the latter at the dedication of Memorial Hall. We have something of an amusing character to relate.

Thirty-three head of Jersey cattle, the property of W.H.T Hughes, of Great Neck, Long Island, and constituting what is known as the "St. Helier's Herd." mostly imported annimals, were sold at auction on Pier No. 16 East River, yesterday, by Peter C. Kellogg Co.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--By order of MajorGen. Hancock, the members of the division team of 1881 will assemble at Governor's Island on Aug. 3 to receive the prizes won by them in the competitions for places. There are 12 of these prizes. The first was won by First Lieut. W.B. Homer, Fifth Artillery.

The Metropolitan nine succeeded in disposing of another League club on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, when they defeated the strong representative League nine of Providence. The game, which was witnessed by upward of 2,000 persons, was an exciting one from start to finish,

WASHINGTON, July 21.--All argument having been closed in the Criminal Court upon the question of the admissibility of the evidence of the witness Walsh, Judge Wylie this morning delivered his decision upon that important subject.

There is a growing impression that the result of the contest between Mr. John L. Sullivan, of Boston, and Mr. Tug Wilson, of England, in the Madison-Square Garden on last Monday evening was prearranged, as was intimated in THE TIMES of the 15th inst. (two days before the event) might be the case.

LONG BRANCH, July 21.--The witnesses who were expected to appear before the Tariff Commission somehow failed to make connection with the several railroad and steam-boat lines between New-York and this point, and as the result no testimony was taken by the Commissioners to-day.

The application for a new trial, made by the defendants in the case of John T. SARATOGA, July 21.--To-day's excellent programme brought a large concourse of spectators to the track. The weather was delightfully cool, the track was in excellent condition, and the betting brisk.

BOSTON, July 22.--A fire broke out in Fairfield, Me., last evening, but only meagre particulars have as yet been received. The fire seems to have started on Water-street, on the banks of the Kennebec River, among the saw-mills, of which there are a number in that vicinity.

LONDON, July 21.--At a meeting of 100 Conservative peers at Lord Salisbury's residence, it was decided to allow the Irish Arrears bill to pass its second reading in the House of Lords, but to introduce amendments to the bill in committee.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22.--The gross earnings of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company for June were $174,843.38, being an increase as compared with the corresponding month of last year of $17,955.12.
CHICAGO, July 22.--The bottom fall out of the market for regular wheat to-day. The market for next month declined about 3 cents, closing at the bottom, while July broke fully 4 cents.

LONDON, July 22.--A dispatch from Alexandria, dated 9:30 this morning, says that Major-Gen. Alison was then just moving out with two regiments of infantry and a mounted squadron in the direction of Arabi Pasha's intrenchments. This movement was expected to lead to an engagement.
--Sophie Arnould, a celebrated dancer in her day and generation, is to have a statue in the foyer of the Paris Opera. The sculptor is Mme. Leon Bertaut.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 22.--We are within 10 days of the meeting of the Democratic State Convention, and another so harassed and bewildered set of politicians as the self-assumed leaders of that organization would be hard to find.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 22.--The sensation of the day is the termination of a four years' lawsuit between Dr. Frank and Mrs. Gussic Flower for the possession of their 8-year-old son. The case was decided to-day under peculiar circumstances, and the child was given into the custody of the mother.

The Troy League nine again met defeat at the hands of the Metropolitan Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of about 3,000 spectators. The Trojans were at a disadvantage by the absence of both Keefe and Welch, their regular pitchers, and the position was very poorly filled by Ferguson, the manager of the team.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 22.--The strike at the Cleveland Rolling Mills, which began on May 8, may now be pronounced ended. Wonder if Mr. Robert R. Hitt, who was nominated for Congress by the convention at Freeport yesterday, ever recalls to mind an incident that occurred in that city 24 years ago, in which he was a somewhat conspicuous figure. If not, we can refresh his memory, having been there and then present.

Money was disbursed from the general fund of the Freight Handlers' Union to the needy strikers in this City yesterday. BELFAST, July 10.--Of Dublin the visitor might say that its glares are in the past, that its present is dull and commonplace, and that the possibilities of its future must be measured by contingencies not likely soon to happen. It is the centre of much political activity, and that is all. Its social brilliancy is gone. Its industrial and commercial life is all but extinct.

CONCORD, Mass., July 22.--The Emerson day has passed off with even greater success than was anticipated. The weather was exceptionally fine. The cars came loaded with men and women who are believers in Emerson and are true to his memory. The speakers kept their several appointments.

Middleton, of Charleston, S.C., who is spending the season as usual at the Ocean House. In the palmy days of slavery the Summer residents of Newport were all known as "Southerners."

CHICAGO, July 26.--A dispatch from Rome, by way of London, this morning, announces that Archbishop Feehan, of Chicago, will be created a Cardinal at the next Consistory. ST. PAUL, July 30.--A heavy, persistent rain-storm, setting in about noon and lasting all day, causes some apprehension as to the safety of the crops. If it shall prove to be widespread, the barley harvest, now in progress, will be interrupted and the grain will suffer.

LONDON, July 31.--In the House of Lords this afternoon, on a motion to go into committee on the Irish Arrears of Rent bill, the Earl of Camperdown (Liberal) asked for some assurance that no further important changes relative to contracts between landlord and tenant in Ireland would be proposed.

A number of Devonshire and other worthies meet at the Mansion House to-day to provide for the due celebration of the tercentenary of Drake. It is 300 years since Sir Francis Drake sailed round the world, the first Englishman that ever made this mundane circuit. For this great exploit his Queen and his country honored him, and the people of Plymouth especially desire to keep his memory green.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31.--A curious story has come to light by the filing of a petition for the appointment of a commission to inquire into the mental condition of Francis Kerbaugh, 81 years old, of this city. ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 31.--At Seneca Falls, last night, roughs forced an entrance into Moreland's saloon and beat Mrs. Moreland. She died this morning. The murdered woman was about to become a mother.

Gen. Skobeleff died possessed of a large fortune. His annual income from it is reckoned to have been about 100,000 rubles. By his will he gave but a small sum to his divorced wife; the remainder he divided in equal shares among his three sisters, the Duchess of Leuchtenberg, Princess Belorsilski, and Princess Beauharnais. It was through the Princess Beauharnais that Skobeleff was related to the imperial family of Russia.

A singular life history was involved in an adjudication filed yesterday by Judge Ashman, of the Orphans' Court, in the estate of John Naulty, deceased. Mr. Naulty was widely known in business circles in North and South America and in Europe. He died in Buenos Ayres in January, 1879, leaving an estate valued at $500,000.
